reviews.review: Excellent . Ricardo was my tour guy. He was fun, accommodating, and knowledgeable diver. He made me feel very safe every minute. I was in a small group of 5. There was another group of about the same. There is no basic enterance. Tour is a must to keep us safe. One of the best experiences I have had in Riviera Maya so far. I am not fond of group tours but this was a great one worth the money I paid (500 pesos or 30 usd). If you are looking for an experience in Rio Secreto at a cheaper price then I strongly suggest this ( although two are different while being similar). I paid taxi 90 on the way there and 70 on the way back at near the end of Juarez avenue away from Playa. Cab drivers ask $150-200 but you can negotiate. Again Ricardo did a great job guiding us along the cave it was a little more than 2 hr tour in the end. Ask them to call a cab for you. They will.

Once in a Lifetime Adventure!. We agree with all the other great reviews of this excursion booked through Carnival Cruises. Eli was an excellent tour guide. Knowledgeable, caring, and organized. The swim through the cenotes was exciting and inspiring. We were given a locker, water shoes, life vest, flashlights, and snorkel equipment. A beautiful walk through the jungle led to the caverns where we took several swims. The water was a bit chilly, but not a problem. Afterwards we enjoyed a simple mayan lunch, and a tequila tasting and talk. This was definitely the highlight of our week! I am not in great shape but was able to do all the physical aspects of the tour.

Amazingly beautiful and busy!. It's definitely a must see but there are so many people that it makes it almost unenjoyable. It is stunning and you will get some great pictures but with 50 other people in the background. You have to move with the masses in and out of the water. Maybe find a time when hundreds of other people aren't there. Bring money for a locker if you plan on swimming.

Very nice activity!. Me and my husband visited the cenote which was beautiful. The guides that work there are very professional and Mario our guide was very nice and attentive. The only thing that was bothering us is that we paid 500 pesos per person and the guide told us that his job was voluntary, so it makes you feel you need to give him a nice tip, cause eventually he was great guide. So I wonder to whom those 1000 pesos were going to if the guides are not getting paid??

Cenote Chaak Tun. Great cenote only 10 minutes from Playa. There are surface trails to explore and of course a cave system. They have snorkel equipment and wet suits if you desire. A guide will show you around. The water is very cool, clear and refreshing. It was neat to explore a real cave system not just some tourist trap. There were only a few other people there.

Took some amazing Pictures. Visited with family. Took some amazing pictures. Entered the cold waters but honestly only lasted 10 minutes because i became frighten by being inclosed and underground. First time experiencing it but somehow hesitant to stay longer. Seen some bats in the cave they didn't bother us. Water was cold and clear blue. Intimidated by some of the fish in the water and some of the dark areas. However worth visiting to capture good pictures and witness its hidden beauties.

Amazing place, better people. Highly recommend!!. Amazing experience for my whole family. From my 3 year old son to my 70 year old father, everyone had a blast. The staff was incredibly friendly, patient and kind. You won't see billboards and flyers for this place which means they don't have to charge you $150 per person like some of the other places. Way better than only other place we have been. I highly recommend you take taxi and see one of the coolest natural attractions in the area.

Awesome Check it out Something for everyone at this great Cenote. For some reason this Cenote doesn't seem to get all the hype you find in some adventure parks or other main tour path like on the way to Chichen Itza. We felt very safe at this facility and the staff , gear , language, Mayan lunch and good restrooms etc were nice. So the surprises were the amount of dry trails you can explore on your own after the snorkeling at your leisure and take as many pictures as you want. The caverns twist and turn so lots to see. Beautiful underworld experience you will remember always. With snorkel gear you get flashlights and excellent close support. You will find fun little fish that nibble on your hands and toes in places and there are also bats in crevices above that you may see. You may or may not get this offer on your tour but they may ask if anyone wants to venture underwater to another small room you surface in and then move again under water to another narrow cave that you swim along to get to a large other main room that is on private property they get permission to go to. If you get this chance by all means do this. Only takes 5 min to get access to 2nd main room. The wetsuits hold the water against your body so this keeps you warm as it heats up. You will get the help you need if you are not sure about anything about snorkeling. They can explain more about it to you if needed.
A WOW!. We had the BEST time cave snorkeling and then a delicious lunch down in another cave and then the perfect ending...tequila tasting, YUM!
HIghlight of our trip. Ricardo was our guide. He was amazing and made everyone feel safe and comfortable. The cenote was beautiful!

Very interesting experience but don't bring infant. We took the royal Caribbean shore excursions. We ride the speedboat and our guide, pabio, pick us up with a nice van with ac. It took less then 20 mins to arrive. We pick up our snorkel mask, flash light and water shoes. The water inside the cenote is cold, but your body will get use to it. I took my 18 months son and it was too cold for him. He was crying for the entire time and I felt sorry for him and my tour mate. The cave is beautiful and it is a very unique experience. The swim lasted for hour and then they offer lunch in another cave. There is a tequila tasting presentation after lunch. Overall I really like it.

Great place to see. This was a great place to visit. It really shows the beauty of nature. My only negative comment would be to give every person a flashlight instead of each couple. The caves can be vary dark. This tour is also not for those who have difficulty walking, especially up and down stairs or those unable to bend and maneuver through tight spots. Our guide was knowledgeable and showed passion for what he did. We got to exfoliate using the calcium which was fantastic. Our tour included lunch and tequila tasting. Make sure to bring cash for this!!! They give a great education on how to tell organic vs commercial tequila.

Indescribable experience. This is a very special cenote, a place where you can feel the age of this planet in your bones. It may not be recommended for the faint of heart, but I would love to go back and would recommend it without a doubt. We didn't even know this existed and thanks to our private guide Monica we could experience this magical place. Clear, ice cold water, stalactites everywhere, bats flying around while you swim/walk and an overall feeling that can't be described.If you have the chance to go, do it. You won't regret it.

Great dive - bucket list. Amazing dive definetly one for the bucket list beautiful clear water the light was amazing not a tough dive just need to be confident and able bodied as its a little bit of a walk to the water

Best shore excursion.. This is the second time my wife and I have visitited Chaak Tun. Both times we were amazed by the beauty of the area. The tour takes approximately 3-5 hours. The guides are very kind and respectful and do speak English very well. An authentic Mayan lunch was served during our tour. Modern facilities (bathrooms) are provided and it looked as if improvements were beginning. Our group consisted of approximately 16 people ranging in age from 12-60+ with varying degrees of mobility. Some of the restrictions within the cenote (cave) required some ducking and there are a few steps. Overall, for my wife and I it was something we had to experience again.

Beyond Amazing. Everything about this was amazing. The guide was very informative not only about the tour, but about what times and locations we needed to be at in order to return to our ship. He made sure we all understood directions and safety before entering the caves. Once inside he stopped and made sure to check on everyone periodically to see if the were okay. At the end we had authentic Mayan food in the cavern. It was simply amazing. I will hands down return. Our tour guide was Eli.

Underground coolness.. Cool trip through 2 underground caverns. Swimming/wading through the refreshing waters is a great plus to combat the humidity outside. Our guide was highly knowledgeable and entertaining. Lunch served below ground was tasty. Also, they supply water shoes, life vests, and flashlights.

Very interesting. It is an amazing site! The food is good not great. It is very hard to read the menu because of lack of light, it would be a great help if the waiters had flashlights. It was extremely warm, they have fans all around but it is still very warm when the weather outside is so hot and humid.

Otherworldly!. This is an experience I will never forget! Your in the middle of the hot jungle and exploring these caverns is cool and refreshing! They will provide water shoes, snorkeling gear and a locker (or you can bring your own) you don't have to be a strong swimmer because there are life vests as well! I recommend you bring an underwater camera to capture it all, it's not super touristy, it was only myself and my girlfriend and our fantastic guide Felipe!Felipe let us take our time, explaining the Mayan references and the geological references, I would do it again anytime! I would suggest getting your own cab out car service to and from (it was about 400 peso round-trip from 5th Ave in Playa del Carmen)Don't worry about the bats, they don't bother you, just go with it! Seriously, this was natural beauty at its finest!

Fantastic way to visit the Mayan underworld!. We visited Chaak Tun for an afternoon while in Playa del Carmen. It is very close to the beach resorts and a wonderful way to escape the heat of the day. Our tour guide was Mario and he was wonderful. He accommodated English and Spanish-speaking guests and shared some great stories about the history of the cenote. We did not wear the wet suits and were quite comfortable. Then again, we are from Wisconsin....
a must cenote to visit. you need to visit as many cenotes as you can for a once in a lifetime experience... each is different and worth taking a look

Tour. We booked a tour here as part of our trip. The cenotes were amazing and the guide very knowledgeable. However I give only 3 stars as they didn't provide any pick up information from our hotel and we were waiting 2 hours and ended up catching a can. Also more information re : photography options would have been appreciated

Great Time and Cenote's are a must!. We came in late and we were the last tour of the day. We did a tour with Abel and he was very hands on and a very nice guy. He showed us around the caves and explained everything in great detail. I feel like it was a short tour because we were the last group to go that day because we didn't get to see the sharks. But all in all it was a great experience and everyone on my trip had a great time here. I would definitely recommend this cenote.

Getaway from the Resort and check this out!. We took a cab (highly discouraged by our resort personnel because I believe they wanted us to invest in their day pacakages). It was so worth it to be away from the resort and people and rudeness. This place is peaceful, beautiful, simple. We really enjoyed swimming in this amazing water with flashlights, exploring a really really beautiful underground world.

If you don't visit a cenote while visiting the Yucatan, you're a fool and deserve to have your tourist card revoked.. The way a wet suit works is pretty simple: it retains layer of water between your skin and the suit, which your body heat warms up and keeps you nice and comfortable. I tell you this because if you decide to piss while you're underwater wearing a wet suit, you're going to marinate in Corona and asparagus for the duration of your stay at this cenote. And when you take it off, you and your swimsuit will smell like a hobo in a porta-potty. Some people are into that, which makes me a little wary in disclosing this little tip since I've inadvertently turned on some people I would otherwise steer clear of, but there it is.The Yucatan peninsula is known for rich Mayan history, cenotes, and drunk white people. Visiting Chaak Tun will cover the first two, which are the best parts of this region. There are over 1,000 cenotes in the Yucatan, and if you fail to visit at least one of them, what the hell did you visit this area for? The bottom-shelf liquor at your all-inclusive resort? To hook up with some drunk Ohio State undergrad with a 2.1 GPA in psychology? For goddamn Coco Bongo?Honestly, you can do all that crap and still have time to hit up a cenote. Chaak Tun is maybe 15 minutes from Playa Del Carmen, tops. My girlfriend and I went yesterday, and it was just us and three Brazilian ladies. Normally Brazilians are louder than a Cuban lady doing a fire alarm impression, but these were cool. A tour group of five is ideal, because it gives you enough time to snap some photos and get a good feel for the place without being the jerk who holds everyone up. 500 pesos gets you access, a tour guide, locker, flashlight, vest, wet suit, mask, snorkel, and probably a communicable disease.Our guide, Felipe, gave us a history of cenotes in the Yucatan and some insight into Mayan culture, then took us to two cenotes. The first was a cavern (they’ll explain the difference between a cave and a cavern; I won’t, because I forgot). There were bats everywhere. I learned the difference between stalactites and stalagmites (I forgot). We had a moment of silence underground, in cold water, in complete darkness. It was beautiful. Seeing all the different rock formations, minerals, catfish, turtles, and bats just going about their business in one of the most virgin commercial cenotes was magical. I also offended a few spirits by farting into my wetsuit and giggling when the stinky bubbles ran up my back and came out from my collar. This cavern wraps around and has some great sights. This one alone was worth the ~$25 USD.The second was of the swimming pool variety. It’s just a big circular fresh water pool underground teeming with bats and catfish with a depth of about 15 feet. It’s pretty serene to just float on your back and listen to the chirps of the bats, the light splashes of your wading, and your fart bubbles.Look, for the price of a crappy meal at a crappy place, you’ll be able to see and experience something that very few people alive will ever get to see.Also, the fart bubbles.

Very interesting site to explore. It is important to know that you are not allowed to visit the cave/cenote on your own. When you arrive they let you know that a tour is required and cost $500 pesos. Typically they take up to 10 people but our group ended up being larger. And the frequent requests for tips is going to be part of the experience. The benefits are that all of the equipment, including wetsuits and flashlights are provided, and the cave/cenote experience is unique and amazing. The tour lasts about 2 hours, including time spent in the jungle listening to some history of the mayan culture and bug spray is not allowed. Most of the time is spent in the water underground and it can be a bit chilly but the experience is worth it! Even if you aren't a comfortable swimmer or aren't that excited about going underground exploring, this is a safe enjoyable excursion!

Bat Cave . You can get really close to bats, they'll even fly around you. The water is chilly but they offer wet suits for those who cannot handle the cold. Bring water shoes, face mask and snorkel although they are all provided as well. You must wear a life jacket throughout the water cave tours. Abel, our tour guide spoke very good English and explained all the formations very well. As most tours go, please be prepared to tip your tour guide.

Un-commercialized Cenote Just Outside of Playa del Carmen . This is a cenote that is very natural and hasn't been modified/developed to look like an amusement park. Even the people in a local dive shop where I bought some stuff hadn't heard of Chaak Tun and it's only 5 miles from downtown. Round trip transport from my condo in Playa was $15 for a new A/C'd van which arrived early. Abel was our guide (maybe 8 people in our group) and he gave us an entertaining (and for the more adventurous, challenging) tour. They provide everything you need.. mask, snorkel, water shoes (no fins allowed), life vests, water proof flashlights and wetsuits. The water in Cenotes is cold so I definitely recommend putting on a wetsuit. The tour is 2 underground water-filled caverns, the main areas of which are large with high ceilings. However, Abel took us on a couple "excursions" where there is as little as a foot of space between the water and the stalagmites above... not for the claustrophobic! You can, however refrain from these excursions. Lighting is minimal to maintain the natural atmosphere. This is an in-the-water tour, not a walking tour. It's an incredible look at a world that most people never see and which has been there for (millions?) of years. For me, awesome.

Absolutely Amazing! Highlight of our trip!. I cannot begin to say enough about this place! This was the most terrifying, most exhilarating, most AMAZING experience of my life! Our tour guide, Abel, made this whole experience worth while! I have traveled to many places all over the world including many different places in the Caribbean and this, by far, tops them all! If you are looking for a spectacular adventure without all the "tourist" fluff, then this is it! Forget all the big named heavily advertised places! This is definitely the best kept secret in Playa del Carmen! But if I have anything to do with it, it won't be for very long! LOVED IT!
Awesome place to visit. The tour guide Sam made this tour the best. I would definitely recommend going to tis cenote but only with Sam since he made the trip worth while.
Beautiful experience. The cenote was a stunning place, magical. You can swim there, take photos. to bring the swim set with you absoloutely.

Amazing cenote adventure!. We had such a good time at the Chaak Tun cenote! Me and 2 of my friends came on a less busy day and were lucky enough to get a tour by ourselves. Our tour guide, Abel, was so professional and made us feel really safe. Even my friend who doesn't know how to swim had a blast!! The water was nice and cool for a hot day, the caves were amazing. We could all agree that this was the highlight of our days in Playa del Carmen and would highly recommend it to eveeryone who wants a super cool snorkeling experience.

Chaak Tum . Best decision we have made. Great tour and the best tour guide Rico. We arrived around 2 and was able to get right in. The tour lasted about 2 hours and was only 30USD and they provided everything. Great experience and highly recommended.
2h discovery-tour for $25 . Great tour guide (Rico), you get life jackets, snorchling equipment, shoes and a flashlight. 200 pesos if you take a cap from Playacar (Riu-Hotels).

Get away from the touristy attractions for some natural beauty. This gem is located off the beaten path, so make sure you have maps/GPS, etc. before heading out. Once here, however, and after paying admission (can't remember, but not too expensive), you are treated to an amazing natural beauty. The water in this cenote is crystal clear, and nice and cool. Not only is it beautiful, but there's a rope swing if you're feeling adventurous, and they usually have some flotation devices around if you just want to cruise around the cenote. The entire environment is serene and relaxing. Definitely worth the time and money!
Breath Taking!. We were not expecting this part of the trip, ( hadn't really listed past the swimming of turtles bit) but OMG it was amazing!

Fun and interesting. These people are very kind and accommodating. The tour is exciting and the water feels amazing. I would not recommend this for young children. This is not a big bustling park. We loved that it was a more intimate setting and off the beaten path. We learned a lot from our tour.

Overly hyped for what it is. Went there around 11 am with our group of 5, had to wait for more to go as a group of 11, had to share flashlights, info on tour was choppy, but the water was cool, no wetsuit needed, 500 peso was steep for what it was. staligtites were interesting. lots of people there. crowded, the water was cool.
Awesome!. We had a blast! It was beautiful, unexpected, mysterious....Don't forget to ask for "Rico", the best guide ever :-)Best $30/person spent so far!!
Beautiful Cenote Close to Playa!. This is a gorgeous spot! Great guides and a fantastic location. Two cenotes for exploring, surrounded by lushly landscaped grounds. A great experience.
Incredible Cenote. I couldn't believe we could find a cenote so close to Playa del Carmen. Great tour we just walked in and it was only $30 usd.

Virella Family. This was the best tour! A first for me and it was AWESOME! Abel was our guide, he was knowledgeable and extremely patient. He took the time to calm my mom of her anxiety and still provided us with a full tour.I would recommend this to everyone, these are not man made caves, this is all natural made over hundreds and thousands of years.Very educational, very interesting, I would definitely do the tour again..

Amazing Experience. We were a group of 6, and toured the cenote with anothercouple and a father with teen son. Everything was includedin the $30.00 fee: water shoes, wetsuit, life jacket, wristflashlight, and snorkel gear. The leader was fun, informative, experienced, patient, anda delight. We needed the life jackets because of the depthof the water; we were not rushed at any time to " get to point A or point B. The cenote was beautiful, with amazing stalactites and stalagmites. The water was cold, but pure, and refreshing.The entire experience was visually stunning, and greatexercise, too !!Have fun

Fantastic!!. Visited here a couple of days ago. Looks a bit run down from the outside, and almost a lack of communication when you get in as there was a lot of waiting around. But once you get in there it's amazing!! We had philipe as a guide. You get one guide per family. So it's a very intimate tour and experience. Saw a lot of bats, and fish as well as a resident turtle. Paid 400 pesos for the tour which, isn't that expensive.its about £15 ( around that price). For two hours and a personal tour it's fantastic value for money! The cenotes were beautiful, and philipe was great at telling us about the history of them, and the mayan history. Learnt a lot of information in such a short space of time. If you've got a few hours to kill, definitely go!! You won't regret it!

Well worth a visit!. Visited chaak tun remote today. Arrived around 9 by taxi but first entry was at 930. On arrival everything looks a bit "rustic". Just our thing! Our group of 4 were kitted out (torch, wetsuits, snorkel,) but you can use your own if you wish. Our personal guide, Philippe, was extremely knowledgeable, patient and humorous. He doesn't just explain about the cenotes, he gives lots of info about mexico and mayan history. Our tour lasted around 2 hours and cost 500 pesos each. Valentina offers a disc of around 70 photos at the end, lovely pic's but we didn't buy as we couldn't justify paying the price for something we'd put in a drawer when we got home (and we used our own waterproof camera ) I would highly recommend a visit, taxis from playa are cheap and this is a great family owned cenote. Be prepared for basic facilities and a wonderful experience away from the tourist areas, you won't regret it
Great trip!. What a great experience! Our guide was Felipe & he was very knowledgeable. It was a wonderful way to immerse yourself in local culture. Would definitely recommend!
Magical place. You have to see the Cenotes, they are just magical. There is an incredible energy coming from that amazing blue fresh water. Even if you dont dive, you can just swim there. It's a must

Be there early to be rewarded.. My friend and I arrived before opening hours, so we had to wait a little. However, since we were the only people there upon opening, us two got a very individual tour, which blowed our minds. RECOMMENDED!!

Great experience . A clear must go. When you arrive the reception and the changing rooms will make you wonder what is this place. But after meeting Ricardo - the guide - and enter the Cenote you will immediately will think what an amazing place this is. It is unique and magical - being inside all the caves and grottes you will be amazed. It's a no miss tour. Just do it!

Absolute a very nice Xcenote!. Everybody please, don't hesitate to go to this xcenote! It is so much cheaper than all those x'plor Xel, xenotes etc. You get a full suit with snorkel and everything. Very nice guide, more than enough time and a very nice experience. 100% worth it.

Fantastic tour - hit midday if possible. WOW this really exceeded my expectations. This was my 4th trip to Mexico over the years but first chance I got to see a cenote despite attempting nearly every time ... being as close as it is to the city, I wasn't expecting it to be great but merely an attempt to check something off my bucket list. TIP there are no taxis out at the cenote, so if you travel in from playa go your round trip option with the cabby for ~450 pesos! They will leave and come back to get you at the end of the tour, they discuss the time frame with the operators at cenote. This cenote is actually privately owned and has been passed down through a Mayan family through generations. Not sure of their hours, we just woke up had breakfast and headed out there ... arrived about 11am, and when we were finished with our tour at about 2/230 they had the gates locked and were turning people away so be aware of that. However, we think this was the perfect time to go! Hardly anyone there and a tour of ~8 spanish speakers set out before us. Luckily we needed an english speaking tour guide ... We basically got a private tour with Abel, and he was fantastic! He took us to some parts of the first cenote most people don't get to see, since it was just us 2 and we were both good swimmers. He was very knowledgeable about the area and was able to answer any of the random questions I had. He also laughed at all my boyfriend's corny jokes without appearing to hate us, also a plus. These guys work for tips so keep that in mind if he gets you into spots you normally wouldn't see with a bigger group. We tipped him 500 pesos but were almost feeling like that was not enough since the tour was so good.Another tip! GoPro footage came out about 50/50 out of what was shot, partly due to having to illuminate all your shots with flashlights etc. especially with the underwater ones. If you have an underwater camera w/ flash, this may be a better option although I am not sure if they are allowed. All in all this was a fantastic experience and I can't wait to go back to Mexico and explore yet another cenote a bit further out. If you are on a limited time frame as we were, this is basically right in playa and does not take long to get to, tour, and get back to hotel zone for drinking. We had a very full tour day the day before and didn't want to get trapped on a return tour bus journey of 3 hours like the previous day. This cenote does not disappoint, you will be happy you went!

Feels Private- Highly Impressive. All visits are guided and guides do a good job of describing the origins and use of cenotes as well as coordinating when groups enter each of two cenotes on the property. It sounds like they may open a third cenote in the near future that is currently only accessible through a rope line. *NOTE: Visit early and avoid cruise tour groups!

Interesting short tour and my skin felt wonderful after. We visited a couple of days ago and had Pablo as our guide, he is a very patient and helpful man. It is extremely hot there so if you choose to wear a wetsuit then only put it on up to the waist as he does a little speech about the Mayan's before you go into the cenote. To be honest you don't need a wetsuit, after the initial coldness of the water you get use to it after a few seconds and it's so refreshing on your skin. The facilities there are small and basic, but that's part of the charm. It's a beautiful place, especially when you see the sunlight seeping in through the open part of the cenote. My daughters aged 17, 16 and 12 loved looking at the cute bats and snorkelling. The only reason I didn't give this trip a 5 is because when we visited I had purposely left my camera in the locker, because I knew they took photos, which she did, but when the tour finished and Pablo took us back to the photo desk nobody was there and nobody could help??! They seemed understaffed, it's a shame as I was really looking forwards to seeing the photos. Our waiting taxi driver was getting impatient, as he had to be somewhere else, so we had to leave with only our memories. ☹️
Nothing impressive. you just go to a dark cave with the cold water, stay/swim there for about 20 min while they talk and go back

Amazing underground rocer. This was my second time in a cenote and it was truly amazing. The water is so clear and we had the best tour guides, Pablo and Daniel, to teach us about Mayan culture. We had traditional Mexican food in a cave and it was all amazing
Beautiful!!. Just beautiful!! The whole Xenotes tour is awesome, and each and every cenote we visited is just amazing. Highly recommend.

Interesting. A very interesting trip combined with a swim with turtles afterwards. We did enjoy it but if you have any problems with walking this is not the trip for you, there are steep steps down into the cave and then a very long walk to the turtle sight, be sure to use bio degradable suntan lotion as they are trying to preserve the environment and the turtles.

Must see.. We visited the cenotes- Wow! Its something you must see. Not too far away from where we stayed in Playacar. Shorter excursion but well worth the money. Guide was informative. Cannot wait to go back again. 11 year old wanted to stay!
Trip. Mago and her driver were fantastic. Very diplomatic guide, problem solver, highly professional and passionate about her work. Great job mago

Fun look inside a semi-open cenote. This is a bit different than open cenotes, so a different experience with snorkeling involved for the full experience. I would go with a group that is planning to go in the mornings because it can get quite full, but you can still have a great time regardless

A New Experience. The area is surprisingly close to town, but feels worlds away when you get to the caves. We have snorkelled many reefs and open ocean, but never in an enclosed space like this. The tour guides (Eli & Emilio) were informative and helpful, the stories shared of the Mayan culture were fascinating (Emilio is of Mayan descent, no less). That said, the area is truly primitive, there are many steps and stone stairs carved or placed into the hillsides. In some places you must stoop to walk. Some of the Elderly on our tour struggled. The overall experience was excellent, and we enjoyed the cool mystery and simple beauty of these natural formations.
Awesome. It was a great experience, our guide Felix was very nice and knowledgable. The underground rivers are totally beautiful and scary at the same time.I will do it again, totally recommend it!!!

Nice trip to a cenote. My husband and I came here with two teenage girls. My daughter was a little timid because of the bats but overall it's a unique experience. Our guide Abel was very friendly and explained a lot to us that we didn't know or had forgotten since school. Afterwards, we spent time tequila tasting with Manuel which was fun because he was quite the character. I would recommend bringing your own wet shoes because it's a little awkward putting on wet shoes that someone else had worn but it was still fine. We bring our own snorkeling gear as well. You don't wear flippers though so you can leave those at your hotel.

Well worth a visit. Today our family visited the Cenote Chaak Tun and we really enjoyed the 2 hours here We booked online however there was no option to at time of paying to book transfers We attempted to call the number on our email confirmation however did not get throughThe night before we received an email offering a transfer however we had already organised a return trip using a taxiThe taxi picked us up and picked us up with no issues The other issue we were unsure of was what time to go We just went first thing in the morning and no issues joining a tour in fact our family were the only ones on the guided tourThe guide Mario was friendly and enjoyed sharing his knowledge relating to all the different areas of the Cenote We really enjoyed his fun informative tour We did purchase the photos at the end as they were also great and it nice to give back a little sometimes This was a great tour to do with the family lots to see and the water was amazing No issues with temperature of the water it was just amazing the freshness and quality Thanks Mario for a great day

You can't miss it! . It was a great experience, the guides helped us a lot with the people who couldn't swim, I definitely recommend it! I would come back to visit this place, we have a lot of fun and we love the views and the experience.

Amazing Tour with Awesome Guide. This is an awesome tour for those that want an educational, as well as, entertaining day trip. If you are in Playa looking for a tour that won't eat up a whole day then dont miss Chaak Tun. Felipe, our guide, was unbelievable! You can just tell that he has a real passion for what he does. He made us all feel very welcome and comfortable. My teenage daughter was very nervous about the cave experience at first, but left saying, " that was one of the most memorable experiences of her life." I can't speak highly enough about this trip. You learn so much about the Mayan culture while being surrounded by jaw dropping beauty. Do yourself a favor while in Playa and take this trip! And please tell Felipe "Hi" for us. The kids are already talking about going back to visit him.

Underwater experience . This was an amazing outing. The water is cold at first so wear the wet suit. The guide, Ado, was funny and informative. The caves are beautiful. Everyone loved it in a group of 15. At the end, their was a guy selling tequila. We bought some because it was so good!

Amazing experience!! Best part of my trip!! I loved every minute!!. 1. Book through viator.com ($30 per person) and definitely add on the transportation option it gives you (for us it was $15 round trip per person from Sandos Caracol) - it's half the cost of a cab ride and the money goes to the cenotes! (hint: the local transportation phone number - if you're like me and leave nothing to chance - will be listed only on your voucher, not the email confirmation!)2. Wear a bathing suit but use their wet suit - it gets cold after a while!! They'll give you snorkel gear, a waterproof flashlight, water shoes, and a life vest - use them all (or bring your own). Bring towels - they don't provide them.3. They give you a locker to lock up all your stuff. It's small but fit a backpack, water bottles, towels, and shoes just fine.4. If you have a waterproof camera or case, bring it and make sure it's fully charged because you'll use it the whole time. It will be under water most of the time though so be careful to make sure it's really really waterproof! I brought a separate camera just for this excursion so I didn't risk ruining my phone even though it's in a life proof case.5. Felipe is the best. Seriously. He's a native to the area and not only does he know his stuff but he's fun, friendly, and patient too!6. Plan to spend the $30 they ask for the photo CD at the end. The photographers are really talented and they also give you a ton of professional pics from the cenotes, which are spectacular. Plus the money goes right back to the cenotes!7. Your resort will tell you they don't know what Chaak Tun is or try to sell you a tour to other cenotes or tell you that this place is really small and you should go someplace like Xcaret. Don't believe them - they're either lying, misinformed, or dumb. This place just isn't commercialized like places like Xcaret are and it doesn't advertise on slick brochures and the sides of vehicles. However, it is far superior in every way!! 8. There's no food or drinks there, so bring your own.9. The bathrooms are very...rustic. Very.10. This place is owned by a Mayan family who values the natural beauty here and respects the thousands of years it took nature to create it. Don't touch anything unless your guide tells you it's ok and be careful not to break any stalactites. It takes 10 years for them to grow 1 cm.11. Tip your guide. They deserve it!! :)12. The tour is at least 2 hours long. Plus time for changing and such. Leave a good window of time so you're not rushed - it'll be worth it, I promise!!
Beautiful. Atmosphere was amazing and the water was great. Came with a tour and was definitely worth going to check out. Make sure and bring biodegradable sun block.
What a place. Like a movie. so clear!. I was forced to go because the open water harbors were closed due to wind. AWESOME Place. I book via the Melia Hotel.

More than I expected. Did Chaak Tun because it was the closest to the ferry as we were coming from Cozumel.It was better than expected. Felipe was our tour guide and was very knowledgeable of the caves and Mayan culture. We had 5 in our group and we did not go thru a tour company so when we showed up and big group was just starting.As it turned out we had Felipe and us 5 so it was a very personalized tour.It took about 2 hours and was a cross of floating/swimming and walking in the caves.The water was chilly so we all opted for the wet suits. I would highly recommend. Why be freezing and not enjoy your time in the water.I would recommend Chaak Tun for anyone trying Cenotes for the first time

A Great Experience!. Went on a Carnival cruise in May and decided to try this out as an excursion. The place was breath-taking and the water was so clear. The water was pretty cold but you'll get used to it after a while. The only thing that I didn't like was how close the bats in these caves were to me. But thats nature, right? My tour guide was amazing, but I wish I can remember his name. Warning, if you are claustrophobic, there might be some part on the tour that will make you slightly uncomfortable. But it is only for a short period of time. Other than that, I would totally recommend it.

Amazing. Visited this cenote this morning with my husband and children aged 17,21 & 23. We really enjoyed the tour, it was very informative and Felix our tour guide did a fantastic job of making sure everyone enjoyed the tour.We highly recommend it, we have not seen any other cenotes but this one certainly satisfied us, it was amazing. My children thought it was a fantastic tour also.

Great trip for a few hours. We visited Cenote Chaak Tun after a friend recommended the spot. It took just 15 minutes from playa del carmen in a taxi and we arrived at 3pm. We were the only ones there so got our own private tour which lasted about 1hr 45. I thought the $30 per person was a bit steep but the tour was fantastic and Felipe was a great guide - very informative! Definitely take a wet suit as the water is very cold!We left our resort at 2.30 and was back by 5.30 for more pool action - glad we didn't choose a Cenote further awayIf your in playa del Carmen this is definitely worth a few hours of ur time

Great adventure. Wonderful, refreshing, beautiful, and informative adventure in caves below Playa. Guide Felix was fun and like a geologist with interesting history of the caves. Don't miss this and ask for Felix.

Cenote worth seeing!. Fifteen of us just returned from the Chaak Tun cenote.I am not a fan of snorkeling and would not call myself adventurous. However, this was two hours of GREAT fun!We had six adults and 9 11-19 year old kids. The price of admission was 450 pesos per adult, and since we had a large group they charged us 350 for the kids. It was worth every bit of it!Our guide, Abl was very patient and did a great job. You do not have to take anything. They supplied the wet suits, water shoes, life jackets and masks. We all wore the wet suits since the water was cold!Everything was very do-able! There was minor hiking, and light swimming, and while you could put your face in the water, you did not have to. I was worried about critters, but that was needless! The bats were lovely and the geology was awesome. Abl did a great job.We stopped at the Tequila drinking afterward and had fun there too!SALUD!

Unbelievable experience. I really didn't know what to expect from this cenote but it was close to the city center and reasonably priced. I'm so glad I went. It was one of the coolest experiences I've ever had. You see bats, go through small caves, and just something that you will always remember. The guides and crew were great. There is a photographer on staff so make sure you smile for them because they take good photos.

Must visit if you're in Playa del Carmen. If you’re spending any time in or around Playa Del Carmen, you owe it to yourself to visit a cenote. It’s the only area of the world that has them. There are many in the area, and I can’t claim to have visited many of them. However, I’ve visited enough to tell you that Cenote Chaak-Tun is absolutely first rate and can confirm that it is quite close to Playacar and many of the resorts in the area. My wife and I were staying at Sandos Playacar and it was about a 15 minute taxi ride away. It won’t be a particularly cheap experience ($20 USD each way for a cab and $30 each for the full experience), but my wife and I agreed that it was the most well spent money of our honeymoon.Our $30 got us wet suits, snorkels and masks, water shoes, underwater flash lights, and a 2 hour tour with only the two of us as guests. Our guide, Felipe, was a warm, friendly guy that had us laughing the entire way while pointing out the many things that make this cenote unique while giving us quite a bit of information about Mayan culture and how they viewed and used the cenotes. The guy is a pro… if you end up visiting, I highly recommend asking if he can take you on the tour. The cenote is quite large and we visited many chambers. We saw many stalactites and stalagmites, looked down underwater caves, saw fossils, spent a moment of silence in the dark, and had ourselves a little spa experience. It was truly MUCH more than just a visit to see a cenote. Additionally, they’ve kept the grounds as natural as they can. Electric lighting and pathways are minimal, giving this cenote a much more natural, undisturbed feel than many others in the area. And the best thing… we were literally the only people in the water. It was so serene. There were other, larger groups we ran across, but Felipe told us that if you come by yourself from the hotel, you get the best experience.Additionally, there will be a photographer that finds you at various points on your tour. We had a go-pro and they had absolutely no problem with us taking our own pictures, but the low lighting made most of our pictures terrible. Their pictures, however, were fantastic and not too expensive when compared to other photography we were quoted while in the Rivera Maya. We were asked for 500 pesos for all of the fantastic pictures, but we didn’t have enough left over after accounting for the cab ride home. We haven’t done it yet, but we plan on purchasing them online.If there is one thing I could improve however, it would be the bathrooms. While they were adequate, they were quite “rustic” and lacked a sufficient changing area for those who are shy. That, however, couldn’t ruin our experience. Again, of all the things we did in the Rivera Maya, this would have to be my first recommendation to anyone visiting.

Great intimate excursion for the family!. I have been to Xplore and it is ok but it felt too touristy. I found this place Tripadvisor. I wanted to see and explore a Cenote at a reasonable price. We had a rental car and drove there and found it very easily with Google maps. I believe they will pick you up though. We had a great time and learned so much!

Important to note you HAVE to pay for a tour if you visit this cenote. Chaak Tun is the closest cenote to Playa Del Carmen (15 minute drive) the taxi cost $150 to get there and when we arrived we were told it is not open for general exploring anymore so we had to pay 30USD per person for a tour. Luckily, the tour guide was great and we came at 2pm so were only sharing the place with 1 other couple. We also didn't plan on how to get home so our amazing tour guide, Eli, gave us a lift. He was the highlight of this experience!
beautiful. I will do this again. It was almost surreal. The water was beautiful and so clear. The guide did an amazing job also
Amazing experince. Great value, good option when the weather is not favourable for the beach. Intresting insight into the geology of the Riviera maya Mexico. Also the bats are cute,😀.

Different Cenote Tour, still Amazing!. Had an awesome time! We originally had in mind the cenotes you see online and on TV, though this being the closes one to our port of call in cozumel, we went for it. The tour is essentially going through the underground river and caves, even a swimming hole,the water will be cold, but once you get passed that it is amazing. Our tour guide Pancho was great and helpful, and the tour even included some Tequila tasting and some authentic Mexican food.

Private tour in a breathtaking place!. We ended up here at a recommendation of our taxi driver, and we were extremely pleased with it! The price is totally worth the experience and is more than fair compared to other cenotes. I would recommend coming alone rather than with a tour. This way the tour guides dedicate their attention to giving you an unforgettable experience. I appreciated that Felix (tour guide) had a sense of humor as well as an understanding of the geology of the cenote, which he shared with us. We even used some of the finite sand to exfoliate our skin at the end! We also were privileged to have Augustina, their photographer, take great pictures of us through out the tour, which we were able to purchase at the end. This was one of the highlights of our trip and I definitely recommend visiting Chaak Tun!

Tranquilo!. This was my second time visiting in the past couple years. This was much better thanks to Mario, our tour guide. He truly loves the cenotes and takes time to explain and answer questions. Safety is #1 in his book. It was a pleasurable experience without the big crowds. We took a taxi from our hotel in nearby PCD. The tour is approximately 2hrs. Upon my return, I would like to see other cenotes, but will visit this one yet again.
Very beautiful place. WOW ! Nature can be so beautiful. It was great to swim in such clean and fresh water. Very sensational feeling to become one with nature

Magical. This was my family's first snorkel trip. The kids have used a snorkel in a pool, but this is completely different. The staff were all friendly, informative, and helpful. I did not feel overwhelmed by the price of this tour for what we received. This was one of the best experiences our family had in Playa del Carmen. The were given all the equipment we needed (we had our own water shoes, and one snorkel and mask) which were life vests, 3 snorkels and masks. The staff made sure everything fit properly, and were told what to expect on our tour of the multiple cenotes. Our guide was Pancho. He was informative, and fun to listen to. He had historical stories for every area. He made sure we were safe, and comfortable along our entire tour. We were able to see bats, frogs, fish, and plenty of iguanas as well as the cave formations including stalagmites, and stalactites. Our guide was also able to explain some of the Maya history to us on our tour. This helped set our understanding for all the other historical data we would here while in the Yucatan. This was an excellent first experience snorkeling, and has opened our family up to diving in the future. Bring an underwater camera, or a cover for your phone for some awesome pics. Bring your own water shoes if you have them to avoid the bacteria from others, and don't bring to much you are not comfortable storing in a locker while your in the water.

Great place, lots of people. The Cenote itself is amazing but the number of people was disturbing. Do not take a tour to go to this place or Chichen Itzá, they all take you to the same places and waste your time and money.

OMG AMAZING - bucket list. we chose this Cenote because it was 3 hours. With the price of all -inclusive we didn't want to be away all day. Felipe was our guide and he was wonderful and patient. Very informative on the culture and cenotes The water is chilly "refreshing" and after 2 hours, I was cold, so if they offer a wet suit, take it, even in June. My only suggestion is to offer better flashlights because it would have been nice to see as good as Felipe did with his very strong light. You can touch these. This was a highlight and only 20 mins from our Puerto Aventuras hotel. Amazing!!!!

A true wonder of this earth. We saw this spectacular sight on TA and booked a trip.The walk along the path is stunning but it still didn't prepare us for the amazing underground water caves.The cold water is as clear as can be and you do need to take proper shoes to walk on the stone floor, flip-flops don't do.The caves are unreal and the most magical sight was the sun rays shining down to glow on the foliage that lives there like a creation from some other world....Truly a special place.

Great experience. There are many cenotes in the Yucatan. This one is only6 k from the beach area of Playa Del Carmen. It is not a big fancy commercial area. It's quiet, small and not crowed. They supply everything except a swim suit. Mask, snorkel, booties, life jacket, wet suit, flashlight and guide. We swam, floated and walked for nearly two hours. The area is underground and partly open in one area where you first go in. We had a small group, 6 people ranging in age from about 10 years to 66. Total cost for a couple about 1000 mx. The water is cold and you are in it for a long time so don't pass on the offered wet suit.

great!. awesome, relative unknown, cenote. great guide, all in price was 450 pesos (22 euro per person). a bit expensive but all worth it. takes you around 2 hours to see the cenote. Accesible by taxi and bike , ask the taxi driver to wait for you, cause there are no taxis available at the cenote.

Awesome experience with a great guide!. We've been spending the end of our Mexico trip in Playa Del Carmen and found Cenote Chaak Tun as a nearby Cenote to explore. First thing to note is that it is not well heard of, even by the taxi drivers, so many didn't even know where to go! We got a map up on our phone to show the driver where it was - and all taxis from central PDC are about 200 pesos to get here (a bit steep in my opinion, but oh well).The awesome positive here is that it is so quiet and not busy, we practically had the entire cenote to ourselves.We did arrive very late, at about 3.15pm. The last organised tour leaves at 3.30pm but instead of catching it up, we were given our own private tour with Francisco who was 10/10 - an excellent tour guide with lots of info and clearly loves his job too.But seriously, the cenote was practically empty and completely silent - so wow! Loved it.All the other reviews below will clarify the specifics. We had originally read some out-of-date information that you can just hire snorkel gear and explore the cenotes yourselves, but this is no longer possible. The tour is 450 pesos per person. We tipped the guide as well, but it is a shame they ask so directly here in Mexico (everywhere!)It is quite far our and hard to get a taxi. I would recommend hiring a scooter/car to get around to these locations anyway.

Brilliant experience. I've always wanted to experience a cenote, so to be able to do one that also has a history (beyond minerals), where Mayan artifacts have been found..it made the whole thing sweeter. Of course, a great guide is icing on the cake, and we had that in the form of Mario -he took his time, gave us so much information, and best of all allowed us to unfold the moment in our own individual ways.

Journey to the depths of Xibalba. Hello Trippies,First let me explain the curious title of my review. According to the Mayan view of the universe and our very informative guide, Felix, Xibalba (pronounced, chi-bal-ba) is the name of the "underworld". And yes, under the world did we go.My girlfriend and I have been traveling to Mexico annually for more than 5 years. though we have not experienced every excursion, we have seen a few and are intent on seeing more. On this vacation we wanted to visit a cenote. A cenote is basically a sinkhole that reveals a fresh water expanse with some truly cool features. There are open cenotes and closed or underground cenotes and many variations in between. Cenote Chaak-Tun (pronounced, shock-toon) is a combination of these extremes, but our experience was mostly underground.The Chaak-Tun cenote is very accessible from the Playa del Carmen area. We were staying at the Iberostar Tucan and the cab ride to Chaak-Tun took about 15 minutes. We arrived and paid our fee of $USD30 per person, not bad. We were instructed to change into wetsuits as the water can be a bit cold. I've seen pictures of men and women swimming in Chaak-Tun with nothing more than trunks and a bikini... I would suggest you choose the wetsuit... lol. There are lockers available for your belongings. If you go, I would suggest taking a minimum of gear with you: thick-bottomed water shoes, waterproof camera, bathing suit (you wear this under the wetsuit), towel, money, ID. While you don't need a towel on the trek, it's good to have it available when you return.After we donned our wet apparel, we met in a central location. We went in the late afternoon so there were no crowds and only one other couple with us from Brazil. We were met by our guide for the next hour, Felix. Felix is extremely knowledgeable about the Mayan culture and the physical phenomenon of cenotes. His familial roots run deep in the Mayan culture and he is a ready resource for any questions you may have.Felix gave us a brief introduction to the Chaak-Tun cenote network and how cenotes are all over the Yucatan Peninsula. That said, we proceeded to the depths. But not before we were given snorkels and goggles; personal flashlights and "required" life preservers. Helmets are available, if you'd like, but we didn't need them.We walked down a stone staircase bordered by rickety hand rails made from a collection of thick vines or long tree trunks. The mouth of the entrance looks just like a mouth with sharp jagged teeth, the teeth being the stalactites hanging from the roof of the cenote. The staircase dissolves into the cold fresh water at the bottom... did I say "cold"... yes, it was cold. Upon first dip, your breath is taken away, but you do get used to it... the wetsuit reeeeeally helps... lol!Not only is the water a bit cold, it's also quite deep, hence the life preservers, which work very well. Felix led us through cavernous regions of the cenote. Some parts were quite tight. If you are claustrophobic, this may be a challenge for you, but have no fear, Felix is there. He will comfort you and get you through.Felix regaled us with his knowledge of the cenote/cave and it's strange structures: stalactites, stalagtites, fossils, etc. In some areas, there were bats hanging from the ceiling. Occasionally one would lose itself from its perch and flitter around, but it was no harm to us. There were a few fish, but not many.At just about the time I was getting a bit chilled by the water and all the cenote/cave recesses began to look the same, our tour came to an end (about 45 - 60 minutes). We took group and individual pictures using the photographer that followed us throughout our liquid journey. The pictures are offered as a souvenir at the end of the trek for a small fee of $USD30. I bought the CD; it was worth it. It also includes other cenote pics and imagery.We had a great time at Cenote Chaak-Tun and Felix is a fantastic and knowledgeable guide. Please tip them well.If you are thinking of doing this excursion, just jump in, the water is fine!

Fun on a rainy day. Went here after our friends told us we had to see it! We took a taxi from playa del carmen (200pesos) and paid no less than 900!! Pesos for the tour! Included in the entrancefee you got a locker, wetsuits, shoes and snorklemask. I would say our guide was the best, he made the whole experience worth it (his name was Felipe) and he took really good care of us. You could tell he loved his job, my girlfriend was a bit scared of the whole setting in the centoes and he made sure she got here time to get in the water, he also explain everything really well! It is a experience you should do if you are bored or if you dont feel like going to the beach! We had fun, learned alot about the mayan people and the creations inside the cenotes. The only thing i want to complain about is the price, you have to take a taxi (ca 400 pesos rt) and 450 per person to get in, and they also expect that you tip the guide before you leave! They have a girl who takes photos, (not good ones) and you get to buy them for 500pesos! Pricey but alot of fun.

A Beautiful Day With The Family. . We arrived very early morning-as usual the weather was very hot, I had no idea what was going to happen, one of the most interesting experiences that I ever had and shared. The team gave us the tools that we needed to get in the water-even a flash light to see under the water. The water was crystal clear and very refreshing. It was amazing to watch the stones under the water and snorkel for hours. I would like to return and experience it again !

Very interesting . We had heard about this place after doing some research online. It was the closest to our hotel so we took a cab from the riu playacar which cost us about $20 each way. Felix was our guide and was very knowledgeable about everything. The tour was overall about 2 hours or so and he took us to 2 caves. It was lots of fun but if you're claustrophobic you might not enjoy this type of excursion as much there were a few tights areas we had to squeeze through and also lots of bats everywhere. But if your not afraid of bats and aren't claustrophobic I highly recommend this tour.

Clearest water ever!. Loved snorkeling in the Cenote caves. The water was cold but well worth snorkeling in the crystal clear water! The water has small fish and lots of plants/flowers in the water. The natural rock formation in the caves and under the water is fascinating! The next time we go we will scuba instead of snorkel as the deep clear waters are breathtaking! A must see.

Best Buy Excursion in Playa. This was one of the best things we did in Playa. Be sure to ask for Philippe. He has been doing cave dives in the area for 20 years and really knows his stuff. He gave so much great information on the cenote. The 2 hours went by so fast.The snorkeling was very cool and the water is clear. I would highly recommend the wet suite (from Wisconsin and without it would have froze). To see thousand year old caves with stalagmites/stalactites was mind blowing. Best $30/person I've spent in some time. There are some tight spaces in this tour.Cab ride round trip (from The Royal Playa del Carmen) was $30 but be sure to negotiate up front to avoid surprises. Booked through TripAdvisor and didn't have any issues at check in.Highly recommend this one if you are in Playa.

A fun place, caves half filled with cool water. Tripadvisor friends, We went here from PDC. its pretty complicated, so the only way to see it is with a guide. I think we payed like 30 or 33 a person. USD. Im sure not a deal, but we try to hit all the cenotes at lease once, and we have never seen this one. They give you all the stuff. The guild explained all the mayan stuff in english. the water was really cold, which was funny, because its so damn hot. They give like half of the people flashlights, and you get to a point where you turn them off. and You are like standing in chest deep water. No matter how big and tough you are, it makes you scared. Its PITCH black. A lady was taking pictures, so you know what that means. a pretty good day. They had lockers, so you have a safe to put your stuff. Go early in the morning and be first. Its very quiet and peaceful. This was something to see. I am 6 foot 4, and 270 pounds. There are some TIGHT areas. If you are claustrophobic, this might not be the tour for you. And if you do not want to be out numbered in bats like 10 to one. But they seemed to leave people alone. A good trip. dr. Darrell of MIchigan.

Fantastic adventure. Cenote Chaak Tun was my favorite part of our trip to Playa Del Carmen! The water was refreshing, and it was thrilling to experience the network of underground pools. Our guide was Felix...he was super knowledgeable and had a wonderful sense of humor. We had a wonderful time.

Great Tour . We just visited and enjoyed a great personal tour by Felix with a group of three friends. Felix showed us the amazingly beautiful cenotes and seemed to know everything about the underground network of caves. If you want to enjoy an adventures tour you should ask for Felix!

BEAUTIFUL. This experience was a beautiful one. I was a little scared because it was a little dark and when I looked with my goggles it was deep beneath but once you swim to the end where they talk to you, you can see how beautiful the scenery is.
Very unexpected pleasure . Loved this tour . Better then rio secreto .. The guide was great . Very knowledgable About the history of the caves . We will be back .

Magical experience!. This was our first cenote experience and I highly recommend it to anyone visiting the area. There are a couple negative points, so we'll get those out of the way first. It's a little pricey compared to others in the area, and this almost led us to go somewhere else. And the bathrooms could DEFINITELY use some improvements. But the staff and the natural setting make up for it. A huge cruise group arrived right after us, so they let them get ahead of us so that my husband and I got a private tour. Felipe was our guide and he was incredibly knowledgeable and spoke English very well. My husband is a much more competent swimmer than I, so Felipe took him to a separate section of the cavern and took some pictures while I hung out with the bats. The whole place was so serene, peaceful like you can't even imagine. I am a little claustrophobic and not a great swimmer, so if you have similar concerns, please don't let this stop you from checking out this amazing place. The battery on our camera died as soon as we got there, so we paid the extra $30 for the pictures taken by Valentina, which were great, just a little pricey. (The photos attached are not her professional photos, they are from my cellphone in a waterproof pouch).
Great experience and accommodating. We were able to pay a bit less for a shorter tour, and it worked out great! Felix was an informative, helpful, and funny tour guide. All around a great experience!
Birthday Celebrations. what a great experience this place was awesome. The underground caves the water was cool but was great to swim in

Great Experience. This was a great way to spend 2 hours in Playa Del Carmen. Our guide, Abel, was fantastic. The cenote was incredible. The water was very clean and the cave was neat to see. Well worth the trip.

amazing. wow the wonders of earth this was a turist attraction I booked for my kidaand my self and he had a blast I went inside but didn't swim in I wasn't prepared for it but the experience was exiting

Guided Cenote Experience. Chaak Tun is very close to Playa del Carmen and is the only guided cenote trip we went on. Because you go through very low-clearance areas and through tunnels, it really does need to be guided. THe cost was US$30 per person which is higher than other cenote entrance fees, but this includes the guide and equipment rental - wetsuit, snorkel, mask, and water shoes. They send a photographer with your group and offer to sell the photos to you for another US$30. This was probably the best cenote we went to along with Dos Ojos, which is close to Tulum.

A definite must do excursion!. So fun! Little scary at first, kind of chilly, but snorkel and you'll see deep crevices, little fish and cool,patterns in the stone. The mineral water was very cooling on the skin after a hot day in the sun. Everything is provided. Just follow direction and enjoy!

Exceeded Expectations. Way better than we had anticipated!We drove our rental car from Playa to the parking lot. 15 minutes, no problema.Upon arrival, you pay $30 entrance fee which includes mask, snorkel, wetsuit, booties, and a flashlight. Bring an underwater camera if you have one. A locker and key is provided to stash your stuff. I wouldn't bring any valuables - just be smart.Guides lead you through two caves. Unreal experience. Nice and cool - great reprieve from the hot sun.I booked through Viator and it was seamless. Walk ups are definitely a-ok, you just may need to wait.
This is not sea world. The majority of similar cenotes are only develop to a degree. If you want a well develop day trip try Xel-Ha.
Best excursion ever. Most unique excursion yet, dark and cold but breathtaking. Get an underwater camera, you'll need it.
Wow. We needed a break from the resort and opted for this. It was so amazing. Gorgeous doesn't describe it. Our guide Felix was terrific. Very personable and informative

BEAUTIFUL. This place is not a very well know Cenote, and it's just a couple of minutes outside of PLaya del Carmen, so you can just go in the morning. You can get a wetsuit and a snorkling gear. It's mainly swimming (not scuba diving), and really really amazing.
Great fun swimming in these caves. Lovely cool water to dip into after a coach trip. Quite slippery on the wood and watch your head on rocks.

Unforgettable excursion!. I LOVED this. I came upon this cenote via google while planning for our trip to Mexico. We wanted to do something that would only take a couple of hours and then still have the rest of the day to ourselves back at the resort. We were told about many other cenote excursions that cost over $100 a person and would take all day to do so we stuck with our plan and booked the trip via Viator - so glad we did. Our transportation was suppose to pick us up at 1030am and didnt arrive until 11:15 ish so that was a little bummer but it worked out great because when we got to the cenote, we ended up being the only ones there for the next tour so it was just me, my boyfriend and the tour guide, Abel who was fantastic. He was so funny, honest and informative. I learned a lot and really appreciated his enthusiasm about the caves and the history. We really had a great time and felt like we had the entire place to ourselves. He really made our experience special and we felt like we had plenty of time to explore and swim around. This being my first cenote experience, I suppose this cave would be considered on the smaller side but we felt we got what we wanted out of the experience and really couldn't have asked for more. Next time I'd like to see an open cenote - this was a closed one and a beautiful one at that. I am a person who has a phobia of small, tight spaces and so there were some points in the trip that I was a little freaked out but Abel was encouraging and Im very very happy I kept on. I enjoyed it all. You really can't beat the price of this place either. $30 bucks a person for the tour and $30 bucks (total) for transportation - awesome and really glad we stuck with that.

Great excursion. We booked the Underground River and 5th Avenue Shopping excursion through Carnival when we were on a cruise. When we arrived here, there were bathrooms with lockers and you could rent wet suits, snorkels/masks, and those shoes made of neoprene. They give you a hard hat to wear as you make your way into the cave and a life jacket. The water was cool, but you get used to it fairly quickly. The water is very deep at the point where you enter the water, but as you make your way through the cave, it gets shallower to the point where you can walk rather than swim. There are bats flying around you, so if you don't like bats, this may not be ideal. There are also small catfish swimming around.

Beautiful spot. We visited here as part of a cruise ship shore excursion. Our guide was very informative and the excursion lasted about 1.5 hours at this location. You do have to wear a life vest when in the water and a helmet when traversing one of the spots. I would not recommend this to anyone who has walking issues. The caves are very beautiful.

Pristine and Beautiful. This was one of the nicest cenotes we saw. Very beautiful, most interesting underwater formations, beautiful reflections and an elaborate system of tunnels.Our tour guide Abel was awesome. He really knew a lot about the Cenotes and catered the tour to what we were interested in. We were in a hurry, and he made sure we saw it all.A bus of cruise ship passengers was pulling up as we were leaving, which depressed me. Hope they preserve this beautiful cenote.

Small Cave but informative. We took a short bike ride from Banyantree Mayakoba to the cave, There was a guide there waiting to take people down in. He was very informative and guided us around the small area with his knowledge. It took about 15 minutes which was nice not to have spend a half a day tour the caverns. I would highly recommend this
Beautiful scenery and loco panchito!. We had a great visit in the cave an cenote. Panchito was our guide and put many smiles on our face with his jokes and his incredible enthusiasm.

Fabulous cenote tour. I visited Chaak Tun on recommendation from Adolfo at the Beach House Dive Hostel on Cozumel. This was my first ever visit to a cenote. Mine was the last tour of the day (3pm) so I was the only member of my group, a special and unexpected opportunity. Filipe was my tour guide, and he made the cenote come alive for me, a really magical tour. He is a former cave diver, very experienced with cenotes. He narrated for me the history of the cenotes, talking about geology, animal and plant life, and human history around the area. I have caving and snorkeling experience, so he was able to match the pace of the tour to my experience and abilities. The cenote was beautiful inside. We visited a number of different areas inside the cave system there, seeing lovely stalactite & stalagmite formations and a Mayan sweat lodge. The water was cool but I was warm enough in the wetsuit that was provided. It was fun to look underwater with the waterproof flashlight, also provided. The tour alternated between walking through water, swimming, and walking on land. I brought my own snorkel and mask, but these were included in the tour if needed. No flippers allowed. I did not come on an organized excursion, so I came by short taxi ride from Playa del Carmen. The cenote staff there was conscientious about finding me a taxi to take me back to town. Thank you, Felipe and the Chaak Tun staff!

Fun first time experience with Felix & Federica. I did tons of research on cenotes in this area (cenotes) and this seemed like the best fit for us. My boyfriend and I visited at around 10am a short cab ride away from Playa and bargained the ride down to 150 pesos taking in consideration he was also picking us up. Anyone got a cheaper ride than 150?? There is no cabs around there so arrange for your driver to wait or come back. We were the first ones and waited no longer than 15 minutes until people started arriving and got us ready for the tour. Our group was only 7 people and we were the only ones in the caves most of the time. They seem to space out their tours nicely. This is a huge reason why we decided to come here. To avoid crazy crowds or large tours. This was the first time visiting a cenote and I am happy we got to do it here with Felix as our guide. He gave us a lot of history and he was super funny so we had a blast! I am a little claustrophobic and the only moment I had to collect myself a bit is when I went under water for a couple of seconds to admire the underwater world. I am so glad I did. The awe and beauty made me forget all about my fears. I didn't once other than that felt nervous or uncomfortable. You don't go in any overly tight spaces it's actually very open and big. Federica, I truly hope I'm getting her name right! Was a doll. She followed us on the tour for pictures and they came out amazing!!! For about 400 pesos we took home about 60 pictures. We had a water camera and it was hard taking pics down there because it's dark so her pro pics are awesome! As many mentioned we were not pressured in to buying tequila and if you are not interested then just don’t buy lol! Many mentioned how they were “forced” to buy. So all and all the park is one of the most affordable, stunning and fun! Heres the breakdown:Cost for 1 person: $450 pesos Includes: Water mask, water lamp, wetsuit, water shoes, and tour guide!Cab ride: $150 pesos one way.Photo CD: around $400 with 60+ pictures. (if you want it)Tip not included.***NOTE: This is a tour only Cenote great for snorkelers no diving. Although you can take off your jacket in the second cent to dive in a bit. Other cenotes charge an entrance about $200, equipment separately, and usually 500 for a guide per person.

OFF OF ROYAL CARIBBEAN CRUISE. My wife and I (not spring chickens -- I 72 and she 64) took this excursion in Cozumel off our Royal Caribbean cruise in April, and absolutely had a fabulous time and thoroughly enjoyed it. Upon departing the ship, we took a ferry about 30-40 minutes to Playa Del Carman and were met on the dock there by the guide (Eli). Can't say enough about his care of all of the people he was guiding. Just a couple of things that might make your trip a little more enjoyable, 1) if you have foot trouble, take an extra pair of sneakers that you can use in the caves. 2) If you can take an underwater camera for some underwater shots. Also, make sure that you take your towels, and a bag to carry all of your belongings. They provide water shoes, lifevests, and helmets where necessary. Be prepared to duck down almost in half in some of the spots to negotiate the paths. We certainly would recommend this excursion, not for its excitement, but for the beauty and history. At the end there was a very nice Mayan lunch (taco, tamale, rice, beans and a drink), and finally a tequila "party" on our excursion. I don' think that you can plan on the "party" as I understand they sometimes are not there. By the way the tequila was "out of this world". Hope you enjoy as much as we did if you give it a go.

Best tour. Fab, fun, informative withArturo from AllTOURnative .. the best tour guide in the world. Absailing into a 20m u derground lake is awesome then real Mayan food and u believable Mayan temples and. Only 1 of 12 acres uncovered sofas. We hope the museums keep finding the exploration. This tour operator knows their stuff.

Beautiful Learning Experience!!!!!!!. I travel to PDC often and have been to many cenotes. In Feb 2016 I went to Chaak Tun for the first time with friends new to PDC. What a wonderful surprise and so close to PDC. We took a taxi from the 5th Ave bus station and asked him to return for us, which he did, they can also call a taxi for you from the cenote. Alex was our guide, and in all my travels, have never enjoyed a guide so much!! He was very knowledgeable about the cenote, formations, the gases found in cenotes, just everything and more!!!!!! Almost a science lesson!! He is also of Mayan descent and we learned so much about Mayan culture, beliefs, some folklore stories as well as some of the language!!! The day we went we were the only 3 in the tour. They have bathroom/changing facilities, however bring snacks as none were available that day. We are in our upper 50s and very active, i believe this tour would be accessible to healthier older adults. You spend most of your time in the water, either snorkeling or walking in the water with some swimming. Beautiful above and below the water line! I highly recommend this tour!!!!! Pamela... Ft Lauderdale, FL

Breathetatking!. A wonderful experience in an under water world! The guide was amazing, great for families even with young children. Definitely with it! This is our 2nd cenote tour and it was still worth every penny!

Swimming With Turtles (Included Cenote Visits). We did the swimming with the turtles exercison with Nexus and it included swimming in the cenotes (x3). Was SO great! left around 8am and got back around 2:30ish. Snorkeled with turtles - amazing - and went to 3 cenotes afterwards. Had snack (small lunch) before heading back to resort. We all LOVED it and would do it again. bring a snack because the wait for lunch can be a bit long.

Must see. Amazing experience. Not far from downtown Playa Del Carmen (approx. 10 min drive). They provide everything you need (wetsuits - I found the water chilly, life jackets, lockers, and snorkelling gear - although you can bring your own if you like). Our guide Philipe was great. Go earlier in the morning and you'll most likely have a small group (beat any cruise tours). We were very pleased with our visit and it was one of the highlights of our trip.

We had a blast!!!. Pancho was our guide and he was amazing and full of knowledge!! His english was great and he was super patient with me.. I have anxiety issues and he was not rushing or rude! We loved it!!
Amazing experiece!. Beautiful environment with professional guide. Several different caves to didcover. Convenient distance from Playa del Carmen.

Enchanting. We really enjoyed this location. Abel made the experience fun, interesting, and safe. We turned the flashlights off for a while and listened to the stillness. We exfoliated in the muddy sand. The dirt road is now paved. We got there when it opened at 9:00, and took the first tour at 9:30. We had only 6 in our tour.

Fun couple hours. Just so you know it is located out in the jungle not in playa del Carmen about a 5 mile drive there from 5th ave address on trip advisor is wrong! Had a fun day though wish we had more time in the water though only about 30 mins in the water was kind of rushed

Great Time!. Francisco (Poncho) was a great tour guide! Highly recommend this tour! They accept credit cards if you want to purchase pictures at the end. Remember to bring enough cash to tip the guide if he deserves it. They also have tequila if you want to make a purchase or sample.
