Royal Carribbean excursion through Explora-Tours. Our tour of Cenote Chaak Tun was a truly memorable experience! Roberto, our tour guide was Very, very informative, friendly and an overall GREAT tour guide!! He took us step-by-step explaining everything and all the details of the culture and history of the area!! The swim through the caves was without a doubt beautiful, exhilarating and refreshing and all the while, Roberto was right there ensuring our Saftey and enjoyment... This is a MUST-DO adventure for anyone visiting the area!!!
great value. Highlight of our stay in Playa. Cheap taxi ride. Must have a guide to see 5 caves so people will not touch stilagtites.

Thrilling experience. We were a group of 3 adults and 3 kids ages 7-12 on a Carnival cruise. We came over from Cozumel on an organized tour and this was one of two stops. I'll get the one bad thing out of the way- at the end is a 25 minute "tequila tasting" which is nothing more than a sales pitch for you to buy their tequila. If you aren't interested in tequila or have kids you find yourself standing there with nothing to do and bored to tears. Our guide was great and the swimming was thrilling. The water really isn't too bad as we expected it to be colder. The formations were neat and the water was so clear. Like anything expect large groups of people which then cause you to be constantly ushered through things quicker than you'd like, but nevertheless it was still a great experience. Locker use was included and take your own water proof camera! We had a lunch included that was served in one of the caves, food was okay.

Prof Lescota. Wonderful and educational.Not for those who are claustrophobic or afraid of the dark. You are given a water proof flashlight for your use. You must be able to walk and squeeze thru narrow openings and be able tho navigate rough ground. Awesome experience. Under ground lunch provided. You need a towel. You are provideda life jacket. Fantastic informative guide. We were with 18 other people in the group. Great value for the money.We even were treated to a "true Mexican tequila" tasting. No lime or salt for this awesome nectar of the Gods. Yes, we bought 2 bottles. Credit cards accepted.There are locks and locker rooms provided so you can change into dry clothes.This tour exceeded our expectations.

Great tour of underground Cenote. Took a taxi from Playa which was 300 pesos one way (might have been conned here?).The site was really nice and it was a large site of connected underground cenotes. Our tour guide Mario was friendly and funny and gave a nice two hour tour in the caves.Tour price was 450 pesos p.p. Including full snorkel gear, life vest, wet suit (if wanted), shoes and locker. The only thing you would need coming here is a towel and bathing clothes.It was a great half-day excursion from Playa del Carmen.

Worth The Money. Cenote Chaak Tun is a bit pricey comparing, but a guided tour is included with snorkeling gear, wetsuits. shoes and flashlights (I have been to Cenote Ikil and only life savers where provided). You get to go two different parts of the same Cenote, our guide Francisco-Paco-Pancho was very knowledgeable (definitely I like that cause I always come up with the weirdest question or observations).There are bats and parts of the tour are dark and a bit small. I believe most people should be okay with this cause I get a bit claustrophobic and I was okay.I brought my water proof camera, and I wasn't afraid to lose it. If you lose something, the guide should be able to retrieve it, but he won't guarantee it. Somebody lost the snorkel and Francisco was able to get it.Worth Checking the Cenote out if you are in Playa. It is a taxi ride away. Depending where you are and if you are good at bargaining you can pay 120-200 pesos. The entrance to the Cenote is $30

Warning to Explorers, Corporate Takeover. Explora Tours recently leased the property so it is no longer open to self-guided visitors. A 2-hour guided tour is required, and runs a shocking $30 USD per person, around $400 Pesos. While this cenote is still awe-inspiring from a cave perspective, it is disappointing that this 'off-the-beaten' cenote has been taken over by corporate business. I understand the preservation side, but there are other ways to welcome guests without a tour. You cannot dive due to the required lifejacket.

AWESOME cenote visit just a few minutes from PDC. We were looking for an underground cenote for our 4 kids (age 5-10) a quick trip from Playa del Carmen. We cabbed there, got all the gear required included in the entrance fee (we paid $30 each as we had a group of 6) and were treated as a private group on our own tour. Our guide Filipe was amazing. Lots of great knowledge imparted as we explored the 'caves' All the kids had a blast. The whole thing, including the cab to and from Playa, took just 3 hours. Perfect afternoon outting.

One of the best cenotes tours. We are on a personal mission to visit as many cenotes in the Riviera Maya as we can manage in the winter months that we live here. This cenote rates right up there near the top. Affordable with an extremely reasonable rate for locals, unique in that we never saw a Mayan sauna before, and absolutely beautiful. So much to see and so much to learn from the informative and attentive guides. Thanks Pancho. We loved this place and plan to bring our visitors there in the future.

Great time away from the crowds. Visited this cenote on TripAdvisor recommendation. Little off the beaten path but that's what made it special. Friendly guides, small groups, more pristine environment. Took a cab from puerto morales and did admission for myself and daughter. Cost less than half of tours big companies sell. Cab driver waited for us while we visited site. Just amazing.

Cool. We went there on an tour recommended by our hotel's front desk guy. We expected more of a wow factor but it is def pretty cool, you are practically in a cave with this huge sink hole filled with "purifying" water. There are fish in the watter (still don't know how) and you can take awesome pictures.

What an amazing pool to take a swim !. We spent one day at this place and we loved it. We had a walk in the garden, took a swim in the Cenote (my husband dared to do some swan dives ...) and had lunch in the restaurant .

A fascinating cenote near Playa. We went one afternoon on the recommendation of our concierge, as we didn't want to go really really far away. We got lost a bit getting there but ultimately found it. Not glitzy in appearance, it is led by a tour guide, you are furnished with (optional but useful) wet suit, the right wet/rock shoes, snorkel gear, obligatory life vests, and waterproof flashlight that ties to your wrist. The first part of the tour, which in our case had 12 people together (but it can be smaller, depending on who shows up when you do), took us to a fairly claustrophobic and initially intimidating cave pool, which however opened up after the opening passageway. Some people climbed down into the water, others splashed in. It's dark down there, but light enough to not be terrifying. We flopped around a bit, some swam further off than others. Many stalagmites and stalagtites and odd limestone formations. The second part led us to another cave, longer, the first part by foot and the second part, spectacular, with a hole in the ceiling where tree roots descended to the water, incense had been lit by the guide, in traditional Mayan form, he had us all recite a Mayan prayer to allow us in to the cavern. We stayed in the main pool area while the guide swam the crowd into the darker recesses, and we're glad we did, as the bats and birds, hearing no people, started their normal activities, flitting around from vine to vine and in the roof of the cavern. It was breathtaking and beautiful, a cacophony of natural sounds, calls, and just us paddling softly in the dark blue water. Memorable. Two hours, not cheap, but worth it.

Stunning!!. This is a MUST see. I would feel cheated if I didn't do this.It is like going into another world and time. The history behind the cenote is amazing and to think, this is their only source of fresh drinking water.
Great time!. Arrived early (10am), among the first ones there. Great tour in a small group of 5. Loved it! Thanks Francisco (our guide). $30 adults, $20 for my 12yo
Swimming in a cenote is a must!. Loved it! So natural and beautiful. Very nice staff also. Make sure you bring water shoes. You can also have authentic food right outside the cave.

Really fun short excursion. We stopped at this cenote on our way back from another excursion and i have to admit that at first it seemed a little daunting jumping off the ledge into the cenote because i am not a strong swimmer and did not know how deep this was but I am so glad i decided to jump in anyway. The water was super pleasant and it was really cool swimming in the cenote.There must have several other tours there at the same time because there were quite a few people in at the same time but it never felt too crowded.

Fun!. This place was awesome! We only had 6 in our tour group (After small talk was happy to find out they were all similar travelers to ourselves) They provide wetsuits, shoes, goggles and a locker. It was very affordable too. Our tour guide (Who called our tour Pacho's Tour) was really funny and informative. The caves were really cool and we're really glad we went.
Beautiful naturel spot. Lay back and enjoy a cooling day in those beautiful under ground naturel creek and spring water very clear and clean water .

Place to ourselves!. We were travelling with a 3 month old baby & grandparents and weren't sure if visiting a cenote would be possible. However, there were plenty of options here to suit us all. Husband & I went for the self guided option as we were short of time & needed to be able to attend to baby if required - 300 pesos for snorkel & torch, and it allowed swimming in first cenote and we were able to walk and look at second. Grandparents paid 200 pesos to look at both cenote and watch baby. They were able to sit near the waters edge so we could easily get to baby if need be. There are of course some steep rocky access steps but we all managed fine. We had the first cenote to ourselves which was really cool. Quite dark and enclosed so not for those who feel claustrophobic. Great being able to look at the second cenote even though we couldn't swim in it alone. There were plenty people here on the guided tour, think that was 500 pesos for 2 hours.We later visited Dos Ojos which may be a bigger and more interesting cenote but is much busier. I suppose the cool thing about the cenotes is how different they all are. The highlight for us at Chaak Tun was having it to ourselves. Worth a visit.
Nice place but overpriced. Its a cool cenote but its way overpriced so even the locals cant get in . And there safety is not too good. Two people drowned there recentely.

Best Cenote right outsidePlaya Del Carmen. This place is well worth the visit. We visited this place early and our group consisted of three and our guide Abel. First off Able did a fantastic job. He was sure to make everything safe for his guests and gives everyone time to get acclimated to environment before pushing ahead. There are several different cenotes that you will visit in this park. They have everything you need right there and in the two hours you will see everything and fell like you got a great value for your money. Highly recommend this park.

Cavern adventure. Visited Chaak Tun last week with Felipe as our guide. What a great experience! Felipe was terrific, the price can't be beat. Not as touristy as the other cenotes and the price $30 plus a tip for your guide was worth every peso!I would think that big and tall people would find it somewhat difficult to maneuver in some of the lower, tighter areas, other than that it's a really interesting place to see and Felipe made it even nicer!

Fun but shorts I tripped snorkeling in subterranean cavern. Speak with others before deciding which cenote to visit. After paying $30 per person with snorkel included, swim with the guide through Caves. Very interesting. Bats flying around. A lot of stalactites but after 45 minutes became repetitious and there was nothing else to do at this site. Check with others to see what cenotes they visited and what they had to offer.
Snorkeling. First time snorkeling for me, and I felt like a pro at the end of the day. Thanks to our tour guide.

An amazing and unique experience. We visited this cenote in Feb 2016 and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Our guide Felipe was personable, knowledgeable and experienced. We were given all the necessary gear and safety equipment to snorkel through the caves. Wet suits are available if you wish, although most of us went in our bathing suits. The formations of stalactites and underwater stalagmites were spectacular. There are lots of bats and spiders (although safely tucked into niches!). If you have claustrophobia this is not the place for you as it is quite dark and confined in places, but I felt very safe and secure throughout the tour. Overall this was one of the highlights of the vacation for me. I would say it is not to be missed if you are staying in Playa del Carmen.

Beautiful cenote and well organized tour. Great place to visit very close to Playa del Carmen. Everything is very well organized. We didn't pre-booked the tour, but didn't have to wait at all after arriving to Chaak Tun since they make the tours for small groups. You will also get all the necessary equipment including a wet suit, since water is rather cool. But cenotes look absolutely great and the water is crystal clear. Although I have seen some caves with similar formations, swimming in Chaak Tun was amazing experience. Our tour guide Felipe was the best possible guide - patient, gave a lot of interesting information, had very good sense of humor and made everybody feel comfortable.
Chaak Tun Cenote Tour. So glad we took this tour which included swimming with sea turtles and ATVing through the jungle. Alejandro Martinez provided a memorable visit!

Chaak Tun Cenote Tour. If you are in the Cancun, Playa del Carmen area you must make time to visit a cenote. This tour was amazing and a short cab ride from Playa. Our tour guide was excellent. We swam/snorkeled in two connecting cenotes and learned so much about these underground beauties! The water is a bit chilly, but crystal clear. Amazing!!
need to be done once in one's life. super experience do to it once - would not do it more... but still great experience.well organized and pretty clean - had a drink afterwards and price was normal

Great Adventure!. I read about this place on Trip Advisor and was eager to try it ! We stayed in Playa del Carmen resort so it was a short taxi ride away!I was with my family so was a total of 6 of us. We were a little hesitant when we first arrived but when we met our guide Fellipe, we felt so much more at ease.He was an awesome guide and did a great job!The cenotes were beautiful and the snorkeling was fun! It was so nice that all of the equipment was provided.Fellipe was very patient with the many questions regarding bats and spiders from my daughters!I definately reccommend this adventure if you are anywhere in the area.

Fun, affordable. This place is a bit off the beaten track but roads are good if you're driving a rental car. Definitely more rustic than the popular commercial spots but much cheaper as well! $30 US was cost for 2 caverns with a guide. Shortie wet suit, mask and water shoes is included in the price. A photographer is on hand that will take your photos for sale after tour.

Perfect, but not for kids. That is one really cool snorkelling experience. You snorkle in two caves, using shorty, mask and a flash light. It gets dark and narrow, so if you are clastrofobic, this is not for you :) Also not for kids under certain age (I would say under 10). Watch for tequily salesman, it is a tourist trap (read: extra expensive). All in all: a great cenote, well worth visiting.

Beautiful and not crowded cenote!. We took a taxi from Playa del Carmen, ride was about 15 minutes. We make a deal with taxidriver that he come pick us up after 1,5 hours. Our guide was Felix and he was great! We had much knowledge about cenotes and had amazing tour in two different cenotes. We didn't take wetsuites and we were fine without. :) There were only 6 of us with guide and just a few other people so it was peacefull. This was definitely worth of every pesos!

Cenote Queen Dubs Thee Fantastic!. I did a write up on cenotes a few years back and wish I had visited Cenote Chaac Tun prior to that write up - it is amazing!! Of the 15+ cenotes we have visited I would put it in the top three for beauty and number one for service and value. We arrived via taxi at 2:30pm and received our gear - light, snorkel, and mask. We declined wet suits and were glad we did as the cenote was cool but refreshing for us. The only thing missing was a towel, wish we would have brought one as we were having dinner in Playa del Carmen afterwards. The guide started off in a mixed wet/dry cave area with a photographer of which I sadly declined since I figured we'd get some stock photos afterwards. He explained how cenotes came about, some of the history of the one we were visiting, and how they continue to work. He was very information and fluent in both English and Spanish. Next we visited a beautiful cave area that had both a large open cavern and smaller sections with just enough room to fit between the stalactites and stalagmites. What was especially nice is there was a rope along the larger sections so you could choose to hang on to that and still see most of the cave and water sections without having to swim or go through too many tight spots. We of course choose to go through some of the smaller sections as the guide offered us a choice for how much to do, and said he did so for every group. The water was crystal clear with light blue shining across the deep caverns and underwater stalagmites. It is like floating through another world since the water is brackish (fresh and salt water mix) and filled with minerals. Underneath we could tell the caves went on for quite a ways. There were some small zebra fish, catfish, and turtles in the cenote as well. One section we swam through required walking through a short dry cave section to get back to the beginning and they had it lit up in red and blue - nice touch!!The second cenote was a vast cavern with just a few offshoots of tunnels. We were given free time to check out all the formations, float around and stare at the bats on the ceiling, or just relax in the huge natural pool. The guides and staff were so great and at only $30 entrance fee with equipment per person, quite a steal compared to other deals in the area. Total visit time is about 2 - 2 1/4 hours depending on how long it takes to get geared up and ready to go.

Great experience with Able. After reading reviews my wife and I decided to get off the all inclusive resort and see this cenotes. This was our first experience with a cenotes and it was a little scary at first until you realize there is a 7 year old right next to you. The cab ride from DT Playa Del Carmen was a 150 pesos w a little negotiation. The ride was a little scary as you go through some seedy areas, but worth it. Able was an excellent guide and made you feel comfortable and the paparazzi Frederica was a little cutie. Highly recommend this experience.

Cenotes tour. We snorkeled in the under ground caves. We couldn't talk my 7 year old into the tour, but he did get in the water. My 14 year old nephew thought is was very cool! I would definitely recommend it.

Neat Experience - Great Guide. My wife originally didn't feel like doing this tour but I eventually talked her into it. She was so glad I did. Felix was our guide and he had a great personality and seemed to love his job. The water was cool, but with a wet suit on it felt fine. They take credit cards and make sure you have some cash to tip the guide at the end. To get there head out Avenue Juarez North past the large school on the right and past where the road converts from 4 lanes to 2. It's probably 1/2 mile after that on the right. I would call before you head that way because when we went early on a Sunday another group came in behind us and the cenote apparently had closed and they were unable to do the tour and were out the cab fare.
excellent dive great break form ocean dives. excellent site great different dive to ocean dive well worth the day out. Crystal clear water although a lot cooler than the ocean 5mm + suit needed

Shopping Should Be Optional. We recently did the Underground River on a cruise to Cozumel. We booked it through the cruise because of the length of the trip and we didn't want to get left behind, which was a really good thing we did because we were about 45 minutes late getting back to Cozumel. You do have to take a ferry from the island over to the mainland but we were easily guided to the ferry once we left the ship. Unfortunately, we were experiencing some bad weather the day of the trip (a few cruise ships decided not to dock that day). We soon sort of regretted that our captain got us docked- we had a very bumpy and crazy ferry ride. They handed out some sea sickness pills and barf bags as we boarded. None of us had ever experienced sea sickness before but the 3 of us barely made it without getting completely sick. Several passengers did throw up on the trip.The tour itself was great. Our guides were great. Very pleasant and knowledgeable. We took a short bumpy van ride over to the caves. They provided water shoes, masks, and snorkels. You don't need the mask and snorkel. The water is crystal clear and no need to go underwater. We were allowed to keep our cameras with us and we got some really great shots. They also took two photos for us and were selling them for $20 I think. During the tour, we did some of it with life jackets on but were allowed to take them off later in the tour. We actually found it much easier to move around though with the life jackets on. There weren't really any tight spaces to go through so no worries there. The water is cool but was actually very refreshing. After the swim in the cave, they brought us over to a real Mexican lunch in one of the other caverns. It was very good. After lunch they did a short Tequila tasting of some organic tequila. It was good, but expensive. After all of this we were taken back in to Playa Del Carmen to shop for a couple hours. We are not shoppers though and didn't enjoy this part of the trip. The merchants are pushy, friendly, but pushy. I think a good improvement for the tour would be to make the shopping optional. We had a 14 year old with us that just complained about wanting to get back to the ship.

Great afternoon. Well worth it. Bucket list. We wanted a simple non touristy cenote experience and this was perfect. We took a taxi from Calle Benito Juarez and 30th av for 150pesos, which takes under 20 minutes. Entrance fee for two adults was 945 pesos. Includes wet suit, water shoes, snorkel and mask and guided tour. (Does not include tip) time is approximately 2 hours. Both the ticket man and our guide spoke excellent English. We would definitely recommend this experience
Great visit!. Fantastic experience. It is not very touristy. Beautiful cenotes. Francisco is an excellent tour guide. Very safe and enjoyable experience.

A not overly touristy cenote in Playa. The cenote is worth it if you're in Playa and looking for a less-touristy attraction. The drive there is not well signed and goes through a less-rich part of town, but don't let that scare you off because the site is secure. The staff spoke good English, there were lockers, showers, and a changing area. The snorkeling tour took about 2hrs total. It was a bit more old-school that the popular, over touristy centotes closer to Tulum. The water is cold (about 20 degrees C) so definitely take a wet-suit when they offer it. A very good experience, I hope this helps you visit.

Really Outstanding. Great way to see a xenote complex. As recommended in many reviews, we arrived at 1.30pm. There was one other couple. We spent the whole afternoon there - they closed when we left. Just a great experience. My wife was not sure from the point of view of snorkeling but she had a blast (we both did). We bought the photo package - not so cheap but worth it because we did not have a waterproof camera. There was no tequila tasting when we were there but that was no problem. Overall, not to be missed.
Amazing experience. We did the cenote tour in December of 2015 -- it's remarkable. beautiful water, great snorkeling, great atv driving. Highly recommended!

Awesome. Slightly claustrophobic, I was a bit apprehensive about this one, but it turned out great. The water is amazingly clear, scary at times, both in the halocline and in the darkness, but such a great experience. Do it! Basic amenities in the car park, changing rooms, cold water showers, a kiosk for that after dive-beer and a toilet without toilet paper. Bring your own. And also, you will be photographed and filmed during your dive, but no stress if you don't buy anything later :-)

Rode our bikes from 5th Avenue - crazy adventure. Our rep at the bike rental place suggested this when we asked him where can we could ride our bikes to. While I'm glad we did, it was a long crazy ride. Took us at least an hour to bike, once you passed over Hwy. 307, there a bike path for a while, then no traffic. So, this cenote is very rustic. We just went to the little cenote inside a small cave and swam [only $11 admission]. For another $10 or $ 11 you can get a guide and swim/snorkel into this large dark scary cave. We just weren't prepared on this day to do this. I really liked this place.

Great cave cenote. This cenote provides a guide, full wetsuit and snorkle gear for visitors. The tour is not optional, you must swim with a guide. We choose to visit Chaak Tun on a rainy day, which was a great way to enjoy a day we might have otherwise spent inside. The caves were beautiful and our guide, Abel, was focused on making sure everyone was safe and having a good time. We were matched up with two couples and a family with young children for our tour and it seemed that all ages enjoyed the experience equally. The cost per person when we visited was 450 pesos, which included the guide, wet suit, snorkle, mask and water shoes. We arrived by taxi and arranged for the driver to pick us up after the tour (about two hours). We paid 200 peso each way for the taxi from Playa del Carmen (not sure if that was a good price or not).

Exceeded expectations!. While Cenote Chaak Tun may not be as spectacular as some of the cenotes closer to Tulum, it was impressive and a great value. The water was crystal clear, the formations were incredible, and the guide, Mario, was fun, informative, and he took excellent care of our group (our family of 5 and one other husband and son pair). For $30 per adult, and less per kid, we had a 2 hour tour complete with all the necessary gear, and with no other parties present. If you are staying in Playa del Carmen, this is an absolutely worthwhile experience.
Beautiful clear pools!. This was a really nice experience! We went snorkelling here and I was a little afraid of the caves at first, but soon got over it, as it wasn't too closed in.

Once in A Lifetime adventure.. This was the most incredible thing I have ever done. We were swimming in a water hole with mineral water. The view was amazing and these Cenotes goes under ground all the way out to the gulf. They had underwater lights and a guide to keep you from going were you should not. The after effect was very refreshing.

Great afternoon cave swimming. Very close to Playa del Carmen is the Cenote Chaak Tun. We got a cab from the plaza for 200 pesos and joined the last group of the day. It was 450 pesos per person for a guide, wetsuit, torch and entrance. We saw bats, catfish (only little ones) and we swam around the caves enjoying crystal clear water and plenty of pretty rock formations. The depths of the caves stretched off in some areas and I could undertand the appeal of cenote diving. The taxi driver waited for us and we paid him the same to get back. It is possible to get a collectivo most of the way if you wanted to save more money.

Rustic and spectacular. No zip lines, restaurants or time share presentations just a well run cenote adventure run by a group of people that truly care for the cenote. Our guide Felix was excellent with a thorough knowledge and respect for the cenote. The cenote as others have noted is spectacular the two hour tour takes you through the cenote for 450 pesos plus well deserved tip for the guide is well worth the expense.(200 peso cab ride each way). See it before it becomes commercialized.

Great Caves and Scuba Experience!. This was a great choice. Not crowded and the tour guide was awesome. The caves were magical. There's so much growth in the caves and it really was a wonder to see. The water was clean and you see the pretty little fish in the water. This was a real cenote. The fish were put in there, they are from those waters. You get your all your scuba gear there and your cab driver waits for you in the lot. loved this place!

A cenote gem!. We wanted a cenote that felt natural and not like Disneyland. We saw the reviews and decided to come. It was all the reviewers said and more. Beautiful, mysterious, a bit scary at times ( in a fun good way) and very cool. We took our two teens and they loved the adventure and the beauty. Our guide Abl also was knowledgable and made us feel like we were going to parts unknown. ( of course we weren't but it felt like it). Sunday was an awesome day to go as it was not busy. Overall a wonderful choice so glad we came here.

Great Cenote experience. This 2 hours trip was a great adventure for us and for our kids. Beatiful caves with quit warm water gave us unforgettable moments in the cave lakes. Felix our great guide gave us really detailed information about the history of the cenotes, he was also very supportive to our kids :). The only thing we are missing are pictures taken by two nice photographers. They were to be sent to our e-mail but unfortunately were not :(. Can someone please give us any contact to them via trip advisor? Thank you!regards,Klaudia, Tomek, Karolina and Michal

Amazing!. This was my 1st time swimming in a true cenote so I don't have anything to compare it to but my experience was amazing! I loved that for a price of $450 pesos you received snorkeling gear, wetsuit, locker and a personal guide. Mario was our guide and he did a great job telling us about the history of the cenote and other ancient Mayan rituals. Chaak tun contains numerous stalactites & stalagmites in a mineral rich cave that transports you to a serene place.

Beautiful and a gorgeous experience. The place consists of about a 2 hr tour. Our guide answered our questions and all together it was a new and fun experience. We did it with our children (three and a five year old) and I felt safe and excited. Even my 79 year old father-in-law explored the cenote for the first time with extra help from the guide.

a unique and wonderfully exciting activity for anyone interested. wow, what a great adventure. I went with a good friend but we saw couples and even one very young child enjoying it. You have to be comfortable going into cold water in complete darkness for a few minutes but when you get to the point of light its really incredible. Be prepared to swim in small caves with plenty of friendly bats ( boy I am making this sound really awful but its not) listen to the wonderful guides who explain the ecology of how these wonderful places came to be, have an authentic Mexican lunch served in the cave, and end with an expert Tequila tasting who explains the process of making organic Tequila which is the smoothest you'll ever taste. Just a one of a kind exciting experience start to finish

Georgeous caverns, clear waters, and friendly staff. My friend and I stopped by Chaak Tun on the way to the airport in the hopes that we'd see some nice caves and get to take a dip in the water in a short amount of time. I didn't think we'd be able to see so much in our time there, but our guide Abel showed us the cave system and was extremely kind to us in our short visit! It's a must see!

a must do. I did a tour of cenote coba and Mayan village It was great we swam in a under ground cenote 1st and saw a huge cave going up that was full of bats then back to a above ground cenote with 2 pools to swim in also deep enough to jump off a cliff in to 7 meters of water (I jumped 3 times lol was a rush) the info you get about how cenotes were formed and they are protected by the Mayans it had a bar as well I spent 2 to 3 hours there and loved it a must do in mexico

Amazing and not super commercial!. I had the most amazing time at Chaak Tun, costs 30USD but this gets you a guide taking you through the caves. I had Abel and he was a great English speaker and explained all the formations and techniques for moving through the caves in great detail. I was alone so got a really great tour as there was only me to worry about. The caves are mostly underground and with flashlights and if you're a good swimmer in some parts to can see 30/40/50 meters away, just breathtaking!!! The water is so clear and it's really well done, don't go commercial, just get a taxi there from main square in playa! It's about 6 or 7ks away from there

A MUST SEE! . This cenote experience is amazing. We went in the afternoon and we had the whole place to ourselves. Our guide Felix was so knowledgeable. He taught us about Mayan culture and everything you ever wanted to know about cenote formation. We recommend you visit in the afternoon as it is usually very quiet and really gives you such a special experience. The photographer was also excellent and put together a wonderful CD of photos.

Craaaaaazy!. We didn't really know what we're getting into, but we wanted to go to a cenote and we were staying in playa del Carmen, so it was close by. It ended up being $54 U.S. (950 pesos) for the two of us to go on the two hour tour. Our guide was Abel and he was great!! He took us all through the underground river and showed us the stalactites, and explained how they form. We had snorkeling gear, and wet suits were available. I didn't wear a wet suit, but was fine until the very end when I got a bit chilly. He took us into one place where if you went underwater and looked ahead it showed just how long the caves go!! There was a girl taking pictures along the tour and they were available for a fee. That was a bit pricy too... $30US for all (60) the pictures or $20 for 4. There was a tequila tasting afterwards and that guy was really fun! Would definitely recommend this place if you're going to do a cenote since it has a great tour and it was an incredible experience!

Cruise ship excursion, well worth the cost.. Did a RC shore excursion, worth every penny. Bring an underwater camera and your swimsuit. They provide water shoes and life vests. You will swim between caves, requires some exertion and not good for people with limited mobility. After we ate a Mayan style meal in one of the caves, then a Tequila tasting, and sale. We never felt a hard sell, and our guide Eli was great, and very patient.

Great Cenote. We have been to many cenotes in Mexico and everyone is different. This one is pretty much all underground. It was so beautiful, the water is so clear and the formations are incredible. We had Felipe and he was an awesome guide with so much experience in diving and cenotes.

Beautiful cenote . Went with a family of 7. Cost 350 pesos per person which included a tour guide, and all the gear. A photographer comes with you and the cost of the photos is 450 pesos which is a bit expensive as the quality isn't the best. You will be asked to tip the tour guide at the end and they will lead you to their tequila tasting section which you are then kinda forced to purchase a bottle. Our tour guide, Able, was lovely and looked after us all. The tour was done at a comfortable pace and we had plenty of time to enjoy both cenotes.I would recommend coming here but just be aware that you could be up for some extra costs.

Okay cenote,. This cenote is okay and an interesting walk through the caverns, but the actual in war we through the cenote is not nearly as good or extensive as others further south towards Tulum. It is about a ten minute taxi ride from Playa del Carmen.

Pictures don't do this place justice. We traveled to Mexico on our honeymoon, and we were trying to avoid most of the tourist traps. After pulling into the parking lot at Rio Secreto and realizing they wanted $75US per person for a tour, we googled the next closest cenote which happened to be Chaak Tun. It's a little off the beaten track and we were actually a little nervous driving there, but once you get there, there are at least bathrooms and lockers. Our timing turned out to be just right, and my husband and I ended up getting a private tour with Felipe. He told us of how he was a trained cave diver and he knew so much about the cenote, the history of the Riviera Maya and had great tips on what to do and where to go. We snorkeled through the caves and Felipe expertly called our attention to fossils, bats, wildlife and other cool sights that we would have missed had we not had a guide. The one-on-one experience was top-notch, and I'd highly recommend having Felipe lead you through the Chaak Tun cenote if you have the chance. For the rest of the trip, we found ourselves saying "well, Felipe told us...!" Also, the cenote itself is beautiful. It's cool and you need the wetsuit, but the water is clear, the lighting is perfect and there is so much beauty to see both above the water and below. If you only have time for one cenote tour, I'd go with this one. Also, we didn't pay extra for the photo package but if I could go back I might have done that as we had trouble getting shots on our iphones that captured the true beauty of the place.

Price was as expected - no restaurant though. Their 2-hour cavern and cenote tour was 450 pesos per person (less than 30 US dollars) and is definitely worth the price. They provide a wetsuit, flashlight and a great guide, although a tip of between 100 to 200 pesos is appropriate for him. A pleasant surprise was that the road is paved all the way out to Chaak Tun now. You will see some painted rocks on the right side of the road on the ground with letters about one foot high that spell out Chaak Tun. If you're driving, slow way down since you will be turning right on a blind curve into the parking lot shortly after you see those rock letters.We didn't do the tequila tasting. From reading other reviews I thought there would be a restaurant onsite, although I understand now that cruise ship tourists are taken to a restaurant in the area as part of their excursion to Chaak Tun. This is a good rainy-day activity since you'll be underground most of the time. Above ground there are also covered areas to hang out in if it's raining. If you can choose the time of day to go, afternoon is best since all the cruise ship tourist groups come in the morning and the afternoon is much less crowded. Closing time is around 4:30 pm.
Thievish staff. You must take guide in this cenote. And fee is 700 pesos per guide. But first time they told us that we don´t need take a guide.
Chaak Tun was great!. This is an awesome way to get away from the cruise ship crowds and the fakeness of Playa Del Carmen...Able was an awesome guide and it was worth the trip!

Great cenote. The closest cenote in playa del Carmen.They are uncrowded and inexpensive to visit compare to others.We had the place to ourselves considering we went after 2pm and it was raining.. They provide us with all the snorkel gear and wetsuits. Expert guide, Felipe was knowledgeable and gave us a safe, and exciting tour. You don't need to know how to swim (he took care of my friend who didn't). After we changed there was Time for fun Tequila tasting session (unfortunately the guy got upset because I was trying to google about their product I ended up not buying, but my friends did).

Great excursion!. My husband & siblings, with their spouses, booked this excursion from our ship. We absolutely loved the day. Great guide, nice authentic meal and a wonderful trip through the underground river. The caves and formations made you feel like you are in another world---really beautiful!
Enjoyed the day 👍

Chaak Tun cenote aka Rain stone in Mayan. The tour companies probably won't steer you to these amazing cenotes a few miles west of Playa del Carmen along Juarez Avenue.We have visited a number of cenotes in the Yucatan and these have been the best by far! They are uncrowded and inexpensive to visit compared to others(30 USD).We had the place to ourselves. They provide you with all the snorkel gear and wetsuits to ward off the chill. Expert guide,Felix was knowledgeable and gave us a safe, exciting tour that even allowed us ample time to spend with the bats, turtles, catfish, small fish and incredible stalagmites/stalactites on our own. After we changed there was Manny with a fun Tequila tasting session and a chance to buy the good stuff.

Well worth the trip. We visited while vacationing in Playa Del Carmen, just a short taxi ride away. Franchesco was a great guide. Our family group ranged in age from 9-72 and everyone was made comfortable.

Awesome tour. This place is pretty awesome. For $30 they outfit you with everything you need (snorkel mask, water shoes, wetsuit, locker, flashlight, life vest) and you spend 2+ hours exploring the cenotes. They are well lit and absolutely amazing. Our group was also only 4 people (including my wife and I) so it feels like a private tour. Definitely worth the trip!
Amazing. This activities included the cenote, visiting the maya and swimming with the turtle. Really good experience and the guide, Cedrick, was amazing. A+
Enchanted Underground!. This experience was amazing! One of the coolest things I've done on a vacation. Mario was a great guide and you have to see it in person because pictures do not do it justice!

Cautious at first glance but fantastic! . My boyfriend and I drove there ourselves and did a tour with just the two of us. It had been rainy that week, so when we showed up between 9:30 - 10 we were the only ones there. I was nervous it wouldn't go well because it was a smaller place and we were the only ones there, but they proved me wrong! The tour is two hours and $30 per person. The guide will take you to two separate entrances to swim in. They also provide you with flashlights, snorkel masks, wet shoes, and a wet suit if wanted. The cenote is very well lit. The girls who work there will follow you around and take pictures at certain spots, as well as candid pictures. At the end you can buy the entire CD of pictures for $30. Great price! Our guide, Abel, was excellent. It was his day off and he still took us out! He was constantly making sure we were comfortable and safe. I would suggest going when it is less busy because you will get a more personalized experience of some of the smaller areas of the cenote (if you are a good enough swimmer to go without a life vest). Overall, it far exceeded my expectations. Great experience for a great price. I would highly recommend going here!

Wonderful experience!. We explored the Chaak Tun cenote with our informative and personable guide Abel. It was an amazing experience- like diving into another world. I enjoyed the natural beauty of the formations rather than the flashy fabricated view some of the other touristy cenotes have. All the staff were very helpful with a great sense of humor. We thought the price was well worth the experience. Abel answered all of our questions, showed us exactly how to maneuver around the formations, made us feel very safe and was personable to the degree that we wanted him to come visit us in the states. Thank you for such a terrific time!

Enchanting Adventure. You have to see this place in person! We went early to avoid crowds and had an amazing tour by Mario. He took his time and explained everything throroughly. The hotel tried to talk us into going to one of the closer, more touristy cenotes- but this one was amazing! Well worth the money and the best part of our trip!

great for all skill levels. Tour guide Franchesco Pancho was great about information of cenote and always checking on safety of us. Well worth the tip to have him with us. Also great that only 3 of us in group more quality time together,not rusyed at all. I dont swim, but felt very comfortable and safe.total tour about 2hrs. Also photos taken were very nice, bought on disc memories forever. Thankyou. Reasonable price for time and equipment received.

Great escape from touristy Playa del Carmen!. Great tour, and definitely bring your swim suit (they provide wet suits, etc.). Had Abel as a guide and he was terrific. Good activity to get out of the sun mid day and only takes a couple hours.

Very ignorant . Went here today as we were told it was very good.Well let's start with the ignorant sales staff.If you do not take a tour you can't get in was what we were aggressively told. on asking the amount 1700 pesos for two adults and a child I just walked away.You always get 1 every now and again,I guess it was my turn.To many good cenotes around the area to pay a excessive price for this aggressive selling practice.

Best shore excursion ever!. We took the "Underground River and 5th Avenue Shopping" tour operated by Explora Caribe and booked through Celebrity Cruise lines.Our guide, Pablo, was excellent! Very professional and informative. We started out at the pier in Cozumel where you meet to take the ferry to Playa dealCarmen. Unfortunately the weather made the ride a bit bumpy, but it's worth enduring! After a 30 minute or so ride you dock in Playa del Carmen where you board a tour van to take you to Cenote Chaak Tun.This BY FAR is the coolest thing I've ever done. You are provided with a locker, water shoes, snorkel and wet suit (if desired) and enter into the cenote where you're surrounded by stalactites and stalagmites and get to swim/snorkel for quite some time. Our guide suggested forgoing the wet suit so that we could feel the great minerals in the water on our skin (it really isn't cold!) this is a must do excursion and well worth the $85 (plus tip!)

Cool escape to the Mayan jungle and cenotes, cool guides (Francisco thumbs up! :). A short drive north of downtown Playa del Carmen and you can already swim in fresh water caves with a rich Mayan heritage and natural beauty. The park is well organized and has an eco touch to it. The staff and guides are really nice and helpful. Our guide Francisco (or Pancho del Rancho like he called himself) was informative and cheerful, he explained about the caves and the nature as well as the history of the site. All the gear is provided (masks, neopren suits, water rubber shoes etc.), the water is nice to swim in, and the experience to dive and look underwater in the cenote underworld is just priceless! A very memorable experience!

Loved this cenote, loved Philippe our guide!. This cenote still retains a lot of Mexican/Mayan charm. The guides are professional and equipment is provided but it's not built up like a classic tourist trap( thank God). It's the cenote you are looking for and its near perfect. $30 usd per person for 2 hours.. Cenote is interior lit. Worth it. Tequila tasting at the exit! One criticism: no showers. Managers, if you are reading this: a hot shower would be awesome, but other than that, please resist making this gem into an American theme park :)

Great place, Abel excellent guide. What a great experience! Really want to comment on our guide Abel who really went above and beyond to make our group feel comfortable!! Try to request his if possible. Beautiful place and really unique experience. Tips: bring pesos, no credit cards :-( also douse yourself with bug spray before you arrive!

Amazing opportunity to see nature's beauty. With a plethora of cenotes in the mayan riviera we chose this one after stumbling upon online. A smaller note you get a more personalized experience here. The views were amazing especially at the deeper cenote at the end. Abel was our guide and was absolutley amazing. He was knowledgeable, funny and considerate. He assisted an older lady who didn't want to get her head underwater. Recommendations take a cab from playa del carmen and arrange time to come back. They accept only pesos so bring enough to tip guide as well. The time is about 2 hour trip. They have all equipment but you can bring water shoes and definitely a change of clothes. They have lockers and bathrooms.

Well organized and conducted tour of wonderful cenote. We visited four cenotes and this was the best by far. It seemed safe, well organized (even with a photographer to record our journey), and commercial in a pleasant, low key manner (unlike much about the raging commercialism of Playa). Best of all was our guide who was a delightful man with great English (he lived in California for a period) and a real desire to inform.

Best Cenote That We Visited. This was a great place to spend a half day. It is only a few miles from downtown Playa. The cab ride was 200 pesos each way. Arrange for the cab driver to pick you back up at the end of the tour as there are not cabs waiting at the park.I thought that the 30 dollar entrance fee was well worth it. It includes a locker, guided tour, wetsuit, and snorkeling equipment. The caves are very interesting since they have stalactites and other formations. The water is very clear. The guide was very friendly and professional. Not strenuous. One of the coolest things we did in Playa.

Amazing tour of Ancient Cenotes!. We had Dante, a guide from our resort take our family and family friend to this attraction and we were not disappointed. We toured two wet cenotes and one dry one. Our guide was very helpful with our disabled son, who snorkeled for the first time. The water is cool and refreshing and crystal clear. There is a rope in the water to follow so you can't get lost. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the history of the area and made the experience very enjoyable. There is an abundance of marine life, including turtles about the size of a dinner plate. My daughter was thrilled to be able to hold one! At the end of our experience we enjoyed hot cheese empanadas with a spicy salsa. Very tasty. I would definitely recommend this experience to anyone!

An excellent afternoon excursion. It's just on the far side of the 307 from downtown Playa. Not quite as extensive as Rio Secreto, but half the price, and, unlike Rio Secreto, you can take your own photos. A fun extended underground cenote tour.

Extraordinary cenote very near Playa. We took a taxi ride to this spot down a dirt road just outside the town of Playa del Carmen. We arrived around 11 and we seemed to have missed the cruise crowds. If you can get there earlier I'm sure it'd be better but we were fine. It is very well organized once you walk up to the front desk. Everything is explained in English and we were told that after we changed in the changing rooms we would be met by our guide. Pancho was our very informed and enthusiastic guide for this incredible experience. My husband is not a strong swimmer and feels uncomfortable in deep waters but or guide Pancho kept him near by his side to explain to him the upcoming underwater terrain. We learned so much about Mayan history and culture as well as how this marvelous geological creation was formed. If you are visiting the area you will notice there are dozens of cenotes to visit and if I had the time I would go to every singe one. I did visit another cenote that I read about and as soon as I reached the other cenote I appreciated the service at Chaak Tun, especially Pancho. There are certain items that can be rented that will make your visit here a bit more exceptional. All of these extras do add up and I will explain which ones you will need. If you have your own snorkeling mask and tube bring them to avoid that rental, also you can bring your own water shoes. They sell them at the Walmart within walking distance to the 5th Avenue for less than the cost of the rental at Chaak Tun. One item that is worth consideration are the wet suits. If you get cold easily get the wet suit, it makes the whole tour and underwater cave exploration very comfortable. If you keep moving and can handle a bit of cool water you won't need the wet suit. If you are unsure just get the wet suit. Another aspect of visiting this cenote are the photographers that will take pictures of you and your family. I was a little annoyed at first by the paparazzi, that is until I saw the pictures at the end of our visit. Well I never buy pictures at tourist attractions, but this was my surprising exception. I bought the disk with almost 30 images of my partner and I for $450 pesos. For all those great pictures it was well worth it when you convert your currency.The only issue I would bring up to the photographers would be to change their use of disks. We came home and realized we didn't have any disk drives on our computers. My partner is going to have to take the disk to work and put the photos on a thumb drive. I wonder if the photographers at Chaak Tun might consider an upgrade of their equipment.

Beautiful underground wonder. There were 3 of us in our party, we took a taxi from 4th and 30th AV. and it cost 150 pesos each way. Be sure to arrange with the taxi driver to come back and pick you up. Ask the price before you get in. The tour was 2 hours so we told him 2 1/2 but I'd wished we said 3 because there is a small tequila seller there and we enjoyed tasting and chatting with him, but were a little rushed at the end, because our taxi arrived.we arrived at 8:30 am and they opened at 9. We got some pictures of spider monkeys while we waited. I recommend going early, we had the place to ourselves.Or guide was Phillipe, and he was wonderful, took his time and was very knowledgeable about the area, and plants as well. I have seen me fri nods coming and I intend to return with them for another swim. The only thing I would do different is I'm going to look for my own waterproof flashlight, they only want to give you one for every two people and one of ours was very dim. Also do not bring a lot of stuff with you, the lockers are not very big and they want you to share a locker between two people. The cost at the gate was $30 and included locker/lock, water shoes, a wetsuit, lifejacket, shared flashlight, mask, and snorkel. They have packages of photos available at the end but we did not buy those. So bring extra cash if you feel you might want that.

Fun and Beautiful. Our first time seeing a cenote and it was very impressive. Felix was funny and formative. It was amazing swimming through the tight spots of the caves, with bats sleeping overhead. It was also nice that there was a personal photographer there to capture some of the moments.

Nice experience but not for little ones.. We experienced several cenotes while in the area. It was different being in a cave. I would not recommend it if you plan on going with little ones. We have 3 children 7-4-2 and they scared and did not like the feeling.

Our first visit to a Cenote and this was WOW. This is definitely not to be missed. Very very close to Playa Del Carmen( straight up Juarez) This was an amazing experience and our wonderful guide, Felix, made it complete. There may be other Cenotes but here the group was small and the time spend experiencing the wonders of this magical place was perfect.

A JEWEL in the jungle!. amazing healing waters of he ancient Mayans - a must see! Hang out for the day - rain or shine. Snorkel or swim - bring your own munchies and beverages. A great family place or romantic get away! We will go back. Oh, and take an underwater camera!!!

Beautiful. The Cenote swim was great. It was part of my package with swimming with Turtles and was very fun. The guide was very knowledgeable and obviously loved the area and was happy to pass on the knowledge. I do wish the road in was a little better.
We loved this spot!. Close to PDC, gorgeous caves, incredible sights, excellent, knowledgable, friendly guide. Worth a visit!

Chaak Tun tour with Felix. This is a cenote very worth visiting. Felix was an exceptional guide. He led our group, switching effortlessly between Spanish and English. He has a deep knowledge and provided a lot of wonderful information, which made it worth taking the tour. It's a very special cenote and after seeing a few other cenotes this one stands out, especially because it is all underground. There were a few kids on our tour and Felix took great care with them to ensure they were enjoying the tour and ok/warm enough. He gave us all a great appreciation for this natural wonder.
AMAZING. do NOT miss this tour!!! swimming in the caves was the MOST AMAZING thing I have ever experienced !!! a must do!
Cenote Chaak Tun. This place was fantastic. All natural, professional, friendly and knowledge guide. We had Felipe as our guide and I would recommend him. A must see if you are in the area.

Highlight of the trip!!!. Fantastic cave cenote! It's about a 200 peso / 20 min taxi ride from Playa Del Carmen.It opens at 0900 (1000 on Sundays) and costs 450 pesos for adults and 300 pesos for kids (they let my 6 year old in for free).You do a two hour guided tour which involves cave walking and about one and half hours snorkelling - lots of stalactites/mites, catfish, bats, etc - very beautiful.All kit is provided (wetsuit, snorkels and masks, torch, buoyancy vest, wet shoes etc), but you can take your own if you have them.The whole place has a very unassuming entrance, but once inside we were blown away by it. We took our kids (6 & 8) but they are both good swimmers.This trip wouldn't be suitable for those who have difficulty walking on rough terrain, or who are not comfortable in water. Water temp is a constant 23C - about 6C cooler than your local swimming pool, but it's fine with the wetsuit.Take a tip for your guide.

Enchanting. Well worth the money and the time. Ask for Abel, he was informative and fun. We weren't rushed, answered any questions and had a great sense of humor. As for the cenote... it was beautiful, awe inspiring and enchanting. The waters are crystal but a little chilly, not bad once you get used to it. The caverns are dark and tranquil (you are supplied a small flashlight). There is plenty of room to float around in. I would go again.
Outstanding. It's such a beautiful experience, u have to at least just once ...I went as part of a day tour to swim with the turtles and cenote..it was well worth it!

Great First Cenote Experience. Got a cab ride from the Gran Porto Real hotel to the Cenote and it cost $18 each way. Not bad! The Cenote was $30 and it was definitely worth it to me! Other reviews have mentioned the cost as being expensive but we had Mario as our tour guide and he was great when it came to taking his time and truly showing showing us everything and explaining how/why things are the way that they are.

Amazing experience! . We arranged with our hotel a taxi who would be reliable to pick us up before and after (400 P round trip) then paid when we got there - get there early & miss the big groups- we paid in cash so it was around $28 per person to enter that includes lock, wet suit, snorkel & mask, wet shoes & guide! Was an over all amazing experience our guide Marios (sp) was knowledge in the history and traditions of the Mayan people! Was excellent!!

Great Experience. Much Better than through a tour company.. Very short drive or taxi ride from the tourist area of playa del carmen. Inexpensive and well worth a visit. You swim in the cenote underground in the fresh water. Go there!

Amazing experience. This place is almost surreal. Snorkelling in a cave with crystal clear water and amazing rock formations. You have to take a tour, but that tour is well worth it, and there was plenty of time to swim. If you are a good swimmer, go without life jacket.

Amazing!. We wanted to visit a cenote without having to bounce into other people while swimming and this was absolutely perfect. The cenote is situated just outside Carmen and you reach it easily by cab. Just make sure to ask the driver to pick you up again approx after two hours. We paid the driver 500 return.It was us and another couple together with our guide Abel who made this experience a fabulous one. The staff here work solely voluntarily so an extra tip is in right place but optional of course. For us it was easy to tip because Abel was really professional giving us a lot of information while swimming and helping me out when I got a bit claustrophobic. If you want to experience a cenote basically on your own with professional guides this is the place to go. They provide you with wet suit, shoes, life west and flashlight as well as a locker for your gear and valuables.

Minutes from downtown Playa del Carmen; amazing! . This is a gem. Just minutes from downtown Playa del Carmen and not touristy at all. A cab will cost you $10-15 each way. Just ask them to pick you up in two hours and you're golden. Able, or tour guide, was awesome. The tour costs $30 per person and a good tip is highly appreciated. This excursion was simply outstanding!

You have to visit Chaak Tun!. I will start by saying that accusing these caves is an extraordinary experience. You will swim in these caves surrounded by small fishes and bats. Stalactites and stalagmites are all over. This cenote is not that touristic yet...and thats exactly why it is so precious! The whole adventure lasted nearly two hours and we paid close to U$27 per person. They provide us with lanterns, water shoes and if you want drysuits. My kids just swam with their bathing suits. We arrived to the location vey late, ;like at 4:00 and with no reservation. Still we were able to visit it! I suggest going a bit earlier.

Two Nice Cenotes in one, but expensive . The complex consists of two different Cenotes; 1 completely underground and one semi-closed. Entry fee was USD 30 per person, which is quite expensive compared to other Cenotes. However, the visit also takes longer (1-2 hours) and includes a guide. Our private guide Abel was very friendly and as we travelled with 4 adults and 2 small kids (3 months and 2 years) he took the time and showed the place first to two of us and thereafter to the others. The Cenotes are beautiful and you need a guide to show you the various chambers via the water. If it wasn't for the price, I would have rated it 5 out of 5.Taxi from playa del Carmen city centre (ca15mins) costed us 150 pesos (one-way); best to agree with the driver to pick you up afterwards as the place is not frequented by a lot of taxis. Be mindful of the large groups of cruise passengers that visit, it can get a bit crowded so better visit early.
Vacation fun . First time ever being in Mexico !Very unique visit, very beautiful !!!Water was so clear and the light shining through the earth was mesmerizing !!!

Abel and cenote was incredible! . We had a larger group and wasn't with a tour company. We picked Chaak Tun because it was close and pulled up without a reservation . While $30usd is pricier than some other nearby cenotes, after having been to gran cenote & a few others, I can attest this is the spot for a truly beautiful experience! Abel was AMAZING! He was knowledgable, funny and let us have a lot of time in the caves...the formations are unlike others and unmolested. I can see why the guides are necessary for its preservation. Everything is provided - snorkel, life jackets, flashlights, wetsuit , lockers etc. worth it!

Abel was the BEST guide for a wonderful experience!!. My friend had never been to a cenote so I wanted to take her to a good one but one that was also new to me as well.I couldn't have made a better choice. Beautiful place, extremely friendly and knowledgeable staff. Abel was a great guide. Personable, knowledgeable and made a point to make our experience feel unique just to us. Highly recommend both the place and Abel!!!

Beautiful cenote few minutes from Playa del Carmen. Easily reachable with taxi from Playa del Carmen. Crystal clear water under the ground. Swimming/snorchling with flashligh. Recommended highly!Just remember to manage taxi back, there are none standing, so you have to ask taxi to come at time requested.Felix is the bedt guide, he will tell you everything about cenotes un mexico.

Hell yes. Do it.. We did an excursion with the Snorkel Shop that took us to this cenote. As many other reviewers say, it was the highlight of our trip to Playa del Carmen. The cenote (cavern) is spectacular and hardly anyone else was here. We went through the cenote, snorkeling in some parts and swimming through others. We opted for this over the more touristy Xcaret and didn't regret it. The Snorkel Shop offers great tours, be sure to look them up as well. Note: people who are afraid of dark spaces, enclosed spaces, spiders and/or bats will probably sit this one out. If you're adventurous, you'll love it.

You Must Go!. Today we visited the Chaak Tun Cenote and it was amazing! My Husband and I went with our children (aged 8 and 6) and other family members. The kids loved it as much as we did! I was worried that the water was going to be freezing cold but it really wasn't, "refreshing" as our tour guide Phillipe called it and he was right. It is such a beautiful place and we would definitely recommend it to anyone. Next time we are in Mexico we'll come back for sure!
Awesome. Yes, the water was a little chilly but you become acclimated quickly during the swim. I would suggest bring a waterproof camera - absolutely beautiful site.
A swim to remember. It's an amazing experience to swim in a cenote. The clear waters have a magical effect. Well worth a dip!

A jewel west of Playa del Carmen. Chaak Tun is an amazing cenote and it is so close to downtown Playa del Carmen. They offer a walking tour and also the opportunity to snorkel. We got there by 9am and were the only ones in the cenote. The silence and the vastness made this tour unforgettable. Our tour guide was Abel; he was very knowledgeable about the Mayan history which made it even more enjoyable and interesting.

Excelent tour for everyone. We booked this tour through our cruise ship and it exceeded our expectations. Great time and very interesting. Its a beatiful site that you dont come across very often. Great guides, very patient and careful with every guest. 100% recommended.
Best Cenote Close to Playa. Have been here a couple times, last time I opted for the snorkel package, definitely worthwhile. Make sure you have "el negro" as your tour guide if he is still there.
Best Cenote. See and go swimming in this system before it gets crowded and overrun like the other ones. This trip was truly perfecto. And ask for Pablo, he's the best!

Mesmarising . Visited here on way back from Chitsinitza omg it's gorgeous with the lights shining through, definitely get in and experience the cool water, they provide life jackets so no excuse :) once you've finished your swim head up to the restaurant for a lovely buffets and nice cold drinks. On way out you'll pass through the tequila shop go on treat yourself loads to choose from and we'll worth the money, remember your luggage allowance though

Fantastic experience! . We where the first visitors and got the first tour all by ourselves. Our guide gave us an excellent experience. Pretty narrow some places during the tour but that made the tour even more special. We have visited several cenotes in Mexico but this is the most awesome so far. You won't regret it:)

True Cenote Experience. Our first Cenote experience and it was great. We didn't want to go to one of the huge commercialized sites and be amongst hundreds of people, so this was perfect for us. We were in a group with three others so it was a nice small group. Our tour guide was very friendly (Abel) and was very helpful. We saw some catfish, bats and heard stories of huge spiders and spider monkeys. We would highly recommend if you don't want to fight the crowds. We got there around 2 pm. It was $30 per person and we then paid $30 for a cd with 20+photos.

Majestic Swim!. We cruised to Cozumel and took a fairy to Playa del Carmen just to see this cenote and it was 100% WORTH IT. Paid less than the cruise's excursion and got to make a lot more of our day. Checked out Dos Ajos cenote before coming here but wasn't impressed with their set up. They basically advertise a cost per cave. Pay this much if you want to see this (with pictures on wall) and this much if you want to see bats too. The people running Chaak Tun have a flat rate (was about $30 US when converted) to explore everything WITH all gear included AND tour guide. Abel was our guide and he was GREAT. My daughter is 9 and took quite a while to get her little butt in the freezing water. He was super patient. He also took us on our own instead of with another group coming in because he knew we were in a hurry to make the ferry back on time. Super accommodating place and a BEAUTIFUL, serene chunk of nature here :). I asked the photographer not to come since we had our own water camera. My suggestion is NOT to do this as it is sooooo beautiful, you won't want to risk it trying to play photographer while your exploring up to your chin in the water!! Plus it's non obligatory, so if you don't like the pictures you don't have to buy it. My guess is that CD is negotiable in price, too, since everything else in Mexico seems to be. I do wish the place had more wetsuits. Mine was huge on me (I'm super petite in their defense) and they had none for children :(. They also didn't give my child a flashlight (children probably drop them in the water so I get it) so she was a bit bummed about that. I took the advice from others on here about it being really busy in the morning so we went around 2 and it was empty. Thanks Chaak Tun!!!

Cool experience, not to be missed.. Myself and my son got a taxi from 5th avenue to Chaak Tun, cost 200 pesos each way. Taxi driver arranged to pick us up 2.5 hours later. Entrance to the caves is 450 pesos, for which you get mask, snorkel, wetsuit and one dive light per couple. Ask for an extra light as this will make your experience much better. The first cave is ok, but nothing to get excited about but the second and larger cave is awesome. You swim through narrow caves and explore the whole system. Recommended

Exquisite!. This was an experience of a lifetime. We started off in the lagoon and then went to the caves. Bats were flying in and out and I managed to capture some using slow motion on the camera. The water was cool, but not "shocking". An easy walk to each destination. Even though it's a snorkeling adventure, the rock formations and surroundings are equally enthralling. Definitely a must see! We spent time on the beach afterward and had a delicious Mexican meal and shopped for local gifts. You could easily spend all day here but 3 to 4 hours will work as well (not including travel).
Amazing natural place. It is worthy to ho and see how nature can create this magical places. We had a great time. The water is fantastically chilled

Great cenote! Not a tourist trap. Great cenote! Seems to be less busy than the others. 5 of us had our own private tour guide and had the caves to ourselves. They provide wetsuits and life jackets. Do bring your own snorkel and goggles
Beautiful. I am afraid of heights, but love to challenge myself. We repelled down into the water. It was absolutely amazing and would definitely do it again.

Excellent experience. The water is cold, but jump right in and you won't regret it! The Cenote is a wonderful place and a great experience. Our guide Mario was fantastic and showed us all the highlights. Easy in and easy out of the pool.

Amazing experience, beautiful location, great proximity to Playa Del Carmen.. We chose Chaak Tun over other Cenotes in the area b/c we wanted something close enough to PDC that our 3yo wouldn't go crazy in the car ride. A short taxi ride later and we started one of the best adventures we've ever had. The pools are clean, clear and surreal. The water temperature is great, though in hindsight, I would recommend using a wet suit b/c of the total leangths of the tour (2 hours). The photographers really know their venue and take great pictures so make sure to budget and extra $30 for the CD at the end of the trip. Our guide, Rico was personalble, knowledgable and fun to talk with Highly recommend for families visiting the PDC/ Tulum area.

Cinotes snorkel. This is a must do trip. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this together. We met some really cool people along with our guides David and Oliver. These guides were helpful in every way imaginable. The cinotes are beautiful to snorkel but I personally intend on diving here my next trip.Best Regards,Richard Riley

Fantastic Trip. Our guides David and Oliver were entertaining and knowledgable. They took us to swim with the Tortugas and explore the Cenotes. On this trip they provided us with transportation, equipment, water, sodas, snacks and a meal at the Cenotes. It was an awesome experience.
Beautiful experience!. Is a dream come true, beautiful and crystal cold water, stunning and calm place, love the tour, if you like the water and nature this tour is a must.

Incredible experience - a great way to see nature hundreds of millions of years old!!!. We visited Chaak Tun as part of a private tour & thoroughly enjoyed it. The caves themselves are magical & beautiful but to snorkel in the cenote & see the underwater stalactite & stalagmites that have formed over hundreds of millions of years is truly wonderful! A very memorable & fun experience & highly recommended.We were lucky in that we had the caves to ourselves & I would definitely recommend visiting either by yourselves or as part of a private tour rather than as a large group. The experience is far more enjoyable & intimate.

Beautiful, exotic experience!. This was our first time swimming in a cave/underground river. We'd never been to a cenote before, and it was stunning. Our guide was Abel, and he was wonderful. He explained to us the cultural significance of cenotes to the Maya and a little about their rituals. He led us through, giving us just the right amounts of time in various locations, and wowing us a bit when time allowed. We booked this as part of an excursion with our cruise ship, so admission, locker, lunch, and transportation were all included in the cost. They had flashlights for us to use, snorkeling masks for those who wanted them (we didn't take one and missed out on seeing some of the cool underwater things). Even lunch was served in one of the caves, and it was very very good.I brought my wetsuit from home and was very comfortable. The water is in the low 60s (Farenheit), and being a Florida girl who is a wimp about the cold, I was very glad to have a wetsuit. My husband didn't use a wetsuit, just a rash guard, and he didn't complain about the cold after the initial shock of getting in the first time. But if you already have one, I'd recommend bringing it.

Worthwhile . This place is truly amazing... very friendly staff .., our guide guy Abbel was great defo worth £18 per head which includes guide for two hours and all the equipment. .. I would recommend going in the afternoon about 13:00 and you might be lucky just like us and have the guide just for your self... it really made it special.. the caves are breath taking ...
Coba Adventures. Great day, tour guides Alex and Martin were great! They loved their jobs and made out day extra special! You are lucky if you get these guides! Highly recommended!

Breathtaking!. This was the first cenote I had ever been to and it was truly amazing. We met a dive instructor from Cozumel who recommended it. There was a cruise ship tour group there at the same time so we waited for them to leave and we had the whole place pretty much to ourselves. We were in a small group of 5 which was ideal and the guide, Ricardo, was funny and informative. He spoke perfect english and was very passionate about the history and preservation of these sites. It was a great introduction to the caves, as the next stop we went we were scuba diving them so it made me very excited! We caught a taxi there from Playa del Carmen which was about 100 pesos (not even $10USD) and told him to come back in 2 and a half hours to pick us up and he did! Little isolated if you haven't organised a ride home.

Cold but fun, can handle big groups. We were a group of 25 in early October. The water was freezing during the tour because we weren't moving much, but it was comfortable once we went off on our own to swim. There were some grumbles at first, but once a few people jumped in the peer pressure worked on the others. Everyone really enjoyed it and were glad they went. The tour guides were funny and informative.

amazing experience. this was one of the places I enjoyed the most in mexico, the place it self is really unique and the water crystalline full of fishes, the only down thing is that its a bit crowed if you have the time to go further and see other cenotes do it.

Ricardo was great, the Cenote was amazing!. You have to drive down an unnamed street by a shantytown to get to it so you might wonder if you're going the right direction initally. Once you get there it's a simple set up. For around $30 you get a wet suit, booties and a 2 hour tour of 3 or 4 cenotes. We went in a group of 5 people with Ricardo - very knowledgeable, entertaining, and accomodating. I wish they had gloves because some of the formations that you swim by are very sharp/rough and I nicked my knuckles a few times. I'm over 6' and some of the passages I swam through were pretty tight. The water was cool, but I chose not to use a wetsuit and didn't mind at all, it was actually very nice compared to the 80F @ 100% humidity outside! I would really suggest getting your own flashlight (not sharing) because it can be cramped occasionally and you might bump your head against stalagtites if you can't see them - no joke! It can also get a little disorienting down there in the darkness. Other than that, I highly recommend this trip. Very cool!!
Stunning. Went to this place on a trip very nice place to visit arrived from the coach had a look round found it to be very cheap foodcand drinks very reasonable price also

Highlight of our Mexico Trip!!. SO amazing!! Our tour guide, Mario, was fantastic. They are very professional, even though it looks a little run down from the outside. The guides speak great English and are incredibly knowledgable about all questions. Safety is huge for them, and he kept great track of us and made us all feel very safe. We had only 4 others in our group, so it was very private seeming. Really, really incredible experience.
A fun experience!. This tour was fun the caves were awesome and the zip line was short but cool to do! worth checking out.

Great Cenote . This was our first Cenote and a great experience. It is an almost fully closed Cenote where you walk and snorkel through.
