Our guide Riccardo was very knowledgeable and for 450 pesos we had 2.5 hours of good entertainment, learned something on geology and maya culture and some physical exercise. Strongly recommend this Cenote.

Great Adventure in PDC.. What an amazing experience it was. It is a must if you stay at PDC. We took a taxi (200pesos) and the driver also came back for us in 2.5 hours. It's about 10 min drive from PDC. We got there at noon just right on time to catch a small group of 4. Our tour guide Ricardo was awesome and knowledgable. Definitely bring a water proof camera for pictures. You will not be able to take your phone. The water is very cold so two hours in there was enough. It cost 30$ per person which includes wetsuit, flashlight, snorkeling mask and a guided tour. Don't skip this adventure!!! :)
Quick Excursion From Playa. Kind of spooky but cool. Guide was great. Easy to get to by taxi. Had everything you need there. Kind of long tour.

Excellent time. Me and my husband went on a Sunday afternoon. It's was a perfect time to go. Only 2 other couples we there. Our guide was Able and He was awesome. He let us just stroll/swim at our own pace. He was very knowledgeable and was able to answer all our questions. The cave itself was beautiful. A bit cold, but the wet suits helped a lot. It was worth every dollar and I would definitely recommend it. The others just seem so expensive and are probably more busy, this one was a lot more personal and calm.
Beatiful!. Open at 9.00hr (NOT 8.00). Just two persons so nice private tour. Equipment is included.Beatiful views in two cenotes!

Stunning Experience. What an incredible experience this was. We went later in the day, around 3PM, and had the place to ourselves. Our guide, Abel, took great care of us and ensured we were comfortable and enjoying ourselves at all times.We happened to visit after some rain and the water level was high enough that they couldn't use their permanent lights. It was actually very fun to explore the caves with only our provided flashlights. But the water clarity was amazing.If you are anywhere near this place, make the effort to visit. No need to book it somewhere else, just pay when you get there. They provide everything you need. They speak great English and can help arrange for your taxi driver to wait for you or come back for you. Enjoy the incredible experience, and leave them a generous tip for their efforts!

swimming in the depths. What a great experience. You can snorkel around and swim underneath the earth. Absolutely beautiful colors and just a different experience all together. Would be great for kids over the age of 10

Best 2 hours of my life. We had Ricardo as our tour guide while exoloring the cenote. Absolutely amazing experience. 2 hour of exploring 2 caves. Ricardo was fantastic and very knowledgeable. Cenote Chaak Tun is a must!
Must do! Beautiful place. . Great for a rainy day activity. Thanks a lot to our gorgeous guide Riccardo, lovely man, had a fantastic time.

One of the best times of our whole vacation. This was an amazing experience. We have been to all the ruins, and been on a ton of adventure tours, but this was our favorite! It was relaxing, educational, thrilling and beautiful. Our guide, Able, was funny, informative and let us set the pace. Don't be worried about the looks of the place when you pull up. We almost didn't get out of the car. They don't waste money on the front entrance, which I'm sure keeps costs down. The majesty is in the natural beauty of the caverns. Who cares how expensive their sign is. They provide everything you need, and make sure you are comfortable at all times. If you are in the Playa del Carmen/CANCUN area don't miss this adventure. Rain or shine! As far as gratuity, is is discussed at the end, but let me tell you it was the easiest tip I've ever paid. So worth every dime!

Fun Activity Close to Playa Del Carmen. The weather forecast was for rain off and on all day so our group of 3 couples decided to visit Chaak Tun for a little adventure in a cave which is usually wet anyway! First, I want to mention it was a short, easy drive west and away from the beaches from Playa Del Carmen. We had a rental car which made it easy to get there and parking is free. We paid $30 per person and that included a wet suit (much needed...water in the cave was cool), a mask, snorkel, water shoes, one flashlight per couple, and a guide (Mario). What a great time we had! A little walking and much more snorkeling in the pools within the caves was awesome! Mario really made us all feel completely unrushed and relaxed. He was very knowledgeable about the history of the area and everything inside the cave. This is a must-do trip if you like adventure and a little exercise doing something other than walking! Highly recommended!

Perfect rainy day adventure!!. We only found this cenote adventure after the monsoon season storm cancelled our plans to snorkel & kayak. It was the perfect rainy-day activity! Water levels were high but we were lucky it was still safe to enter!Ideal if you have rented a car as it is out of town a few miles away from everything & as it is not a main tourist attraction public transport was a more challenging. We got to tour the cenote with a very experienced, good humored & knowledgeable guide: Ricardo or "Rico". If you can request to take his tour you will not regret it! He ensured we felt safe, learned a lot & had fun despite our initial fears!! The price includes all the gear (light, wet suit, snorkel & mask, water shoes & a locker for your belongings). Everything is beautiful & made easy for you. Be sure to bring extra cash as there is a photographer taking your pictures (she offered us a cool CD of images afterwards) & to tip your guide - no way would we have done this without one!! Enjoy, this is a very cool experience that can be tailored to various skill & desires!

Cold but wonderfull. When you immerse yourself in this attraction your first impression is the temperature of the water. It's COLD! Once you get acclimated to the water temperature you can enjoy the wonders of Mother Nature. A good rainy day activity.

Great rainy day trip. We were a group of six adults that needed to get out of our hotel room on a rainy day. This was a perfect day. Mario was our guide and he was very accommodating....allowed us to explore, take pictures, answered our questions and was safety conscious. $30 per person with everything we needed for a great adventure was incredible. Close to Playa Del Carmen! Can't go wrong with this trip.

Exciting Adventure!. It was the first time to explore and underground cenote with a flashlight It was absolutely beautiful. We went there because our taxi driver recommended that place and we were a little bit skeptical because just before getting to Chaak Tun, the driver passed next to a area that did not look very nice and there was a lot of garbage on the side of the road. We were pleasantly surprised when we got there, the place was clean and well kept. Ricardo, our guide, was amazing, he explained everything we were going to do during the tour and we relaxed (we were both nervous) and enjoy the tour. The rock formations and the clarity of the water are amazing. I recommend this tour for the people that are going in an underground cenote for the first time because it is not very long and, if you like the experience, you can go to others that are longer than this one.
Great Cenote Diving. Being part of an adventure that not many can or have seen. The jungle travel, the water the people. and Diving

great trip exciting underground river swim. we did the swim on a Tullum visit ,then turtle and reef swim followed by the underground cave swim ,cold but such clear water ,trip was with Go Nature great guide Mario would recommend over Chichenitza itza
Crystal clear water! Beautiful!. We went to several cenotes including this one while in Mexico and all were so different it never got boring.

Very cool! . Our guide Abl was awesome and very concerned for our safety and for the preservation of these amazing caverns. He took his time and shared so much information. He gave us plenty of free time to explore. Lunch was excellent as well!
great experience. Stephano was an amazing guide. It's a once in a life time trip. Do not do if you don't like caves. I Recommend you accept use of a wet suit its 20 degrees in the water...

What a Wonderful Day!. So hubby and me travelled with a couple we made friends with at our hotel to this Conote by taxi and our wonderful taxi driver "Berto". He recommended this place and I couldn't agree more. It's completely out in the sticks and down some very long dirt roads, but that was the charm and we loved it.We were very lucky to have our guide in the canote all to ourselves. Maybe not good for them but it was great for us and we got to see this amazing underground cave feeling very relaxed in this cool water.Even our taxi driver Berto came with us! A great experience! Ooh and Bats, lots of them!
Cenote Cenote. Very interesting and something to do if the weather is going to be a bit dreary. All in all money well spent

Awesome!!!. This was sooo cool! Our guide Rico gave us the tour of our life. He was 100% concerned about our safety and comfort, and showed us a great time. The cenote is beautiful and awe inspiring. If you are comfortable swimming around in a dark cave, don't miss this one. The water is cold but they supply you with a wet suit, so its ok. The entire staff does their best to give you a wonderful tour. Everyone speaks English, so if that's important to you, don't worry.
vacation. Nice place to sit and relax and view the water fall with a restaurant there to eat something or get a drink

Just what I needed. After a long day in the sun, this was a perfect place to reset and recuperate. Swimming in the Cenote was refreshing and a little scary as there was black fish in the water. Had a few Nibble at my feet... the sensation was weird. I had alot of fun and recommend especially if you have kids.check out my video of my time there.
very beautiful place. What a beautiful place, You can swim in there and it's a really good experience. You could also have nice pictures in those xenotes.

Great location, great staff, amazing vibe!. I googled this location trying to experience the infamous caverns of the Yucatan peninsula.We, myself & a friend, arrived and were blown away.We paired up with our guide, Felix who cared about nothing else but costumer satisfaction. His overwhelming love for the area was an added inspiration. He even took us somewhere we hadn't been before as he asked us if we were interested and his enthusiasm was impossible to ignore! A super loose, fun & great guy!The staff manager made us realize why the place runs so well too, his relationship with his employees is amazing. The place is chill, people are relaxed and there are no strict rules as to ruin your experience.The staff seem to care more about your experience in Chaak Tun than the money which is what made us tip them more!Chaak Tun itself is a experience you mustn't miss!We highly recommend it!

Snorkeling with the Stalactites and Stalagmites!. Not as well publicized as other Cenotes this one had it all for me. Snorkeling gear, wet suits (use one, trust me. it's much colder than that lovely Caribbean and you are in the water for 1 1/2 hours) and booties were included as well as an excellent guide who didn't rush, just the opposite he wanted us to slow down. Never felt like we had to "move along" to the next spot. The water was a bit murky in spots but still easy to see the underwater caves, and stalagmites. It can be a tad claustrophobic but it is so beautiful that once you get going you likely won't notice.
Cave dwelling. Great place to swim and enjoy the underground caves. While you are there you have to go to talum and XKARET.
A must do!. One of the great wonders in Playa. We went on a tour of the Cenotes and being able to swim through underground caves in crystal clear water is something i will never forget
Amazing. Our guide was very informative as we travelled through the cenote. An experience you will always remember. Will come back again

The Most Impressive Cenote You've Never Heard Of. Most of the Cenotes you'll see in photos are underground watering holes where you can admire the beauty but you just kind of swim around in one place. But this one being so different is one of the things we loved.This cenote is more of an underground cave tour where you get to swim. There are parts with tight spaces, low ceilings and cold water. This felt like a mini-adventure and less like a tourist attraction which is what we were really looking for.The only "bad" thing is that your photos will not turn out too great if you don't have a good flash. There is a photographer who takes a few photos which you can buy at the end. But the sights you'll see with the flashlights they provide is well worth the price of 350 pesos per person.And to top it all off the guide, Ricardo, was amazing. Funny, insightful and made sure we all appreciated everything.

See as many sights as you can. Go and see Mayan ruins they are amazing ! Tulum is beautiful and I recommend going on the Mayan culture tour to see how the mayans now live and go to there villages. Makes you realize what you have. See lots of sights they truely are amazing

Cenotes...clean...fresh...advanture. One of the best attractions from our vacation. The water felt fresh and clean. It was very clear water so snorkeling was great but next time I would like to dive in the cenote caves :)

The best thing we did. Snorkeling in the cenote was quite the experience. Something we've never done before but something we will most certainly do again. Be sure to wear some bug repellent because as you walk down the steps to enter the cenote the mosquitos will bite. The water of the cenote is quite chilly so it takes people a little bit to get in the water so you may be standing waiting for your turn so the mosquitos will be flying around.
great place to swim. We had great guides Alex and Ben. The locals were very friendly and you could jump from the cliff into the water.

Great expérience! Must see . First of all, do not book this from a reseller. Go directly instead and you will pay around 22$ USD per person instead of 89$. Just take a cab, scooter or car to go there. You will save trust me. Guide was amazing and fun!
Amaxing. Unforgettable experience to swim in very refreshing low oxygen water. You need to be a some good sort of swimmer or take support.

Absolutely amazing. Absolutely worth it, this is an experience you'll never forget. You get to swim in an ancient ruin underground. They provide everything except a swimsuit & Towel. They even have wetsuits and swim shoes.

An amazing cave swim near Playa del Carmen. Chaak Tun is an amazing underground freshwater system just a short taxi-ride away from Playa del Carmen. The facility supplies wet suits, snorkel masks, and underwater flashlights. Our guide, Ricardo, was entertaining and very informative, describing the geological formation of the cave system in an amusing way. He is compassionate and understanding of his guests worries of the unknown. The stalactites are beautiful and the water so clear and cool. This is a must do while vacationing in Playa del Carmen.

Good Trip. Brilliant excursion, did this visit in conjunction with a morning on the ATVs with friends and was a great way of getting rid of the dust and dirt, the young lady who took us down was very well informed and certainly knew her stuff

Go for it!!!. I was scared to try this and my kids really wanted to - so we did it and it was the highlight of our trip. Cold water - but you get used to it and you will never experience anything like it!!

Interesting. It's nice that it is not that touristic, an interesting experience if you've never been to a cenote (this was our case). Try to go early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the ppl that come from cruise ships. Also, tips are expected, but I guess that would be aplliable to most of Playa del Carmen.

Great short excursion . Typical Cenotes - basic but adequate facilities. Awesome watery caves, friendly fun knowledgeable guides. Drove there ourselves and paid 360pesos for 1.5 hour tour including equipment. Only a 15min drive out of Playa del Carmen and well worth the effort.

Fun and close to Playa. We wanted to visit another cenote but didn't want a long bus ride, so we took a taxi to this place right on the outskirts of Playa. We arrived around 10:30, and we were the only ones there...but a busload of cruise ship passengers were starting their tour just as we were finishing, so go early! This isn't a free swim deal, you have to take a tour of the caves with a guide for US$30 per person. Totally worth it! Our guide was Ricardo, and he was very knowledgeable and spoke perfect English. They are working on opening more caves for future tours, so this place will just get better.

Amazing hidden gem! New info as of 8/2015. My wife and I had our honeymoon in Playa Del Carmen in August 2015. We really wanted to experience a Cenote and were torn between a couple different options that we found. We found Cenote Chaak Tun to be a great value and bring in the great experiences of snorkeling in a cenote as well as the experience of going into an underground river (we had looked at Rio Secreto and several other cenote excursions). We took a cab from the cab stand on Constituyentes, they told us it would be 200 pesos for one way, 600 pesos for the round trip and the cab driver would wait for us at the entrance and we could leave whenever we wanted. This was different from the $35 that the cab driver at our hotel told us. He did not say anything about round trip so we assumed it was one-way. Definitely verify that before you go. You're going to want the driver to wait for you as it is way out there and nowhere near a main road. The front desk might be able to help you call for one, but who knows how long that would take.Admission was $30 (we had read online somewhere that it was $10 but that was older). That includes a mask, water shoes, wet suit, lifejacket, flashlight and helmet. A tour guide also comes with that. We had Felix who was great. He was very knowledgeable about the cenote, the history of the Yucatan peninsula and the Mayan influence. You can definitely tell that exploring caves is a huge passion of his.The tour part of the exploration is about an hour and a half. It's so surreal and I definitely recommend anyone that has the chance to go there.They take pictures throughout the tour and offer to sell you a video set to music at the end. We did not have any cash left on us at this point, but I don't remember it being that unreasonable, especially compared to the more mainstream tourist stops. Plus you can't really take any decent pictures of your own in the cenote.I will definitely be recommending this to anyone I speak to who is going to PDC.

Great Experience. We had a great time during our excursion. Water was clear and cold but only for a minute to adjust. Honestly, the scenery is so beautiful it takes your mind off the cold water. Our tour guide Pablo was great. Gave us plenty of time to look around and enjoy. Food was great. Delicious. Price of the pictures were reasonable compared to other excursions. We were a group of 6 and everyone enjoyed it.

Cenote Chaak Tun. It was the most beautiful experience of my life and I recommend it for all the people who want to see the beauty of nature. Our guide Felix is a very dedicated man to his job and loves all that it means this magic place. I strongly recommend him as a guide if you want to have a tour full of Mayan history. If you don't feel comfortable in deep water don't worry you will get life vest and also Felix will be there to help you. For me it worked and thanks to him I could to see this miracle of nature, Cenotes!

Great Excursion!. This was definitely worth the trip. Taxi fare from downtown was 190 pesos each way, entrance fee was 360 pesos per person and included everything you'd need such a wet suit, water shoes, flashlight, and mask. There are lockers and bathrooms available. We were there for about 2.5 hours.Our guide Rico was outstanding. My wife is not a strong swimmer and he made sure she felt completely safe. He took my GoPro on a long swim through some underwater passages.Highly recommend a trip here.

Must not miss the Cenotes!. Amazing experience! A must visit place in Playa. Don't buy the tour from the hotel. If you go to the Mayan Ruins there is a kiosk at the entrance from the Tourism Company and they will sell you the tour of the Cenote for $45 and include the entrance to the ruins. Take a cab. We paid a cab $100 to stay with us all day and take us everywhere. It was the best decision!

Great experience, 2 hours of adventure. Just returned from this Cenote. I dislike the commercial, busy all day trips so this was perfect for me. I did not book a tour and only decided to visit as it was raining. I took a taxi from the Royal to the Cenote (200 mx each way) which was more convenient than being packed in a van and waiting for others. My driver was happy to wait for me. I bought my ticket at the Cenote ($360 mx which was $200 mx cheaper than then tour counters charged). All gear is provided. I joined a couple so there was only three of us in our group which made it a very personalised and non commercial experience. Our guide Felix was excellent. He is passionate about caves, very knowledgable and his English is great.

Go after 1pm. This is the fourth cenote I have been to in the area, the most "organized" and I believe the closest one to Playa. Go after 1pm as before that it's likely to be full of cruise ship tourists. The swimming is great of course and the formations beautiful, naturally lit. Last time I was there there were only 4 other people so it was quite peacefull.Downside - souvenir shop and more commercial than other cenotes I've been to.Upside - very close to Playa so if you only have one chance and/or no car you can get there cheaply by taxi.

A wonderful way to start the day!. We explored this beautiful cenote with Ricardo, who was our very knowledgable guide. We spent a couple of hours exploring the cenotes, and saw some amazing stalagmite and stalagtite. What a magical place Chaaktun is!Ricardo speaks excellent English, and shared a lot of interesting Mayan history.

A Nice 2 Hour Guided Tour. My wife and I went discovering today and found this cenote just west of town on Benito Juarez. We had seen it 10 years ago when we were here for a day and a friend showed it to us. It has since expanded and we decided to take the 2 hour guided tour. Ricardo was our guide and it was just the 3 of us. They provided wet suits, water shoes and a underwater light. Lockers were also provided for our stuff. Ricardo was very knowledgable and his English was excellent. The sights inside the cavern were absolutely incredible. Plus the water was crystal clear and so refreshing. We were both very glad that we chose to spend our time here. Highly recommended.

Agree with the other 5 star reviews!. You do need a guide here and it's totally worth it. They don't charge for young kids and have a reduced charge for teenagers. The tour is well done and lasts just under 2 hours. The professional photos are worth buying since it's hard to get good shots in the low light otherwise. The CD they give you also includes some general shots of the cenote and the animals that live there. Our group had about 12 people in it and the guide spoke Spanish and English to us. Our 6 yr old was too cold and didn't do the whole tour: they don't have wetsuits for kids. There's a chance to stop in the middle. But our 9 yr old was so excited that he didn't feel the cold!
unique. It's a great quick place to check out! About 15 minutes from Playa del Carmen. The guides are very informative of the cenote.
Chaak Tun Cenote. This is really worth a visit - you get to swim in the underground cenote and get taken round by a knowledgeable guide. Not busy like other cenotes we have been to.

Mexico Flexico. A great time and must see if you are in Playa del Carmen! For $30USD, you get every piece of equipment you need, a locker, as well as a guide. Ours was Ricardo (or Rico) who was very helpful and funny throughout the trip. He explained everything in Spanish and then in English for our group. The cenote was gorgeous and he gave us a good amount of context to appreciate all of the details of the caves. Water was exquisite and refreshing. It does get a bit cold after a while so the wet suits were clutch. Highly recommend this as part of your trip to Playa del Carmen!

Highlight of our trip!. So so impressed by the breathtaking Cenote Chaak-Tun. Thanks to TripAdvisor reviews we decided to try this even. We booked our tour through the Viator site connected here. I think $30 was so incredibly reasonable. The roundtrip hotel ride offerred by the tour company is extra. We decided to take a taxi. We paid $15 USD to get there and agreed to pay the same if he returned in about 2 hours. There was a large cruise ship tour group ahead of us so we waited until they left and to see if anyone else showed. We were really lucky because it was just us and Abel. I was excited to find out Abel would be our guide as I had read many nice reviews about him. They were all true! Abel spoke perfect English and made us feel very at ease in the cenotes. You can tell he loves his job and has a lot of respect for the history and nature of the cenote. Be sure to bring cash for a generous tip as he advised us he is working as a volunteer dependent on tips. You can bring towels, a bag, shoes or whatever you need because they do provide a padlock /key for the lockers at the entrance. I didn't realize that so I had a waterproof wallet. I chickened out about my waterproof case for my iphone and I'm glad because it really allowed for me to enjoy the cenote without trying to take a million pics. The tour sends a photographer to key spots to take photos of your party, and IMO the price of the disc (about $30) was reasonable. We bought it :) There was another option to buy 4 photos that they print for you on the spot. The park provides you with vests, waterproof flashlight, mask and aqua shoes. The "scary" factor is there just a little. I don't think my kids would have enjoyed it...it's dark, cold water, and there are a few bats flying around. To me, that was awesome. I know bats don't bother us, but still could see some of the kids on the passing tour not loving it. I'd say 8-9 years minimum. There are a few spots that we had to duck under a rock and Abel helped guide us. That was a little odd feeling to be swimming under a dark rock, but pretty exhilarating! My husband and I were SO glad we did this. It's a truly remarkable, unique experience. We were grinning ear to ear, just not believing how cool it was the whole time.* One note I want to mention about Explora tours....a big thank you to them. Once I was home, i realized I must have inadvertently thrown out my photo disc. I got ahold of them by phone and they got my info (I saved my receipt and sent a pic of it) -- they were in contact with me to email me the photos I thought I had lost forever. I can't say THANK YOU enough!

Anniversary Trip. This was a wonderful experience that the world has to offer. I love that you must take a shower prior to our gong into the cavern water. This allows us to preserve it and experience it at the same time. Great trip!
Go if you dare!. the cenote themselves are great, however you are picked up in a van, and no doubt you will be at the back. Be prepared for a horrible, long bumpy road into the cenote area.
tranquil. The cenote was refreshing and very peaceful. The history behind the cenote was very interesting. I would do it again

This is a great place for the price. This cenote is a great place to spend a couple hours and see some cool underground formations. The staff is very friendly. Take Benito Juarez west of 307 about 4 miles and it is on right side.

Amazing, beautiful site. My husband and I came here when visiting Playa Del Carmen. We took a cab there because we could not find any public transportation that went to Chaak Tun. It was not a very expensive cab ride and only took about 15 minutes. It cost about $30 USD to do the tour per person. Water shoes, life vests (if wanted), a waterproof flashlight, wet suits( if wanted, I recommend this because after 2 hours in the water it got very cold), and helmets (if wanted) were provided in addition to the tour. I also recommend bringing cash because you are in the middle of the jungle and the WiFi is not strong with the credit card machine. Our tour guide, Abel, was incredible. He did the tour both in Spanish and English. He was informative, funny, and showed us such a good tour. You get to explore 2 different caves while on this tour and you learn a bit about Mayan culture. The caves are filled with stalactites and stalagmites and it makes you feel like you are in the depths of the earth. The flashlights allow you to see in the dark caves as well as into the depths under water which can be hundreds of feet deep! In the second cave, you get to sit in a shallow portion and rub the sand on your skin, like the Mayans did to look younger. Abel told us that the sheen on oil we were seeing on the water was from people wearing sunscreen in the water, which he explained was very bad for the environment. So I recommend refraining from wearing it. You're under ground so you won't need it. This was such an unbelievable, cool site. It's hard to put into words what it was like. You should just go experience it for yourself! I only wish we could have gotten a little more Mayan history with the tour.

a-m-a-z-i-n-g-!-!-!. This place is like nothing I had seen before. Getting there from Playa del Carmen was easy and it took little time. We took our tour in Spanish because the group was smaller than the one in English. They provided wetsuits, masks and flashlights. Freddy, our tour guide was extremely good. I was very scare at the beginning. I went there with my husband and my 2 sons, ages 10 and 6. Freddy told me to be calm, and he assured me this place was very safe for all of us. At the end of our tour, I couldn't be happier I made it. This place is like out of a movie. Freddy gave us a ton of great information about this amazing cenote. We never felt unsafe there, and we really had fun appreciating the wonders that nature put in this place. The surroundings are clean and they make emphasis in keeping it as natural as it can be. No big constructions, just a place to get your equipment, restrooms, and the jungle. Something you will appreciate is that they have a photographer on site. Our photographer was Federica and she got very nice shots from our tour. At the end, you are able to get your pictures cd for only $40 (good deal if I compare with a $30 picture I got at the dolphin thing at Wet-n-Wild in Cancun 4 years ago) the pictures have a decent resolution and it is a great option if you don't have a waterproof camera with you. Again, this place is a must if you visit this area. Freddy and Federica were great.

WOOOW!!!!. After spending all night on our flight to Cancun this was one of our first stops. Being a Saturday (August 8) at around 2pm the place was not busy which was great. We took the tour with Abel and he could not have done anymore to make our experience better! Abel was sure to make everyone comfortable and not only explained things about the cenote but also talked briefly about the Mayan culture, which happened to be beneficial in the long run. Also, some professional pictures where taken which we didn't think we would buy but was actually a great purchase because you not only get great pictures of your family or friends (can I hear Christmas cards) but they also had some amazing extra pictures of the cenote that only a pro could take! This definitely was one of the best stops we made! Don't forget when you go to ask for Abel!!! He will make the whole experience that much more unforgettable!!!

Absolutamente Maravilhoso. This cenote is incredible & a little intimidating at the same time. Almost surreal, it feels like a movie set? The water so clear, clean & fresh (not too cold) my skin felt very soft afterward. Our guide Abel really took his time w/us answering questions, he's extremely knowledgable & funny too. My 13 year old loved this excursion & wants to return next week.

Maravellous. Out of the world. Recommendation is to go when there are few people. A must see, must do in your life. Guides are great and make sure to get the photos by pro photographer.Outstanding and highly recommended and economical by going directly there and going in.

Great activity- strongly recommend. . My friend and I decided to visit Cenote Chaak Tun (Wednesday 5 August) after having read previous reviews on Trip Advisor and weren't disappointed. We were extremely lucky in the sense that we had only 2 others in our group and so were taken into some smaller spaces that we might not have been able to experience in a bigger group. I have a fear of open water and fish, and my friend isn't great in small spaces but we were made to fee at ease the whole time, and looked after very well by Abel who was fab. There's so much to see, and with so many stalactites and stalagmites to dodge- there wasn't any time to worry about the fish (which were very few and down at the bottom of the cave) after too long! While life jackets are advised, my friend and I are comfortable enough swimmers and so didn't need to take it- which helped when navigating the small spaces! But if you're not great or tire easily, I'd definitely advise taking one. We got a taxi from the bus station for 150 pesos but unfortunately he didn't come back for us as promised. The man at the desk however was very friendly and helpful, and called us a taxi- which cost us 200 pesos this time. We were just glad to get back so didn't bother contesting the price!Such a fab experience, definitely a must. If I went back, I'd take goggles as opposed to the snorkel mask- just a personal preference as I like to breathe out of my nose when underwater. Watch the bats- there are loads, but they're harmless and really fun to watch!

Worth a few hours, particularly if you need a break from the heat/sun!. I did a lot of research before my boyfriend and I (both in our mid-30s) arrived in Playa and I read about this cenote and planned to go. We ended up not visiting it until our last day of an 8 day trip, but we were very glad we did. This and our whale shark tour were the highlights of our vacation. It was particularly well-timed for us because my boyfriend was really done with all of the heat and sun of our late-July trip and wasn't up for another full day in the sun.We scouted it out a few days earlier when we had a rental car and decided to just take a taxi back on another day, from our hotel (The Royal, right on Avenida Quinta). We were quoted 200 pesos each direction. I probably could have talked it down a bit but didn't feel like it. When we got to the cenote, which as many say is just 15-20 mins from downtown Playa at the end of Benito Juarez (good thing to know because a lot of locals are still unaware of this cenote, including taxi drivers), I asked if he would return or stay. He said 500 pesos total and he would just wait for us, so that's what we did.I'm not sure what a few other reviews are saying about not needing a guide, but yes, this is a guided cenote only. And it is 360 pesos per person, including any equipment you may want. We only used water shoes, masks, and a flashlight. The water was refreshingly cold to us, but there was a child (about 9 yrs old) in another group and I think one of the adults, that were very cold and ended up stopping early because of it. We did not use life-jackets even though the guy at the front desk said they were required in the first cavern. Our guide asked us if we were good swimmers and when we said yes, he gave us the option. I do not recommend going without a life jacket unless you are comfortable treading water for about 30-40 minutes with few breaks. You can't really SWIM so really think about whether you want to tread water. I was fine but it did definitely get tiring. I just figured it was good exercise since I hadn't gotten any on my trip!I was kicking myself for not bringing a waterproof camera. No, you can not bring anything that can't get wet so if you don't have your own, the only option is the $20 for the CD they make you, that only has about 10-15 pictures of you and then a whole bunch of filler stock pictures of the caverns and animals. There was one really nice picture of us so $20 was worth it to me.INTERESTING FEEDBACK:We were originally told we would join a group of two families and there would be one guide with 9 guests (they limit the groups at 12). Then we were suddenly told that a different guide was going to take just the two of us. This sounded great to us, but it turns out, he was brand new (only worked 4 days there) and didn't know ANYTHING about the cavern, rocks, geology, or even which areas of the cavern we could go to. He tried really hard and was very nice, and in some ways, I wouldn't trade it for the alternate experience because it was very quiet and peaceful at times with just the three of us, but that is definitely not the typical experience. When we overlapped with the original group we were added to, we listened to their guide for about 10 minutes and found out that he is EXTREMELY knowledgeable. So, just be aware that if you want to learn about the cavern, make sure to ask for a knowledgeable guide. I have a fair amount of knowledge about cave formation and rock formation so I was actually teaching our guide things at times I think.Sorry for the long review but I felt I had some good info and I know that is what I am always looking for! We went on a Saturday around 12:30 at the end of July and didn't have to wait at all. I really recommend going if you have some time and just want a few hours of something different.

Beautiful Cenote Close to Playa!. This is a wonderful cenote for first time visitors to Playa who are unfamiliar with cenotes and are curious about this unusual geologic feature. The cenote is a short ride from Playa, the guides are knowledgeable and friendly and the site is beautiful. We took a student group, and everyone loved it. Recommended.

Stunning visit. Awesome cenote in Riviera Maya. The guide is outstanding and explains with passion all the history and process of stalagmite generation and Maya’s culture. You have the choice between a more informative, historical or adventurous tour. Ask for a more adventurous tour and you’ll experience funny and unbelievable stuff down the water. The free time at the end let you explore on your own the cenote. Come early around 9am and you’ll be the only one, having a full cenote just for you. The cenote is so natural and wild. As a matter of fact, bats and sacred birds are living altogether. Finally, the price is super reasonable everything included compare to other cenotes.

Nice cenote, but tour required for tourists.. This was a nice experience. Great cenote very close to downtown Playa and it is not well known. Most folks visiting when we were there were locals. The tour itself is nice and the cenote is very refreshing. We had a great time and the guide was excellent. So why the 2 stars? For being duped into paying for a tour. I've read several reviews (including some from earlier this year) indicating you pay an entrance fee and can rent gear, but are not required to purchase the tour. The place was fairly empty when we went and it was on a Sunday. The guy at the entrance said a tour was required and it was this way since at least 4 years back. I made the mistake of saying we were visiting from LA. I finally agreed after haggling the price down to $250 from $360 pesos per person. I wasn't going to put a damper on our day and let the family down. The price is not bad, but considering a family of 8, it adds up. Especially when you're going in expecting to pay far less, and paying for a couple of taxis to and fro. To top it off, all other groups of people (with the exception of another tourist group) we ran into roaming the grounds were on their own. I didn't bother to bring it up to the guy in charge as my family was having fun.Again, this is a nice cenote. Just be prepared to pay $16-23 USD per person. Other cenotes along Hwy 307 are about $4-6 USD. I always pay in pesos when in Mexico. The estimates are at the going conversion of about 15.5 to 1 USD. You obviously pay more if paying in USD.

Good visit . Loved this Cenote. We got a taxi from Playa it was only 15-20minutes away. Able was a fantastic guide! I would recommend doing this over a tour as you don't have to stay there for lunch you can just get a taxi back to playa as well as not being too expensive

Muy interesante. We took a taxi and arranged a return from 70 diagonal for 200 pesos. We knew the price beforehand (360 pesos) and though expensive, it was a fantastic experience. Something we would not be able to rival in England for 20 pounds. Our guide was Abel, as Spanish speakers we joined a Spanish group for the first half of the tour and were left to our own devices for the second part, swimming with one other family. Abel was very patient and kind and gave lots of reassurance to my girlfriend who is not an experienced swimmer. Though photos we purchased look good however I should have haggled over the price. I'd definitely reccommend this, it lasts at least 90 minutes and if you haven't had the opportunity to swim in a cave with bats and catfish then go for it. If you've been to similar cenotes already then maybe give it a miss.

great cenote if your stay is near playa del carmen. I was not willing to go far from playa so this is best bet. I enjoyed this cenote even though I am not swimmer. I dint like our guide and they charge almost same for guests who do not want to get wet..my wife didnt get into water and I paid 350 pesos for her.It is not going to that interesting if you do not dive into water.

Stalactites, Stalagmites and Bats (Chaaktun Cenote). This was a fantastic experience. We took a taxi from Playa del Carmen - Avenida Juarez ( a few blocks up from bus station). The price was $150MX to the Cenote and took 10 minutes. I asked the driver to come back for us (volver) in 2.5 hours. He charged the same price to get back to town. He was waiting for us at the front desk after our visit. He was a very affable chap. I would not recommend walking it. Cycling would be a possibility with plenty of water.The actual tour costs $360MX per person. This includes a guide, waterproof torch, use of life jacket, helmet, snorkel/mask, water shoes and wetsuit. There are toilets, changing area and locker with padlock (no cost) The water is cold but not, in my opinion, too cold for a suit. We took our own dive shoes and snorkel/mask. You get used to the template after a couple minutes.Our guide's name was Felix and he was outstanding. He was friendly, knowledgeable and caring. First of all, he let my wife and I have some time in a cave to get used to the water and our surroundings. It was brilliant. There were a few little catfish roaming around our feet and one or two bats seeking out lunch with their sonar skills. This cave was big enough to stand up and swim (2/3 metres water depth and 10 metres long/3 metres wide).oFelix returned to take us on our Indiana Jones-esque adventure. He explained to us about the Mayan traditions and the importance of nature and the cenotes to their culture.He then led us to the main cave and showed us all his favourite nooks and crannies. The information about the geology of the cenote was excellent. He justified everything with technical knowledge of minerals.<It takes 100 years for a stalactite to 'grow' 2cm.>I asked a few questions - Felix had an answer for them all.Highlights were the beauty below the water and the sound of the bats flying past your head, forming a miniature gust of wind.I'd recommend taking a waterproof camera. We have read on this that it is busy in the morning. We went on a Monday (beginning of August) arriving at 1130am and we had the place to ourselves, with our own amazing guide.Any questions and I'll happily reply.

Cenote and then Tulum - snorkel shop. Booked a tour with Graham at the Snorkel Shop and asked if he could also include a trip to Tulum few days before tour. Cenote is superb with three different areas to visit. Nice that it is all undergound so makes it eary sometimes but beautifull. Alex our guide was very knowledegable and our driver Lalo made a superb guide aswell on our way to Tulum. Very knowlegable and looked after us throughout the 7 hours. We then finished the day having a late lunch which he recommended. Great day.

Awesome experience!. We went to Chaak Tun in July of 2015. We had visited one small cenote on our trip and wanted to visit more. We ended up just renting our own car and driving to Chaak Tun. It was a little hard to find, only because the area didn't seem to have many street signs. We found Juarez Ave and followed it inland. We were hesitant because we didn't know how far to go or if we were on the right path. Then we saw the entrance sign on the side of the road and were very excited to have found it. It actually wasn't hard to find, we just had to trust or directions. When we arrived we found out that we had to do a guided tour, but that was fine because there was a friendly staff member ready to take us once we got suited up. We went on the 2 hour tour and had a great time. The cenotes are really cool and they give you a bunch of great information about the rock formations and the history of the Mayans. Although it was a guided tour they showed you an area and then gave you free time to explore on your own before moving on to the next spot. They also give you a flashlight so you can see, since many of the areas are dark. It was a great tour and I would highly recommend it. It was nice to visit a place that wasn't super crowded with tour buses and large groups. We went in the afternoon so I think all of their big tours had ended for the day. I do suggest getting a wetsuit if you get cold at all. We did not get them and we were ok, but by the end of the tour you have been in the water for a long time in dark caves, so needless to say it did get a little chilly and we might have been more comfortable if we ad gotten the wetsuits.
Cold but well worth a dip.. Actually took part in this swim. Beautiful natural water & its surroundings were amazing. Nature at its best.
A must!!!!!,,😊. Excellent place to visit,,, once in a lifetime, a big must thanks to Tatianna, she was fantastic guide, ,the water was so clear ,the caves ar out of this world fantastic, ,,
A great experience!. The water was crystal clear and the setting and view upwards magical! Though my wife found the tiny fish slightly offputting.

Awesome Experience!. My husband and I booked and centote and cave exploring trip through The Snorkel Shop, and this is where we visited. The water was super refreshing and cenote is one of a kind. If you don't have a flashlight, it will be near impossible to explore Chaak Tun. It can get pretty narrow and deep in parts as well. I would definitely visit again!

Had a wonderful time!. Everything about this experience was just wonderful. Felix was our guide and he was just amazing. He was funny and very knowledgeable about the cenote and the Mayan culture. The water was very cold but the wetsuit helps you out a lot. My girlfriend and I don't know how to swim but everything was doable. We weren't afraid to do anything. The cenote itself was beautiful. Everything about this place was great!

Once in a lifetime experience!. You have to check out the Cenote Chaak Tun! My husband and I rented a car and drove to this excursion on our own. We found it on the map and it led us right there. We did not have a reservation at all and they were very accommodating because we started our tour within 15 minutes of our arrival. Felix was our tour guide and made me feel very comfortable as I could not swim at all! He explained and went through all of the history and cool things about this cenote. He also was able to manage the tour in both speaking spanish and english for the other travelers. The tour was only supposed to be 2 hours and it went into 3 hours because Felix went above and beyond to show my husband more cool entries to this Cenote. This was an absolute amazing experience and you must see it! It's affordable and worth the trip to Mexico.

Great Rock Formations - Good For A First Cenote Dive Experience. This is one of several cenotes in the area and one I recommend for less experienced cenote divers. Entry to and exit from the dive are easy with the steps provided, but prepare to carry your gear a distance to get to the steps. There is very little wildlife to see, but the rock formations are impressive. Bring your flashlight!

Cenote was awesome!!. What a experience the water was cool but the caves was amazing! Oh our guide was awesome Felix was terrific he explained everything very well. He also make sure u are safe and safety is his concern. Please do semi extreme it was awesome dong go regular boring loll. Have fun and enjoy the caves and culture
So beautiful!!. Super clear water and not crowded with too many people. Bring snorkel gear from condo or you have to rent it.
Do not miss this in Cancun. Do not miss this adventure. Cave exploration at its best, the guides take amazing care of you and there is so much to see.

what an experience. Come prepared with mosquito repellant as they are everywhere. But once in the cave and swimming you are transported to another world, the water was so fresh and clear with actual fish swimming. We will never forget the experiences.

Mayan Chaak Tun Cenote. Beautiful Historic place, the Indians (local People) were freindly and helpful. The guide was excellent well informed on local history and made the trip well worth it and a learning expierence. His English was great. Incredible sights, I highly recomend this Excursion.

AWESOME!!. I had a great time in this cenote. There were only three of us and Abel was our guide. He spoke great English and was very informative. He explained stalagmite formation and gave us a little history on Mayan culture. There's also a photographer that takes pictures which you can purchase. Only 10 min by cab from 5th avenue. Definitely a must see!!

Incredible!!!!. Since there were only two of us on the tour, we got special attention. Our guide was great, his English was perfect. We got to swim and snorkle, the water was cool and refreshing. The things we learned were incredible.

Great cheap excursion. Our tour guide was very mindful that many people in our group couldn't swim so he kept things PG. We swam through two caves that were connected. Saw some bats, catfish and a dead arachnid of some kind. Got to hold a stalactite.

Awesome!!!!. Picked this Cenote and Caves because it was a short and easy drive from central Playa. Felix our guide was absolutely the best and the caves and cenotes were cool and refreshing. Well worth the 360 pesos per adult.

Great Excursion. After our swim at Akumel, we went to this Cenote for a swim. It was beautiful and the water was very cold, which was very refreshing. A wonderful way to finish our excursions for the day!! Our guide Juan was great! The underground cave was fascinating and very beautiful. Our whole group loved the experience. We highly recommend this trip!

Wow!. Breath-taking site! Even if you don't swim in it, the place itself is very captivating! Beautiful trip! Saw this after Chichen Itza with a tour from Viator, so any one can make this necessary double trip! Get a feel of Mayan History!
Amazing. Amazing, This is so beautiful and the water is very cold for a swim, but you must swim I had to as I could not go and not swim in the Cenote.

Propose! Romantic place, do not miss it!. Day or night; you will love their food, their service and the place is incredible; no words to describe it. If you want to propose in Playa del Carmen, do it in this place!

It was okay….. The cenotes are beautiful! We went as a tour group but if I ever went again it would be on our own. Our guide talked too much and handed out several questionnaires. The mosquitos were bad as we had to stop and listen to the tour guide. Worth seeing but not a bucket list item if you know what I mean.

Not to be missed gem !. If you are interested in a (not yet overcrowded and commercially exploited) authentic cenote in the region of playa del carmen, you really must see this. We booked this excursion online (only a 7 miles ride from PDC), through Viator - much cheaper than TUI - and had a perfect excursion. In a small group.Our guide Felix, a native Maya, was really outstanding : very professional, extrememy informative and most helpful for al the participants of our group. Especially for my wife who was really afraid before. ..Felix had the skills to make her very comfortable. Super !A never to forget experience and perfectly organized.Also a plus for the photographer who made superbe photos for a very reasonabel price.All in one : a very deserved 10/10 !

Great cenote\cave!. Our family had a great time at this underground cenote. The people there give you lifejackets,snorkel gear,underwater flashlights, wetsuits, water shoes, and a locker included in your admission( 360 pesos for adults, and 250 for kids). Our guide was Abel. He was very friendly and helpful. We strongly recommend wetsuits, as the water is around 60 degrees. They take your photo at various locations and you can buy them if you want at the end. Their photographer is very good. From Playacar, the 20 minute drive was 350 pesos one way.

Go there right now. So we rode cruiser bikes there from downtown Playa del Carmen. Lovely protected bike path up Av. Juarez, past a shantytown area and then on the right. $30 gets you a guided tour, which is the only option, water shoes, wetsuit, snorkel mask, flashlight. Thee ceynote is INSANE. Granted it was my first one, but it's huge and beautiful with lots of varied formations, bats, super clear waters. Abel, our extremely kind and competent guide easily went bilingual and offered all kinds of opportunities to see extra sections accessible underwater.magical. Go now (btw stop at Don Tacote for a snack on the way back.

Great attraction. For an excellent and affordable adventure visit the Chaak Tun Cenote. We stayed in the Playacar area and decided to take a 15 minute taxi ride (250 pesos each way) to the this Cenote. We had previously read the reviews and decided to give it a try. The admission is $30 pp and included a guided tours and snorkel equipment. Free lockers are available to store personal effects. By arranging our own transportation we saved over $200 from a similar tour group excursion. When our taxi dropped us off, we made arrangements for him to return to pick us up.  During our 2 1/2 hour stay, we visited 2 underground water filled caves (Cenotes). The water temperature is 62-64 degrees but it very refreshing and no one felt cold. The site also had some local wildlife including monkey's and several bird species. Our tour guide Jorge was very informative as well as amusing. A photographer took photos of our group along the way and a personalized CD was available for sale after the tour. This tour was informative and affordable and I highly recommend it.
Update. 10 minutes ride in taxi from playa. The rates are 360 pesos pp for a two hour guided tour. Unfortunately, we couldnt visit because of an issue with the card machine ...Deceiving.

money is more important here. went with family to have a good time but we had a awful time , if you want to have a relax time watching this kind of cenote go to another cenote,here everything is timing,bad service and its a very expensive place.

Chaak Tun was a great experience with Abel as our guide!!!. I was apprehensive about the Cavernas Y Cenotes. But from the moment I arrived until the time me and my wife left the Cenotes was a great experience. The entire tour took about 2 hours, but in return we got a good history lesson of the local area. Abel our tour guide made the entire experience with the Cenotes comfortable and memorable. Abel was very accommodating, knowledgeable and friendly guide. We stayed at a resort in Playa del Carmen and caught a taxi to the caves. I would recommend this attraction for friends and family.Mel

Perfect day activity from Cozumel or PDC. If you are in Cozumel and looking for a short but moderately challenging adventure, this Cenote trip is perfect. Bad weather in Cozumel sent my nephew and I onto the Ferry ($10 each way per person) in Cozumel to Playa Del Carmen (45 minutes) at 9 AM, arrived PDC at 945AM. We tracked down a tour guide service within a block of the ferry landing. He arranged for taxi service to and from Chaak Tun, tickets for two, and wetsuits and mask and flashlight, all for $100 US or 1500 pesos. The cab drive was less than 15 minutes. Chaak Tun does not present itself well as you approach and enter the site. In fact, it was pretty "rural". But the basics were there and we were well received, and were handed a flashlight, shoes, googles, and a wetsuit. 5 minutes to change and place belongings in a keyed locker and we were set. Just one other couple was with us so with guide there were only five in the group. Before we entered the water, we were given a life jacket to wear. I don't want to spoil anything, but suffice to say, the 2 hour experience was pretty cool. Treading water through caverns, viewing awesome and beautiful structures, seemingly endless expanses of clear water beneath us, all was just refreshing. On a difficulty scale of 1 to 10 for modestly active people, it's about 5 maybe 6. On a cool scale, it's about a 8.5 maybe 9. The guide, Ricardo was passionate, entertaining, and very safe. Novices will find this awesome, skilled divers will be well entertained. The trip ended after about 2 hours, and the same cab driver who brought us was waiting for us. We were back at the Ferry dock by 12:30, easily in time for a relaxing lunch and then the 2PM ferry return to Cozumel. In summary, leave Cozumel on Ferry at 9AM, be back in Cozumel at 3PM. In between, a remarkable experience and relatively high value for the dollar. Would definitely recommend for couples or families with active and adventurous kids.

Chaak Tun is the bomb!. We read reviews on TripAdvisor and we're not disappointed. Thank you fellow reviewers. We took a taxi for our large group of 10 and were warmly greeted by Ricardo. He explained the tour and equipment and prices. $30US for adults and $20US for kids. This included wetsuits, water shoes, life vests, masks and underwater lights. Hard hats were also included but optional. There is a dressing area and lockers are provided. We toured several cenotes with amazing caverns. It was like something from an Indiana Jones movie. It was very clean and Ricardo explained the formations, the minerals present, as well as the bats a a birds and spiders present in these caves. He also gave information about the Mayan culture and history including the rituals of cleansing themselves and their early sauna! He didn't overtalk like some guides and was very helpful with the younger kids in our group. A photographer is present to capture your adventure and we purchased a CD with pictures from our tour and included are great pictures of the cenotes and jungle area.

cenote chaak tun/with felix!. my wife and i walked to 30th and juarez, and could not find the tour via the map on website, so we took a taxi to cenote chaack tun on our own. (150 pesos one way) 720 pesos for two, and had mr. felix for a tour guide. he took the both of us on the best tour we have had(traveling all over the caribe) felix is so passionate about his culture and makes an impression on you that will last for sometime to come. he is a great tour guide, and a better man! thanks for one amazing day felix!! bueno fortuna

Great Cenote in Playa Del Catmen. If you happen to be in PDC for a couple of days, I highly recommend going to Chaak Tun Cenote. The entrance fee is 360 Pesos, a little bit expensive but worth it and you'll get the equipment you need to swim in there (mask, shoes, life jacket, ...). Our guide was Abel, his english is really good. To get there from central playa, a taxi would cost no more than 80 Pesos, remember to bargain since you might get charged more. On the way back you can even catch a collectivo for 20 Pesos! Have fun.

A true Gem!. Andy is the best! He is lively and funny, and very informative. This is a great day! We went to 2 separate areas of this Cenote, and the views were incredible. The water was 62-64 degrees, but honestly, once you got in, you get used to it very quickly. And the place is a true beauty. At the end, there is a nice authentic Mexican lunch of mini chicken softshell tacos, Tamales, beans, rice, sauces, black bean sauce, etc. Excellent day! One of the best tours we have been on. Lockers, snorkel items, vests included.

Hidden Gem!!. This is by-far a MUST SEE! It is so hidden, you can miss it if you don't pay close attention. The price is very reasonable, about $30 usd and it includes the life jacket, swimming shoes (bring your OWN!) and hard hat (to enter the caves). This is true beauty, nothing man-made. Be sure to take an underwater camera!

Absolutely beautiful. Combined this with your visit to the Coba Mayan Village and ruins because after the heat there and excursion of climbing the Mayan Pyramid the swim in this Cenote (underground pool in a cave) is awesome! It's beautiful too with the lighting. Jump off the lower driving platform, it's exhilarating! I suggest you don't jump of the higher one though.
Wonderful Place . It was a very cool place with a lot to see. Abel is a very good guide kind and he took the time to explain us everything and never press us. I really recommended this place.

Gorgeous. We came here on a trip to chitchen itza and have to say it was the best part of the whole day :) totally amazing to swim in a cave with the fish and birds flying above you :) exhilarating experience :))) highly recommend

Knowledgeable guide, great time!. I came to this cenote with the idea that I was going for a short swim, but what I got was a lot more. My tour guide, Felix, was very knowledgeable of the Mayan culture and gave a lot of interesting background information that I did not previously know. He took me through an underground complex and explained a lot along the way. I was given a flash light and had the opportunity to go underwater to see some of the caves which could ordinarily not be seen. I definitely got my moneys worth and had a great time!

Great experience. Awesome guided tour of the cenotes and caves. Felix was a great guide who made the experience very enjoyable, and looked after my wife who is not a confident swimmer, as well as pushing me to try new things as I am a good swimmer. Beautiful natural underground caverns with stalactites and stalagmites. Must see, highly recommended!

Top activity. First the prices. Taxi from The Reef Coco Beach Resort to cenote is 250 peso one way. Entrance 360 peso per person. We had a great guide named Abel. He was very friendly and knew what he did. Its a great experience to visit this cenote. Its not so crouwded with tourists so that made it even beter because its like you are alone in the cave! When your there... Ask for Abel to be your guide! 5stars!

Adventurous Outing. My husband and I had a great time exploring Chaak Tun. We decided to go last minute as Rio Secreto was too expensive for us. We are so glad we made that choice! Chaak Tun was an affordable and fun outing. We drove there from Playa del Carmen (10-15 minutes) around 1 in the afternoon and there were very few other tourists there. I believe it was about $30 US per person which included life jackets, goggles, flashlights, water shoes, and wet suit. We chose not to wear the wetsuits and while the water was cold getting in, it really was find after a minute. Abel was our guide and he was fantastic. We went into the caves with him and one other couple. We liked his style because he offered us choices about what we wanted to do, some options more adventurous than others. We peered under the water into deep and seemingly never ending caves, exfoliated with fine sand from the cave floor, and even turned off all our lights at one point to experience total darkness. Unless you are a champion swimmer (and maybe a hotshot) I would wear a life jacket, as most of the time you cannot touch the bottom. I should add that I did this tour 4 months pregnant, and despite having to decline the option to crawl through a small space to traverse caves, I was totally fine during the tour. Nothing too strenuous, however if you are afraid of darkness or tight spaces you will likely wish you never got in the water. I definitely recommend this trip to those visiting the area, particularly if you need an afternoon out of the sun. We purchased the picture CD for $20 US afterwards just for fun since we could not bring our camera into the water with us. Hopefully you will have Able as a guide. He was awesome.
So beautiful. I have never seen such clear water. You can imagine the Mayans gathering water from here. Beautiful.

Nice cenote. Got to the cenote area early to avoid the crowd. My guide was from Diversity Diving in Playa Del Carmen. She cave dove in her spare time. Very good diver, as I am a cavern diver myself. When we did our surface interval, others were in the cenote. Then when we dove again they were out. If you have dove caves or caverns, cenotes may not be worth your time. I enjoy all sorts of caves, caverns, cenotes, so it was interesting to me.

Worth It. I've never been to a cenote, but this one was fantastic. Our guide was Abel, and he was incredibly welcoming and very helpful with my wife (slightly scared at first). The place is not a disneyland by any means and is far more authentic. The formations and cave exploring was amazing (watch your head). There are 2 caves, and you get to swim in both of them (they are both different and very cool at the same time). Tour time is about 2 hours. When we went there it was 720 pesos for 2 people (included wetsuit, goggles, flashlight, and water shoes). Pro-tip, go in the afternoon. We went at 1:30 and had 3 other people with us (other tours at the time looked like they were just couples). Abel was awesome, explained everything, and showed us all the hidden nooks and 'special' spots of the cave. It was well worth it. The guides work on tips only, so help them out... they all speak spanish, and english very well. Additionally, if you don't have a waterproof camera, their is a photographer that takes your photos at certain spots. They sell the CD to you for like $30 I think. We took a taxi from our hotel for like $50 USD + tip and he returned in 2 hours to bring us back to the city. There is no taxi service, as this place is in the middle of nowhere. I wouldn't recommend attempting to walk/bike here from the city either. All in all, it was worth it. It's not a resort cenote like some of the other commercialized ones, and it's a more personal and authentic cenote. The water is incredibly refreshing. If you're a good swimmer they will let you go in without a life jacket. The 'hardest' part of the tour is that if you want to see some cool stuff, you have to cross under a wall that is about 1-2 meters wide. Probably takes about 2-3 seconds under water. Kids could do it just fine.If you're looking to kill a few hours in the afternoon after getting sunburned at the beach, highly recommended.

ammazing place. back to the hold time those Cenotes ( cave water system)have been created many many years ago when the meteorite hit the earth near by this area,,, it s a fantastic cave were you can enjoy swimming and diving just in the middle of the jungle,,,, a must to be done when in Playa Del Carmen area

An adventure not to be missed.. This was my first visit to a cenote and this is a closed cenote that means that you travel entirely underground. The company provides wetsuits, goggles, life vests, and flashlights. Our guide was Felix who is very knowledgable about the science of caves and the history of the Mayan culture. We had an older individual with a knee problem and Felix was so helpful, patient and professional in helping to negotiate the obstacles that he faced. We were a group of 10 rangeing from age 17 to 68 and we ALL had a blast. You will see wonderful sights of stalactites, bats and even very large spiders that make there homes in these caverns. Photos of your group are taken even when you're unaware and you have the option of buying a CD of the trip. I highly recommend you enjoy this adventure which is reasonably priced.
Again amazing. The history and beautiful thing to see, the amazing clear waters and how lovely it is to see how well the denotes are cared for.

Great experience with Ricardo. With all the cenote choice in the PDC area, we were not sure which to choose. If you are staying in PDC, you could not ask for a better or more-convenient cenote to visit. We had a rental car, so it was super easy. We just got on Juarez and drove until we found it. Easy parking. We had our own short wetsuits, aqua socks, snorkels, and mask, but they provided all that. Ricardo was our private guide, and he was outstanding. But I am guessing all people here are great. It just seems to be a very-well run place. "Paparazi" photographed our entire experience, and we gladly bought the DVD. This tour had it all. We highly recommend it.

Unique experience if you haven't been to Cenote. There are so many cenotes on the Yucatan peninsula, it's hard to say whether any are more outstanding, but the visit to Chaak-Tun was absolutely memorable. They do not advertise widely, so finding this one was a little challenging, but if you look on google maps you'll find it on the road to the west of Playa del Carmen. The group we toured the caves with was very small, and the guide was very personable. We took pictures in the caves, but let the assistant photo us in the water, which we purchased on a dvd after the tour. Made it most memorable.

Abel is the bomb!. Amazing swimming experience. Abel gauged our swimming ability and did not require us to wear life jackets. We actually got the chance to dive under water to different compartments in the cenote. Not far, but enough to make you a little nervous. The water was cool, but very comfortable in the wet suits. Watch your head when surfacing, those are some sharp stalactites.

Unbelivable experience. Based on TripAdvisor reviews our family visited the Cenotes. What a great experience! Our guide, Ricardo, was kind and knowledgeable and led us around helping those who need it and also making it adventurous for those who were up for it. He explained some Mayan history and traditions and took us on a beautiful tour. It was so much fun! The water was beautiful and refreshing. Their equipment was first-class. Don’t miss this experience and ask for Ricardo to be sure your trip is as fantastic as ours was!

Great place to visit. My husband and I were lucky to come at a time when we got our own tour guide and there were no other people in our group! It was truly surreal exploring the underwater caves with no one else there...stepping down a ladder into the dark waters with bats flying above your head was pretty cool. Our tour guide was ok... he either talked too much about unnecessary things, or left us totally alone (in the last cave), which was a bit weird!

Discovered a Little piece of treasure. We just got back from Chaak Tun and it was amazing. Weve never been to any other cenotes so nothing to compare but would def recommend this gem to anyone. Ricardo was our guide and was fabulous! Definitely a must do.

Up and coming. This attraction is newer in its operation but the people working to make it something are really eager for you to have a good experience visiting the caverns and cenotes that is such an integral part of their world and culture. They have a modicum of equipment and facilities at this time but since it is new and up-and-coming it wasn't as though we had to wait for the group in front of us to finish their tour before we would have wetsuits and masks. I would, if I did it again, probably bring my own mask and wet suit (since I am a diver and own these pieces of equipment) but most people do not so its good that they are working to provide these items especially because you are going to submerge yourself in water that catches your breath at first but then is quite a comfortable temperature with a wet suit. And you are going to want a mask so as to really enjoy viewing all there is to see under the surface. The tour guide was knowledgeable and provided a lot of interesting info on the culture of the Mayan people and how the Cenotes played a part in that culture. He indicated that the Cenotes were integral to their spiritual practice and I could definitely see that and really take that into my own spiritual sense. The price was right, it wasn't too long (I could have stayed a lot longer but this is one of the smaller sites so I will just have to go back and do more exploring) and the people were friendly and helpful. What more can you ask for on vacation right?

Well worth the cab-ride from Playa!!. First off, this is not quite as cool as Rio Secreto, but then again, it's less than half the price and more conveniently located, an $8 or $10 cab ride from the beach at Playa. And it takes a bit less time. So if you want to kill two hours some afternoon in Playa, let's say it's a rainy day, Chaak Tun is a GREAT idea. And it's very cool, particularly if you HAVEN'T done Rio Secreto, and ridiculously cool if it's your first cenote swim/snorkel. It is decidedly bigger and more interesting than the ones outside Valladolid, and Gran Cenote down near Tulum.The guides are excellent, quite knowledgeable, with a very good command of English. My girlfriend's flashlight burnt out, and our guide found us all a nice place to stand, then swam his butt off and ran his butt off to go get her a replacement, and was back about 3 and 1/2 minutes later. He also allowed another guest's daughter, who was an excellent swimmer, to take the tour without a lifejacket and explore several caverns with him that were only accessible via submerged entries (and hence impossible to visit in a lifejacket).The fee includes a shortie (yeah, the water's a bit chilly, but not bad once you get used to it and the shortie fills with the layer of water required for insulation), a mask, snorkel, and flippers. And with the strength of the dollar, as of April 2015, it was something like $24 per person.Good fun. We were a middle-aged couple, but the younger couple with teenage kids had a blast as well, and it would work for any kid that could swim and understand instructions, let's say age 7 or 8 and up.

Very Unique Excursion. Can't say that I have ever been anywhere like this, A truly unique experience. As is the case with most cruise excursions, wish we could have stayed much longer, but so glad we went and hope to check it out again when we go back to Play del Carmen.

Perfekt. Grate Adventure. Really nice and passionate guide. We first knew about this hidden secret place through tripadvisor. If you want to experience the magic of mexicos cenotes, this is the place to visit. Karoline & ChrisNowegian

Best Cenotes tour!. We just came back from a morning of exploring the wonderful cenotes of Chaak Tun. We had seen other cenotes in the past and these are up there with the best! We were lucky enough that we had Abel as our guide; he is just an awesome guide! I'm already planning to go back this week!! Thanks to everyone of Chaak Tun for an unforgettable trip! ( ps. They also take very nice pictures!!) Alex and Linda

A highlight of our trip. After reading other reviews we settled on Chaak Tun for our Cenote swim. The others that our resort recommended were just big swimming holes that you can dive in. This one is a great experience, real cave swimming. We've been in many cave tours but never in the water before. Our guide, Abel, was very informative and helpful. He was careful with a few older people in our group, and we had no problems at all. You're given a wetsuit, water shoes, flashlight, lifejacket, and goggles. You can opt to skip the lifejacket but it does help keep you afloat so you don't have to tread water a lot. I expected the water to be a lot colder but it wasn't bad at all. I think it could easily be done without the wetsuit but it did help somewhat. Overall I'd really recommend this tour for $30 US per person. You can buy a dvd at the end for $20 or 30 with photos of your group if you want.

less known gem. went on a tour to this place. was not impressed on the way or in the waiting area, waiting for our guide.. but once the guide took us in the first cenote, I was in love.. This place has less crowd and the guide was able to host the small group intimately, the guide swam with the group and guided different water passages.. it was the best cenote that I visited this trip.. (better than some other better known ones)..The facility still has some room for improvements but the cenotes were amazing.. our guide was awesome.. Would definitely go back to this one when I am in that region

Scary Kat in a Cave! . Absolutely worth every penny! Felix was our guide and I felt like family! I'm not a good swimmer plus I'm not the most adventurous lady but I had an amazing experience and plan to do this tour again on our next visit! They provided everything you should need; suits, goggles, helmets, shoes, life vest "if needed", flashlight, & locker! I do recommend if you prefer bring your own snorkeling mouth piece as they don't provide them! Make sure you take care of Felix well ie. Tip this is how he makes his living! Also buy the photos they are worth it as well #Memories and they will make great gifts later if your into artsy personalized gifts! :) I will revisit my review to update with our photos currently traveling! ;) Thank you Felix!!!!

Cenote Chaak Tun or Chaak full of Rot. My hubby and I decided to spend our first day paddling around a cenote. Being a Sunday, we knew there wouldn't be a whole lot of action at this local cenote, Chaak Tun. This is our third visit to Playa, second cenote. This is more like a cavern. The "ceilings", if you will, of the cenote are super low in spots, so you need to be aware. If you are claustrophobic, this isn't for you. There are spots that are a bit tight, and do to the amount of bats and their guano, it can get stagnant as it did in this visit. I was ready to gag at one point from the stench. If I may be a bit graphic, it smelled like rotten gum disease or a-double-s. I have glaucoma and permanent filters in my eyes, so I have to be super protective of them. I didn't feel like I could swim comfortably in this cenote- even with goggles. I was disappointed. I enjoyed Dos Ojos cenote better, because it was a real underground "river".
