Amazing experience if a little expensive. Went with a group via taxi not expecting to have to pay for a guide - Felix was amazing though, really knowledgeable and aware of the needs of the group. Caves were amazing and although I was nervous, it ended up being a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

Awesome!. This is a must see. Be sure they don't put you with a guide that doesn't speak your language because there are so many interesting things to learn. I had Felix as a guide and he was great. You can tell he loves sharing his extensive knowledge of the cenotes (there are actually 3 in the tour.

Most amazing experience....can't believe we did it !. We were taken to Chaak Tun by a driver who we had hired for a day trip on his recommendation ..... It was absolutely incredible !!!! Abel was our guide and was a wealth of knowledge.... He made our time in the cenote so enjoyable and fun..... At first I was a little nervous going so far underground but his professionalism made me feel at ease so that I could enjoy a once in a lifetime experience. What I loved about Chaak Tun was that it was not over commercialised .... We had plans to see some other more well known cenote parks which we then cancelled as we really saw the best nature had to offer with this one..... Loved loved loved this experience...... Thank you Abel from your Aussie friends !!!!!
Totally new experience for Skandinavian people. I like this place so much. At first it was a little bit scary to go down but I was so brave and I went to swim. It was worth it.

Informative and exciting adventure, get out of the sun and into a cenote!. We went to Chaak Tun on April 20th, 2015, got there around 2pm as suggested by other reviewers. We drove there in our rental car, it was about 12 miles outside of Playa. There's a divided highway most of the way, then the road jogs where it narrows down to a two lane road. Shortly after that, you'll see some white rocks on the side of the road with "Chaak Tun" spelled out on them and then it's right there on the right. There was no one else there waiting, we did run into other groups down in the caves but it wasn't a big deal. There were nine of us but we were quicly outfitted with our shortie wetsuits, flashlights, and goggles. They had water shoes if you wanted to wear them, I wore my chacos. The goggles were a little blurry, if you have your own I would recommend bringing them. The water was cold, we definitely were glad to have the wetsuits. You can wear a PFD if you want to, you get those after you go down into the first cave.And we got Felix for our guide, he was the best! He speaks great English, has a great sense of humor, and was proud to educate us about his Mayan heritage and beliefs. We did the "adventurous" tour and most of us ducked underwater into a small cavern at one point of the tour, the ceiling is just about a foot over your head. Other than that, you are in pretty big spaces. Felix showed us how the caverns extend underwater throughout the caves by holding us down underwater (if you wanted to.) We were in there for about 2 1/2 hours total, at one point you come out and can take a bathroom break and then you go into another cave.We saw turtles, bats, fish, and Mut Mut birds. There was a photographer who was around (not in the water) and he took group pictures of us which were available for purchase at the end of the trip. We bought the disc and the pics were pretty good, not great. If you have an underwater camera, bring it.It was a great experience and I would highly recommend it.

Amazing experience. Our guide Ricardo was very knowledgeable and gave us a good insight of Mayan culture. He went the extra mile to provide us a very good experience to remember. A must if you like this kind of tour.

Worth the 360 pesos! Awesome 2 hr excursion through the caves. Abel was a great tour guide. He made things fun and spoke great english. We went around 12:30 and were the only ones, so we got a private tour. They give you everything included in the price (locker, snorkel mask, wet suit and water shoes). Credit cards accepted. You're in the water most of the time, so bring an underwater camera if you have one. Overall, my fiancé said this was one of the more unique activities she's done while traveling.

The local's cenote - great spot to fill a few hours if tours are booked. We had a lazy breakfast and decided to try and get out on a tour but found all of them booked. We were hoping to check a cenote out.So, I asked if all the tours and all of the cenotes were all truly "booked". It was about noon and I just couldn't believe there was no possible way to see a cenote that day.After asking around we found out about Chaak Tun.We were convinced by some locals that we'd need transport so we ended up paying a gringo tax of about 500 peso's to get out there. 1500 peso's total for admission and a buggy (pronounced boo gee) to get us out there.Bonus - the guys we talked to said that we were gonna get to see the real deal. The local's kinda cenote. "None of that paint on walls crap most of the tourists end up seeing". :) haha, the guys that sell tours were pretty funny at times.Absolutely worth a visit. Loved it.p.s. It's not very far outside town and if you wanted to you could easily bike out here.

Worth the trip. We had a great time checking out chaak tun. Alex our tour guide was great. A lady in our group was feeling a little uneasy about enter the cenote, but alex calmly escorted her in the water and guided her around.....she seemed to have a great time after that. The cenote are beautiful and all the gear you need is included. We pay $30 US a person. Our taxi ride from paradisus in playa del carmen was $33 each direction.... get you cabby to stay....Go, worth checking out. (Alex look out for stalagmites)

Abel the master guide of the Cenote Chaak Tun!. Wow, we had such an amazing experience swimming in the cenotes. The main reason we came to Riviera Maya for our honeymoon, to see underground rivers! The pictures do not do them justice, our tour guide ABEL was really good, he was well spoken, took us to see many extra cool spots and helped guide us easily so we didn't accidentally "bump" into any of the stalagmites and stalactites :) He was very knowledgeable of the caves and even took many pictures for me and my husband! You gotta check out these natural cenotes. One of the best we've seen! :) Enjoy and thanks Abel you are fantastico! wish we had more $ to tip you, you deserve way more!

A Gem, right in town!. Transportation and guided tour of beautiful ceynote, all gear provided, for very reasonable cost. Great for all ages, and our guide Victor spoke to us of the history of the sites and the Mayan culture. What a great day out!
Amazing must visit when in Mexico. Amazing! Swimming in cenotes was mind blowing cold when you first get in but brilliant once in Water is so clear! Definitely recommend to anyone to go !!

Great snorkeling fun close to Playa del Carmen. It was a well organized snorkeling trip into the cenote. Very dark, cool fresh water, and well led by our leader. I particularly loved the total peace and tranquility and silence when we entered the one cenote and were asked to be still and quiet for 1 minute..total darkness and silence which I haven't experienced like that. If you love to snorkel, this is a good 2 hour excursion and can drive or book a tour there.

Great Visit. Taxi driver didn't know about this place until we showed him the address. Seems to be a little known about location.Not crowded, great tour. Guide we had was great, made sure we had the right mix of snorkelling and stories about the Mayan culture. Go after 1 p.m. to avoid the crowds - can take 2+ hrs, go at your own pace. Remember to book your taxi a pickup afterwards.Entrance fee includes snorkelling gear, wet suit and Wet shoes.

Kristie matthews - Gig Harbor, Wa, USA. We took our 16 year old son here and it was Amazing - I can't believe we didn't hear more about this place !!!! Seriously a MUST on any visit to Playa Del Carmen ( short taxi ride away )Our guide was so much fun, very knowledgeable and so patient with me (I'm clostrophobic) he made me 100% comfortable and I will go back on my next trip!The caves are stunning !!! You have to see this hidden gem !!! And the price was great

Best Experiance in Playa Del Carme. We had an incredible tour to Chaak Tun last week. What a wonderful experience. I was not really sure what to expect but upon arrival the employees made us feel welcomed and that the tour was going to be worth the money. Our tour guide Felix was one of the best guides we have had on any tour of any kind. He was very knowledgeable and helpful. He gave not only a tour of the caves but a history lesson on the Mayan culture and anything we wanted to know about the Cenote. He enjoyed his job and loved sharing his special place with us. I would greatly recommend this tour and if at all possible call ahead to request Felix! You will not be disappointed. Our 14 year old daughter told us this was her highlight of the whole trip to Mexico. Better than swimming with the dolphins.

Fantastic experience. Peaceful, not crowded, very personal tour. Alex from England was a fantastic tour guide who made sure we had the right mix of snorkeling, beauty and great stories about the Mayan culture. Go after 1 p.m. to avoid the crowds!
Loved it!!!. This was a fantastic experience, great English tour guide who was very knowledgeable. We spent almost three hours exploring these Cenotes and I'll never forget it
Natural wonder. A must see! The snorkeling in the caves is awesome. I've been to Mexico several times and this by far was my favorite excursion.

Most amaizing place to snorkel in the world. sac Aktun system is about 320 meters large.you will explore part of this underground river by snorkeling.It's about 5 km walking you must take a taxi or rent a car to get there.The tour itself last 1 hours with a tour guide and the cost per person is 350 pesos mush higher than any regular cenote because this one is unique .Life jacket and snorkeling equipment will be given to you upon arrival.Amazing ..and usually very quite place.You will have an amaizing time with kids and family.I leave in Mayan riviera for 15 years and I am a Tour a guide this is the best spot to snorkeling.Just take a taxi from your hotel it's safe ,,,taxi driver wait for you for little extra fee...whorstedddd 100% ....
Three in one. What will you see? Here you will find an open cenote, closed (cave) cenote, sacred cenote. This is a Magical place.

AWESOME!. This was so much fun, and only it's short drive from the resorts. The guide starts by providing wetsuits, goggles, snorkel, hard hat, and waterproof flashlight. Then a short walk/tour through the trees, you get to meet a shaman and get his blessing before going into the cave. Once in more info on the place, you get splash around for a while, take pictures, and check out the bats. Finally, they serve a tasty buffet at a different cave.

Amazing experience!. Visiting a cenote is a MUST-DO if you are in Playa del Carmen! We visited Chaak Tun after the recommendation of one of the staff members are our hotel. We had an hour and half tour with Abel. He was an incredible guide who was very knowledgeable. It was an unforgettable experience. My only regret was not having a camera to capture the experience. However, this will not be easily forgotten.
WONDERFUL. The best one cenote along the Mayan Riviera, absolutely don't lost it, very refreshing clear waters. The best option after a day under the Caribbean sun

Do it on a Sunny Day. LIGHT RAYS ! FOSSILS ! CLARITY ! CAVES, with Bats and Spiders ! I highly recommend this Dive, it was my first Cenote dive and definitely won't be my last. We used Playa Scuba, the owner, Klaus was good Dive Master and a very unique person. It was a easy dive, as divers should always be calm and cautious, this a dive where you maybe in complete darkness at times, with near zero visability, due to salt water/fresh water in certain sections. Enjoy the Adventure, we did !Doug, 200+ dives, open water diver.

Private and exciting. My wife said she felt like she was on an episode of the bachelor. We showed up with a guide, and we were the only ones allowed in for our time slot. We entered though a hole in the ground with a tree log ladder. It was lighted inside, so we were able to enjoy the cave and the water. For this tour, you get to walk, crawl, swim, and slosh through the caves. You enter on one side of the park, and exit on the other. It is quite the experience, and i highly recommend going.

Anna Zavadskaya. I am very happy with the wonderful cave, is also worth a visit. Special thanks to instructor Felix Kastan′eva, he showed all the beauty of the caves. I WILL REMEMBER THIS FOR THE REST OF MY LIFE, IT'S AN EXCELLENT EXPERIENCE, I WANT TO SEE MORE CAVES IN MEXICO. Thank you!

Must see. Cenote was easy to get too and not very far from downtown Playa del Carmen. You will pass some stretches of land that have some squatters living on it. Apperently there is an affordable housing shortage in PdC area, and this is the only alternitive for some. The Cenote has a privet swimming hole kind of feel to it. They had changing rooms, a small snack shack and they did provide you with Hard Hats for the walk down and into the cenote. The guide from the Snorkel Shop, Alex, was very experienced and knew a lot about the area and the history of the cenotes. He did a great job of getting our group into the cold water. The anticipation of the coldness was worse than the actual temperature. I did have a surfing shirt on so that helped. I saw some other people with 1/2 scuba suits on. this would be nice for diving...but was probably to much of a pain to put on for a snorkel trip. The cave is lit along the snorkeling "path". But Alex passed out small underwater flashlights for us to share. It would have been much better if we all had our own light. When you snorkel, I find that it is best done solo to explore all the nooks and crannies. Alex knew a lot about the wildlife, marine life and insects in the cave. We used Playita Tours for your transport: eduardota55@gmail.com / Lalo.

Fun for the whole family!. Our family decided to take a cab out to these cenotes on our recent trip to Playa del Carmen, very glad we did! A few of the reviews on here mentioned getting to the cenotes later in the day to avoid crowds, we got there at 2 and there were no crowds at all. Our guide had mentioned that there were large tour busses there not long before, so going later does appear to be the trick. Our guide, Alex, was excellent, very knowledgeable of the area and the cenotes. We learned more about the Mayan culture from him than we did from our guide in Tulum! We also had our 2 young children with us (4 & 7) and were concerned this activity might not be age appropriate. It was great for young children, both kids loved it and were quite entertained by all the bats! One word of advice, while they do provide all the equipment (wet suits, shoes, etc) for adults, they did not have wet suits nor shoes for the kids. Turned out to be fine, the waters weren't too cold and they wore their regular sandals for walking and slipped them off before getting into the water. The crystal clear water and rock formations were unbelievably beautiful! Combined with the story sharing of the significance the cenotes played in the Mayan culture made for quite a special afternoon trip that we won't soon be forgetting!There is one small disappointment, I read all the reviews of a photographer tagging along and selling photos for $30 afterwards. I personally thought that would be a great arrangement, my hands would be free and I could just enjoy the scenery. There was no photographer or offer to purchase pics. So ask before you head out on the trails and grab your water proof camera, you're going to want to have pictures to remember this experience by!

Fantastic time!. Had Ricardo as a guide - absolutely lovely and very knowledgable.. This really is off the beaten track and we were dubious on arrival but once inside it was magical. Absolutely beaitiful caves and crystal clear water.. Want to go back!! Thanks Ricardo :)

brilliant private tour!. visted chaak tun with 3 friends and had a tour with our guide Felix. he was a really friendly and knowledgeable, as someone who was a tour guide in a cave in another country I can safely say he knows what he's talking about! if you are visiting it's probably best to get there early, we were there around 10am and there was pretty much no one else there for most of it. fantastic experience!
PERFECT PLACE!. Perfect place, the best cenote in Yucatan! Perfect for swimming and snorkeling, with water clean and transparent. We come back!

Chaak Tun Cenote. Our experience was awesome. The guide, Felix, was super knowledgeable and explained everything about the cenote in great detail. He was also very careful not to push any inexperienced swimmers out of their comfort zone. If you are using a taxi to get to Chaak Tun, I would suggest asking them to return to pick you up, so you don't get stranded.

Absolutely a must!. We decided to go see the cenotes but weren't sure what to expect. After a very professional and fun tour by Felix we can confidently say this is the best tour in Playa Del Carmen area.

Unreliable schedule. 6 of us arrived to Chak Tun around 3:30pm, only to find out that it was already closed. I told the gentleman at the door that we thought hours were from 9am - 5pm. He said that that day (Saturday) they had few visitors so they decided to close early. I told him there was 6 of us, that we had taken 2 cabs to get there ($240 pesos for both cabs there... and another $160 to get back to Playa) and wanted to tour the cenote and caverns, and were willing to pay a little extra. Come back tomorrow, he said, to which I replied... "I don't think so".

Wonderful!. Lovely views whilst underground of the cenote (sinkhole ) with stalactites and stalagmites plus bats flying around near the roof top and daylight shining in. Lots of people swimming in the cold water!

Great attraction!. The highlight of my trip with Ricardo as a guide. This tour is $360 pesos and includes private guide wetsuits masks, locker and water shoes. The supplied flashlight is dim so if you have a dive light bring it! You can ride a bike from town, we rented a cab for $120 pesos, takes you right there. Best to arrange the cab to come back before you let them exit. If you are claustrophobic or afraid of the dark this is not the tour for you!

Overall Amazing!. This is the first Cenote my husband and I have every been to, so I can only base our experience on this one, but it was amazing! We took a taxi to the Cenote from our hotel. The fauna & natural beauty of the place was breathtaking! It was not far from Playa del Carmen. I read other reviews that said to go after 2PM. We followed that advise and it worked out perfectly. We got there right around 2PM & basically had the whole place to ourselves. Our guide was very knowledgeable! I loved learning about the history of the place. We also had a photographer take pictures of us (optional) I think it was worth it, we got several good pictures. I think the photographer was around $30. It was a lot cheaper to do it this way rather than with a tour. We got to go at our own pace and it was just us, so we got to have all our questions answered and because we were such good swimmers, we actually swam under the water to enter another cave, which was thrilling! We went in early December and didn't have any problems with mosquitoes, however the caves did have a few bats, but they weren't flying around or anything. I'm scared of bats and it didn't even bother me! The equipment was included in the cost of the tour. We got a wetsuit, underwater flashlight and snorkel. They had lockers to use for free so you could lock up any valuables. We asked our taxi driver to come back for us and he opted to just wait for us even though it was like 1 1/2 - 2 hours before we were done. We gave him a good tip when we returned to our hotel, which he was really happy about. Overall, it was amazing & really inexpensive to go by yourself. Have fun, I know we did!

Chaak Tun Cenote - Great experie. We wanted to experience the cenotes while visiting Playa del Carmen. We chose Chaak Tun because it was conveniently located and reasonably priced. We expected to have a good time, but we ended up having an absolutely wonderful experience! The cenote was even better than anticipated, and our guide, Ricardo, was fabulous. Not only was he extremely knowledgable, he's a free-diver and was impressive to watch in the caves! We went with our teenaged children and everyone had a fantastic time.
Chaak Tun. My wife and I have over the years have been to many cenotes in the Yucatan over the years and this is one of our favorites.

Must See. Disclaimer: I've never been on a cenote tour before so I have really no comparison. However, to speak on the attraction itself, it was amazing! The tour lasted approximately 2-3 hours, with about a little more than an hour in the water in the cave. The water was cool when you first went in but you got used to it, and it was so clear!! It felt like you could almost touch the bottom (but it was really 25 ft down in some parts). You were led by a guide and flashlights the whole time and got to explore the entire cave. Afterwards we were treated to a traditional Mexican lunch which was delicious. The cost of the tour included a wet suit, water shoes, life vest, hard hat, snorkel gear and locker rental. The guides were very knowledgeable and clearly seemed to enjoyed giving tours. I would definitely recommend this tour!

What a place!!. Fantastic place to visit -- could spend days wandering about. The spectacular" is exactly that, although I must admit that I enjoyed the old version a little more than the newer version

Beautiful cenote, terrible guide. Beautiful cenote, clear water and fantastic formations! The cenote was a little hard to find as its in the middle of nowhere and there are no signs but eventually I got there and it was the best looking cenote I've visited so far. Guides are mandatory and I was happy to learn more about the cenote and Mayan culture but unfortunately Abel didn't seem to know anything at all. He didn't know what a cenote was or how it formed; at the end of the tour the other guide thankfully explained it to me. I was also hoping to learn more about the Mayan culture too but we skipped over it in 30 seconds. I would hope the a tour guide would at least know the basics as the amazing cenote did deserve a knowledgeable guide to compliment it. I still recommend the cenote as it is amazing, just ask for a competant guide!

Nature Quest. Natural wonder! Loved the beauty and knowledge gained! Family friendly excursion. Eric and especially Sandra went out of their way to share very interesting history and facts about Mexico, the maya riviera, the jungle, the people, the ecosystem, land and sea life. Loved it!

One of the BEST cenote tours I've been on.. My husband and I like to try and hit up as many cenotes as we can while we're in QR. The recent tour of Chaak Tun is now competing for the number one spot. Like most cenotes it doesn't look like much from the outside.We were a little put off by the $30/person price tag and required guide since most of the cenotes in the area are a couple bucks and self guided. However, the guide is definitely necessary. We were in a group of 4 with a guide named Felix and he was fantastic., The smaller group you are in the better because you get to do more things while in the caves. At first it was a little freaky down in the caves with the bats flying around and the small quarters. However, once you get in the water and start swimming around, you forget where you are and focus on the natural wonder around you. The peace that this particular cenote provides is profound. It has such a calming effect on anyone who enters it. I wish I would have had a waterproof camera. It would have been great to take photos although I'm not sure how well they would have done the place justice. Also, most of the time you're treading water so if you opt out of the life jacket it might have been a pain trying to juggle a camera, a flashlight and a snorkel mask all while swimming. Don't miss this one-just west of Playa del Carmen on the main road.
Cool Cenotes. Great tour! We saw 3 cenotes and got some history lessons too. It was a small group, my 4 plus 3-4 more so very intimate!

Amazing tour in a amazing cenote!. We went to Chaak Tun which is just a taxi ride away from center if Playa del Carmen (possible to hitch hike as well if you are lucky) and had absolutely the best time! Our guide, Alex, was not only fun but also very informative! He had an answer for every question, he was extremely well informed in mayan culture and geology. Absolutely worth every penny! And don't worry if you don't have a waterproof camera as you can buy photos onsite too. Highly recommend to everyone!!

AMAZING!!!. From playa 5th avenue, it was 150 pesos for 5 of us. Cost for tour was 30 usd for adults and 15 usd for kids(8 and 10). You get wetsuit, mask, flashlight, watershoes, guide and locker. It was incredible! I have been to other cenotes and many places in riviera maya, been going for over 15 years, and this is near the top! Beautiful look at earths wonders! My kids did great, but definitely would not have if there was any fear of water, darkness or small spaces. Alex was our guide, he was great! Bring a waterproof camera or phone case or you will have to purchase a cd from the park (about 25 usd), it does include some beautiful pictures of the park though. They also said that procee do help the Mayan people who keep up the park, so that's always a plus. Go ... it's so worth it!

Clear Water. The staff, especially Fernando and , are just wonderful and very knowledgeable of the area and the geology. This is a wonderful Cenote. Be prepared (bring your own snorkel and mask) for one of Nature's best and amazing showings.

Amazingly cool. Beautiful natural cenote. Exactly the type of place we were looking, not too touristy and yet staff which are very helpful. The water is so clean and spectacular. Visited 3 cenotes, swam in 2 of them. Alex was the best tour guide. Thank you Alex!

amazing snorkeling tour. one of the best cenotes for sure. very professional organized and nice tour guide.
inside the cave you will enjoy the view for sure and if you get lucky like we, you get an extra tour in another cave ... ;-)

Unexpectedly entertaining.. We arrived near closing (30 minutes until closing, tours 2 hours long) and were turned away originally. Explaining it was our last day, they said they would look for a guide willing to take us through. They found a guide willing to take us through as long as we hurried and got through in an hour. Note: the cenote is only paid, not able to see without tour. We paid roughly $20 / person, got wet-suits, life preservers, lockers to secure our personal belongings, and started the tour. They start with a history of Mayan culture which was very interesting. Then we entered the cenote. As we arrived so late, it was dark outside. We received flashlights. The water was gorgeous and was pretty cold but with a wet-suit, you get over it quick. Even though we arrived late, we received a prolonged tour - we were in the Cenote for over 2 hours. The guide was very interested in mayan culture and they are quite funny. Our first flashlight broke, then the second one started flickering. But the guide made jokes and made us feel very comfortable. The guide said they work on tips / are not paid so we tipped but the cenote and tour were well worth it. It is back in the country, about 10-15 minutes from downtown Playa del Carmen. Well worth it and unexpectedly one the better parts of the trip.

pricey cenote tour. it's actually a network of cenotes connected with very narrow canals and that's why you're not allowed to explore by yourself (you could get lost easily or even hurt yourself). A cab from Playa centre shouldn't be more than $100, if the driver doesn't know where it is just tell him to follow Av. Juarez 6km inland until you'll see a sign on the right. The guide is $360 pp and takes you through the underground labirynth and gives you some history lesson also. views are spectacular, you will see many cenotes, some with natural light and some with lamps installed - it's quite dark in general so take waterproof flashlight if you have one. the whole experience takes about 2 hours, we were lucky to have the guide just for 2 of us and I can't imagine doing it as part of bigger group (I know they do it).Tip: If you are afraid of small spaces choose another attraction.Overall amazing experience but pricey for what you get.
Amazing. Loved the water , it was so clear. A little difficult to walk down with steep steps down. Unique experience though

Denote, Mayan Village and Chichen Itza. Awesome day trip. Incredible experience and historical. A must see if in Playa del Carmen. Spend the entire day reliving history and swim in the Cenote. You will never forget a visit into Mayan history. Eat lunch in the village and you won't be disappointed. It is a full day tour and you must have a tour guide but it is worth the time.

Fantastic experience - get in there while you can! . What a great cenote! Our guide Ricardo was great at telling us about the history of the place and showing us around. We felt very adventurous going 'caving' and we loved that it was so quiet. I also loved seeing the catfish and the bats. Definitely a great little excursion to do when you're in Playa as you can do it in half a day (it only took about 2.5 hrs to go round which was both plenty and not too long).

Great tour guides. Been to Mexico 3 times first time to do this and we had a lot of fun. Not for the poor swimmer or take the life jacket. Tight spaces going through some areas but we loved the adventure. The tour guides spend a lot of time giving history of the area. Worth the money! Ricardo thanks for a nice time!

Very cool experience. Took a tour with Alex through the two different cenotes at the park. Alex shared lots of Mayan history and information throughout the tour. Highly recommend this tour...you'll not see anything like it on your own.
crystal waters. everything , first time on a cenote ,magical place,you can feel the history on the walls,stalagtites ,and stalagmites everywhere what can i say you have to do it , trust me!!

cenote. amazing activity wish i had seen the vests before going down I think to really enjoy the activity you need them, there are no lockers though or at least did not see them, great for kids if they had the vests
Great tour. This is a great tour, far better than the expensive cenote parks. Easy to get to being off the Main Street of playa. Our tour guide Alex was wonderful. I highly recommend this place.

Great guide service and tour. My family of 4, mom, dad, 15 and 17 yo boys really enjoyed the Cenote Chaak-Tun tour with Ricardo. He gave us a great description of the underground river and Cenote systems throughout the area. We had plenty of time to enjoy the waters and we even got a nice mud mask and a little music from the stagellicites. We had the place to ourself and it felt like a private tour. A must visit while in Playa. A big thanks to Ricardo for such a great tour.
Off the beaten track. A great experience in a wonderful cenote. Beautiful caves with ancient stalactite and stalagmite formations. Thank you Felix for the informative tour. Loved it.

Awesome visit to genuine cenotes!. Great guide with a lot of charisma and charm who led us through the highlights of Chaaktun! The guy that runs the whole place has his heart in the right spot and is a very warm and genuine person with love for the environment. The beautiful clear water and limestone formations of the cenotes makes it more than worth its money! The scuba equipment is new and fresh. Make sure you wear a wetsuit. Would definately go there again!

Absolutely amazing. Had the best time at this cenote, one of many we went to. This was the absolute best one! Felix, our guide, was phenomenal and helped us through many different caves. All their equipment is free and they are patient and fun guides. Would absolutely recommend. They even have a photographer follow you around with photos! While they were amazing, we had our own camera otherwise we would definitely have bought them.

Great place with great tour guide . I went with my friends and we really had a good time. I recommend this to all who wants to see a cenote and have a good time. I think the price is fair considering what it includes. Our guide was really good and funny.

Great Little Excursion in Playa. We wanted to visit a Cenote without going through a tour company and through research found out Chaak Tun is only 4-5km from PDC and can be reached by bicycle. So we rented two bikes for the day and headed out on Av. Juarez toward the jungle. After seemingly leaving all civilization, we finally happened upon Chaak Tun. Upon arrival, the staff were very inviting and we were told of the 1.5-2 hour guided tour for 360 pesos/person. For the cost you get a wetsuit, mask, flashlight and water shoes, along with the guided tour, which frankly is well worth the cost as you couldn't possibly discover all these caves have to offer without a guide. You also get a locker to put your belongings in which is a relief. They are not high-security lockers by any means so don't bring more than you need - Money (see below), a change of clothes, towel and maybe a sandwich or snack for after, as the swimming is a bit of work!Felix was our absolutely fantastic guide - One of the best tour guides I've met - So knowledgeable, personable, helpful - and full of humor. He will cater the tour to your swimming ability and makes the whole experience delightful. It really is a great little adventure, as long as you aren't claustrophobic or afraid of the water (or the dark.)As for costs, besides paying for transportation (Taxi/Rental Car/Bicycle) my recommendation is to bring the 360 pesos for admission per person plus enough to tip the guide. I'd recommend a minimum of 100-200 pesos. Photos taken during the tour are very nice and cost 250 pesos. We bought them and did not regret it.

Chaak Tun. I had read about this on tripadvisor and thought it would be a good alternative to a big group tour. It was one of the highlights of our trip. Felix was great at telling everything about the history and culture of the cenote. It's a quick taxi ride from PDC and takes about an hour and a half for the tour. Don't miss it.

guided tour?. I was not expecting this to be via tour only when I arrived and was not too pleased. I had heard it was 200 pesos and enjoy by yourself. I really did enjoy the cenotes though and I think it was probably worth the 360 pesos that I think it cost. The reef runners and flash light were pretty necessary and we would probably have missed some cool spots without the guide.

Cenote. Bring your swimming suit with you and experience the amazing underground pool. This is a pretty deep pool which you probably need to walk at least few flights of stairs down but all the hard work will be paid off by seeing the amazing natural water cabin -

Great afternoon trip from Playa. We caught a taxi out from playa to the cenote where we met Felix who took us on a tour of the underground cenote. It was warm but we still hired the wetsuits as it was a bit cool in some of the areas. The afternoon was like nothing I have ever experienced! Felix knew heaps about the caves and was great to have a laugh with. We also ended up buying the pictures that the girl on site took as there were some great ones in there.
Quiet Adventure!. This place was great - close to town so we visited on an afternoon we didn't have much planned. It took 2 hours and we were there pretty much by ourselves. It was really cool!

Quite expensive if on a budget. Taxi drivers from Playa either said they didnt know where it was or they had never heard of it, but we just walked up to the 30th and had no trouble, 150pesos one way. When we arrived we were surprised that it was 320+ pesos each, yes they supplied the shorty wet suits and masks but there was no discount if you have brought your own gear, I was still surprised on the price. They were pleasant but personally not at that price. I wouldnt recommend at that price, also they have limited lockers so we had to leave our belongings at the entrance which the chap said he wouldnt be leaving and 2 mins later he walked up the path!

Great shirt trip from Playa. My new wife and I took a taxi (150 pesos) to This beautiful cenotes.Our guide was Alex and he was awesome! We were lucky enough to be the only ones in the tour when we went.$30 each, 1.5 hours of touring the cenotes and swimming through them.Great fun!
Incredible!. Absolutely incredible! What an experience to swim in such beautiful Cenote.... We will never forget. Thank you Monroy (best tour guide, for sure)!!

Nice quick excursion and learned some Mayan history. Very interesting. Must buy guided tour- $360 pesos. Guide was Ricardo and he was really good. They provide wetsuit, mask, water shoes and flashlight. Water was refreshing not ice cold. We learned some Mayan history re cenote, Mayan gods, etc about 90 min to 2 hours. It wAs a good break from being on a beach without committing a lot of $$ and the whole day.
Amazing. This was the best! Loved swimming in the caves !!!!!!!! Water was very very cold at first!!! Well worth a visit!

Amazing Find - Top Notch - Highly Recommend. This was an excellent excursion. $30/person which includes a guide and all equipment. Swim through caves. This is not overly touristy, it's still pretty rough/wild. Would highly recommend. It is hard to get good pictures with very low light (and you are swimming most of the time). A van from Playcar was $55 for 5 people round trip, arranged by the hotel. The cenote is just outside of Playa del Carmen so it's a short ride. Whole trip probably took us 3 hours, but we really took our time to enjoy it.

great sinkhole. change rooms were clean and you had to shower prior to entering the sinkhole. there were to platforms to jump from. 1 from 9 meters and the other from 5m. you had to be careful from when the stairs changed from cement to wood as the first two steps were slippery. the water was pleasant and not cold. I guess if you brought diving gear, you could of explored the bottom to see if there was a cave there leading deeper into the earth.

underground freshwater pools. low key, relaxed exploration of a natural wonder. Tour guide very knowledgeable, respectful and caring, made the excursion doubly worth it. Look for Alex if he is still there. Whole operation professional yet relaxed.
Beautiful place. Worth visiting.changing rooms available to get changed. Was very busy when we visited Lots of people waiting to swim in the denote due to weather being very hot Well worth a visit

A swim to remember!!. we were able to visit as part of our tour of the Coba Mayan ruins. After climbing the ruins and a quick zipline, it was refreshing to take a dip in the amazing wonder in the ground. Our guide gave us some extra time to swim, relax and take in the beauty of those cave. Another must visit if you get a chance. Be careful of the steps they are steep and a little slick. The it's all worth it at the bottom!!

Highly recommended!. Wonderful cenote! Beautiful caves and a fun adventure. I thoroughly enjoyed swimming around and exploring. Water was chilly but clean and refreshing! Alex was a very informative guide who gave all the information one could hope for, was supportive and well mannered, thankyou! This is the third cenote I have visited and this is the most natural, most adventurous and well organised. Couldn't recommend higher, had a blast!
Worth the visit. Not too busy and a nearby attraction if you're staying in Playa del Carmen. Need to get a taxi to it
Great experience. Short cab ride drive from PDC. Check the cruise ship calendar ahead of time to possibly avoid big crowds. I'm a non-swimmer & felt safe. Lifejackets provided.

BEAUTIFUL AND INCREDIBLE PLACE!. Just a tip: all those who come to visit Playa del Carmen, have to go swimming in the beautiful waters of this cenote, little known, but certainly among the best to visit.

such a gem!!!. wow! this was perfect! We got there and our guide Felix pointed us to lookers (that were free) for us to put our stuff in while we went down to the caves. We had brought our water shoes but some of our group didn't have any so they lend them some (no fees!). If we wanted we could get life vets for the water, some took other prefered not. We then went to the first cenote which was big and open but still amazing to see. Easy entry in the water with stairs or you can jump in. After some time, we moved on to the other one. You need hats to get in as the ceiling is low, then you come up to this wonderful tree that opens up to the sky, just gorgeous. We then proceded to the caves where it was dark, more closed up....in other word perfect!! just has a cave should be. Felix was amazing, he described everything we were looking at and he even took our camera underwater to get some shots of the tunnels underground. We would go back in a second!!

Off the beaten path and totally worth it.. Chaak Tun is definitely off the beaten path but this is an asset and not a detriment. Due to it not being overly known it has yet to get the over the top tourist feel and that was a very welcome thing. The cave is beautiful and they have not done a lot to it by adding outside influences or modernizations. There is limited lighting in the cave which gives you the ability to take in the natural beauty of the place. Swimming in a cenote had been on my bucket list for some time. This is definitely a great way to cross that off. Our guide, Felix, clearly had a passion for the cultural significance of the place. It showed and it made the trip much more enjoyable and informative for me and my family. They provided wetsuits, masks, helmets and life jackets if you wanted them. The water is rather chilly so the wetsuit was a very good idea. The helmets were only needed in certain spots and Felix took great care guiding us through and showing us the cave. As there is limited lighting the only light at times was a small dive flashlight. If you are bothered by the dark, bringing one of your own dive lights may not be a bad choice. If you are looking for something off the beaten path and sort of an eco-type of trip, I would definitely recommend taking the tour at Chaak Tun.
Quick Adventure. 15 minute cab ride from Playa del Carmen. Awesome adventure in under 3 hours. Felix and the team were very accomodating and we had a blast.
Beautiful. Went early and had the whole place by myself and the guide. It was beautiful and peaceful. Took 90 minutes and that was perfect.

Watch your head!. This cenote was alright, but it's probably more worth it to visit a bigger one that's better equipped (they didn't have enough wetsuits and shoes for everyone). You're required to take the tour, which I felt was overpriced (around $30/person) and too long (almost 3 hours). It's also very dark in there and easy to hit your hit on a stalagmite (it happened to a few people on the tour), so make sure you duck especially when walking.

Unreal and aweome!!. Chaak tun was such an amazing place! The cenotes are so peaceful (if you have the luxury of exploring them with just a small group) and beautiful. It feels like diving and swimming in an Indiana Jones -movie, we've never experienced anything like that before. A couple of things worth knowing though: we were told in advance that there are no lockers to keep your personal belongings, so we brought nothing but our clothes and some cash. This is not true, since there are toilets and lockers, and this would have been nice to know. We would have brought at least a better camera. Secondly; we read somewhere that the cost is 100 pesos per person, but in reality it was 360 pesos. Which is not bad for this amazing adventure, but considering the locker-issue we had just enough money with us to get it but just a ridicilously little tip for the guide, Alex, who was so great and who works there voluntarely!! So; bring enough cash and cameras if you wish. All the equipment (snorkels, shoes, life jackets, helmets) you'll get there. We higly recommend this wonderful place!! Once in a life time experience!
Fun and interesting. I loved Cenotes... I'm not big on group excursions. Some in our group were afraid of the water, etc.
the best. wonderful staff and setting. Can I live there? The guide was the best and soooo cute. Gay people as we are, we are just wanna come back.

Heavenly underground!. my wife and i had the pleasure to stumble upon chaak tun as we were driving various backroads behind playa del carmen. chaak tun is not anything glitzy on the outside but get inside and you are treated to a stunning environment of clear water and caves to swim through or walk between. really, it was such a beautiful place, i would have been happy to pay a larger entry fee. we were guided by a young guy, felix, who was really friendly and gave detail on many things mayan, he gave extra meaning to the information we had received from our guide at chichen itza the previous day! I was so very happy that there was a photographer on the site who took pictures at a about 4 well selected locations....$25 bucks for fabulous photos... chaak tun...a great memory.

Great attraction but the cost is tourist (and guide) exploitation.. This is a great cenote. It is well set up and you get life jackets and helmets meaning even non-swimmers can join in. The site is extensive with two main pools, we even saw a turtle in one! The guides are excellent and informative, yet fun and speak English. It really is a great site.Now the disappointments. Firstly, the guides are not paid, meaning you feel obliged to leave a large tip. The entrance fee is maddeningly high and you are followed around by a lady with a camera who then charges an extortionate fee if you want the pictures on a memory card. As with everything in this part of Mexico, the tourist is milked for every penny they have. That said, it is a good attraction and as long as you know what to expect, you can still enjoy it.

Hidden gem. There are so many famous cenotes down here in the playa del carmen area that I didn't realize there are many right here. Chaak tun is just straight up Juarez. They rent you wet suits and masks and a guide, our guide was Felix. Then cenote was beautiful and lighted to walk in to. The water is deep and so clear you can see the bottom. Felix was awesome about making sure we all saw every thing and explaining the history of cenote's and the Mayan culture. The tour was over an hour, and pretty easy physically. I definitely recommend this cenote, it's right in town, you can go any time and the views are amazing.

Last minute excursion. Sitting around Royal hotel and decided to check this place out in the mid afternoon. Walked to taxi stand in front of hotel and jumped in a cab 200 pesos each way. The driver waited at the site while I toured the cenote. Check in was quick as we were the only people there. Got assigned a guide who did not speak English (bummer) but we were able to communicate well enough to understand the subtle beauties of the area that he pointed out. It was $30 USD for the tour which took 90 minutes. Overall this was a fun thing to do on a whim or as a planned excursion.

What a great afternoon excursion from playa del carmen . Small quaint cenote excursion for older kids comfortable in the water or adults. One cenote is an small underground " pool like " swimming area and the other cenote is part walking , part wading and part snorkelling/swim ( very dark in places ). There is a tour guide for a simplistic type of tour , they supply water shoes , wet suits and goggles ( no snorkle) for $20 pp Monday to Saturday last group goes in at 3:30 pm. On Sunday last group goes in at 1:30 pm ... But we went at 2:30 pm and saw the whole thing Great activity for a couple of hours ... 20 mins from pkaya drl carmen

Fascinating. I loved this excursion. We went on this excursion from the Carnival Cruise when we arrived there where people waiting for us at the pier, they took.us to a ferry boat that would take us to the main land in playa del carmen. The ride was smooth, the ferry boats have both indoor seats and.outdoor seats and are super comfortable. 45 minutes later you arrive and your guide is waiting for you to take you to.the cenote. A short ride on an airconditioned bus and we arrived at the cenote. It was an Experience. Crystal clear water inside a dark cave filled with stalactites and stalagmites. Nature all around. We where given snorkel gear and a flashlight so we could see how clear it was. You can also take.your own gear. It does require a little physical activity tho. Take good water shoes, theres a lot of rocks when you enter a cenote, also when in the cave you will have to walk up some stairs and slippery rocks so you need to be very careful. After the cenotes we where given a delicious traditional meal inside another one of the caves. It doesnt get any more natural than that. The peace you find in these places is unbelievable. Our tour guide was amazing. Do not miss the experience of swimming in one of these places, believed to be entrances to the underworld by the mayans. PLEASE PLEASE ! DO.NOT use any sunblock or any kind of lotion before you go into these places, do not touch the stalagmites and stalactites as this will stop their growth and it takes hundreds of years for them to grow.Thank You Hope you find this helpful

Low key cenote experience. If you want to avoid screaming crowds, silly side shows, all day amusement park extravaganzas, spend 2 two at Chaak Tun. Its entrance near the inland end of a major road that leads to the beach in Playa, as soon as the road makes its first deviation from straight.You can rent wet suits, and there are masks, water shoes, underwater flashlights, helmets for those wanting them. Volunteer guides will lead your small group through a series of caves. There is some walking and two different cenotes to swim in. Occasional hints of color in the limestone and some attractive stalagmites and stalactites are on view.

Favorite part of a great family trip. We were on a Carnival Cruise with the family over New Years. We are traveling with three children and the prospects of travel from the ship, to the mainland, and then to a cave seemed daunting. I am so glad we made the journey. Our guide Andy was knowledgeable and spoke English fluently. His lectures were informative and interesting. He asked for his English rating and we all gave him 9's and 10's. The facility had restrooms which were rustic but clean. Lockers were provided but not used by our group. Lifejackets were provided and necessary for our kids. I brought swim shirts for the kids, but they were not needed. The water was cool but just fine. We swim in Lake Michigan regularly, and it was about the same as summer water temp there. We entered two different cave systems and both were beautiful. We were encouraged to jump into one and we did! The kids loved the adventure. I have to say it was so unique and interesting. I loved it.

Awesome. A perfect ending to our vacation. Felix was a very knowledgeable guide and was a perfect guide who spoke English and Spanish fluently. He shared a lot about Mayan culture which was an added bonus. Wet suits are optional but made for a very comfortable swim-- you only need masks (snorkels optional but not really needed-- as the sights to see are largely above you and at times you have the option of diving down a bit to see entrances to caves and occasional fish.) We really enjoyed the Grand Cenote but the caves at this one were in comparison rather awe inspiring. Crystal clear water and when it was dark the flashlights that they provided worked really well above and in the water. When coming out we mistakenly left behind a wallet with cash and credit cards and assorted things in a beach bag. We did not become aware until 30 minutes out. When we returned our guide had retrieved our belongings from a bench and stored everything in a locker to await our return--what kindness and a great relief ! Don't miss out on this place--it's worth the fee!

Afternoon well spent. If your looking for an easy outing from Playa, I would recommend you visit this cenote which is only about a 15 minute cab ride, paid 175 pesos for the ride out and had someone who spoke spanish help me negotiate for 150 pesos for a taxi back to 5th ave. Going out I handed the taxi driver a piece of paper with the cenote name and even then he had to call in for directions, but it is just straight north of Playa a very simple drive. It cost us $30 per person for snorkel, life vest, wet suit, water shoes and a guide. Free lockers are available. There were only six people in the group I went out in but it would probably depend on how many people show up at the same time. We first went into a large open cave and just swam around ourselves for about 15 minutes. The water did not feel cold to us but others in our group without wetsuits did think it was cold. The cave was fascinating especially if it is your first time in a cenote. Then we walked a little bit to another cave where the guide led us through the various caverns and paths. Our guide could not speak any English and while he tried to be helpful to us, was a little confusing at times. Luckily one of our group could interpret and also lucky that he had a flashlight as the guide had a lot of trouble getting his to work. As it is very dark in some spots, I was very grateful for the extra flashlight. Despite the poor guiding, the cenote itself is extraordinary and truly a wonder. We had a lot of fun and am so glad we took a day off from the beach to do this.

Wonderful Experience. We did this as a part of a cruise excursion for "Underground River". Our guide Andy was very friendly and knowledgable about Mayan history and the formation of the cenotes and cave system. The drive from Playa del Carmen to Chaaktun took roughly 10 mins. There is a place to change or use the potty at the start and end of your experience. There are helmets, wetsuits and life jackets available with life jackets being mandatory for parts of the tour. Our tour began walking through to one of the locations with Andy giving us full narration along the way. We entered / exited caves at three particular locations and each time we could get into the cool mineral water or opt to wait it out. It is amazing how crystal clear the water is there! It was cold but it was soooo refreshing after being in the hot sun. In two of the caves, there was the "Mexican Paparazzi" snapping photos. At the end of the tour I purchased them both for $20! That is reasonable so don't be cheap and negotiate. The last stop of our tour was a traditional Mayan/ Mexican lunch that was prepared and eaten in the cave. Andy explained what each dish was, how it was prepared and any significance associated with it. Delicious does not begin to describe it! Overall I feel like this is a can't miss experience.

Perfect Couple of Hours. Loved it. Close to town. Stunning to see (my first cenote). Fun to swim and explore in. Guide was friendly. My partner is a beginner swimmer, but with a life jacket they provide, she was cruisin' in the caves with the group gleefully. Saw a cool older lady with a walking cane rockin it on the tour too. I don't have a waterproof camera, so we splurged and bought the photos provided by the photographer. Such a fun experience! Highly recommend!

Enjoy an Exciting Swim in an Underground Cave. This is advertised as a cenote, but unlike pictures I have seen of those formations, this is really more of an underground cave system, rather than a sink hole. After a 10-15 minute ride from Playa Del Carmen down a dirt road, you come upon an opening in a fence with a small parking area and a disheveled sign overhead announcing that you have arrived at Chaak Tun. Hard to believe from the exterior what all the hype is about. There is a small entry hut where they take your payment (credit cards accepted) and suit you up with booties and a johnny wet suit (you will definitely want these; consider, also, wearing a long sleeve shirt under to help keep you warm), mask and snorkel. You can do without the snorkel, but definitely take the mask. From there, you march down a short path and down some stairs into the cave entrance. Life jackets are optional, but with the chilly water, lack of strong lighting and being in an uncertain surrounding, you will feel much more comfortable taking the jacket. From there, it's into the water! After adjusting to the sudden temperature drop and the eerie feeling of being in the water in a cave, you concentrate on slower breathing and controlling your elevated heart rate. Then you begin to really enjoy the experience - the water is crystal clear. If there are no waves or ripples, you can see right to the bottom from above. The guide takes you through several passages that you can explore. A few were small, but nothing too claustrophobic for me (I am not real good in super tight spaces). We went to the smaller cave first, which I think is the better way to do it as it prepares you better for the bigger cave. There, you walk along a pathway through the cave until you come to a large open area where the cave is open to the sky (hence the cenote, I guess). There are many bats flying around, but they are pretty cool and absolutely harmless. Here, our guide took us to a platform above the water and we jumped in, rather than heading down steps (for the less adventurous, there are steps). More twists and turns through the cave system - fascinating rock formations, ledges, fish, sand and more. Sometimes you can stand; others you must float or swim. At one point, in the very back, our guide offers to turn off the lights completely so that we can experience complete, total darkness for a few minutes. Very cool. Despite a holiday week, we had the place to ourselves in the mid-afternoon. Hard to believe for something so close to town and so well covered in the reviews. It's also a great place to cool down on a hot day.

You must come here!. We were not sure about were to go for the Cenote tours and we decided upon suggestion of our Tax Driver Ivan to come here. It was a blessing!! The whole place is amazing and the caves are really stunning to visit and see. The staff is very courteous and VERY friendly. Our tour guide Diego was great and shared with us lots of tips that made this experience truly amazing. The water is cool, but since we were here in a very warm day it was actually very nice to be in it. There are lots of caves to see and some are extremely well light. It is a Must Do Experience to come to this Cenote when here in Playa Del Carmen. You will not be disappointed.

Beautiful cave, no crowds!!!. Had an excellent time here! It was super convenient to Playa, maybe 10 minutes each way and cost only 300 pesos by taxi roundtrip. I got there early and had a private tour, since no other tourists were around. The cave was fantastic, the water wasn't too cold, and I got everything I needed. Only caution - at that time, the guide spoke mostly Spanish so if that's a concern you may want to go later in the day. All in all - wonderful!

Great experience. We have young children and big all inclusive parks like Xcaret and Xel-ha don't work for us because we would probably use only 20% of available activities. Cenote Chaak Tun is close enough to the main area ...about a 10 min cab ride from the hotels on 5th ave. We loved it. Our guide Roberto was very patient and gave us an excellent tour. I can't swim but managed fine ...you need to be able to float and they give you a life jacket, goggles and wet suit. It was a 90 min tour through 2 Cenotes..easy to navigate and a very good choice for people like us who want to indulge in some adventure but aren't professional divers or enthusiasts. They even arranged for a cab back for us. All in all very refreshing and satisfying without long lines. One caveat...this place is 3 to 4 miles from the 5th Ave tourist area ...not 0.4 miles as reported by maps app on your phone. We were trying to walk there then realized after asking around that it isn't walkable so we took a cab.

Breathtaking caves; friendly, well organized staff. What a great day trip.We took a van-taxi from Grand Mayan Riviera--he knew the spot, but it should not be difficult for anyone to find. The Avenue Juarez is a big, paved street heading out of town, and the site is well marked. We got there around 12, and the taxi driver agreed to come pick us up in 2.5 hours.We were greeted warmly and all costs were explained clearly--$30US per person to go on the full tour; $30US for a photographer to accompany us; the required guide was a "volunteer," and thus would be paid in tips. We got suited up in the provided wetsuits, life jackets, and swimming shoes, and left our belongings in small, locked lockers. Our guide led us through the jungle on a well marked path--think National Park hiking--and down into the caves. There we got snorkel masks (but no breathing tubes) and flashlights, and we got into the water. If you have your own snorkel tube, bring it. Flippers would be useless. A waterproof headlight or flashlight would be good, too--you get one for every two people, so an extra would be nice, but not essential. The water is cool, but the wetsuits kept us pretty comfortable. The caves are huge, with spectacular stalactites and stalagmites--the beautiful pictures on the internet only begin to suggest how magnificent they are. And looking down through the clear water you could see many underwater caverns. We followed a loop around through the caves, and then the guide led us through the jungle to another, huge cave, where we swam around freely.We had a picnic lunch (which we brought with us) on tables set up in another cave. We bought the cd of photographs--about five of the pictures are terrific, and ten are good, and the rest blurry or awkwardly framed--but those 15 good ones made it worthwhile. This is an experience we will want to remember.We had six people in our group--two grandparents, in their 80s, and two twenty-something guys who are very athletic. One of the young men is a scuba diver and has been spelunking. One of the grandparents has macular degeneration and some impaired mobility. Amazingly, this was an activity that everyone enjoyed thoroughly. But if your 80 something grandma isn't quite as adventuresome as ours, this will be too rugged. There are many stairs, and some rocky parts that are uneven for walking. I should add that the guide, Carlos, was wonderfully patient and attentive to Grandma, helping her on the stairs and into the water. She found it challenging, but she did it!We had the caves to ourselves, which was fabulous, and Carlos never seemed in any kind of a hurry. In fact, everybody there was super nice and accommodating.The grandparents offered to take us all to Xcaret. Can't tell you how happy we are we chose to go to Chaak Tun instead.

Treasure!. We followed the advice to go after 1pm. We had the caves to ourselves. Not much in terms of interpretation, but being trained in geology, not much interpretation is needed.take Avenida Jaurez straight out of town. There is good signage. Xplora just leased the caves. They are charging gringos $30US. Its worth every penny. They provide a wetsuit, water shoes, and a mask.We were also lucky enough to see a local mating pair of leopards.

Cenote exploring. This has been my favorite adventure so far in Playa del Carmen. Easy to reach via cab and the staff was incredibly friendly and helpful. Felix, our tour guide, was very knowledgeable and took my girlfriend and me on a personal swim through two dark and beautiful cenotes. We had a blast and I would say that this is a must do trip for anyone staying in Playa del Carmen. Thanks again Felix.

Easy trip, no need to go through salesperson. BEAUTIFUL. Jungle, caves, stalactites and stalagmites, swimming. Family friendly. From Playa del Carmen, get a cab and tell them to take you to Cenote Chak tuun. 15-20 minute ride. Bring your own snorkel and mask if you have one (and wet suit). If not, you can rent from them for $30 per person. There are locals that serve as guides on a volunteer basis. Carlos was a local guy who was AWESOME. Bring cash to tip them. There was also a photographer there that stayed with us for an hour and we got a whole CD full of pictures for $30. Their main crowd are cruise ship excursions so of you are there when there Is not one, you have the whole place to yourself.

Worth visiting! . I was in a group with another couple and had Felix as our guide. He was terrific! Friendly, informative, funny with very good English. It is my first Cenote, so I don't have anything to compare it to, but truly enjoyed seeing the caves.

Hidden Oasis. This place is so beautiful- cheap way to get there is by city van/bus. Lots of sun and great swimming. Rent life jackets and snorkel- nice colors of fish. Pack your lunch and a cold ? Really quite nice to visit.

Great cenote, but don't go to early! . We visited the cenote at 9 o clock in the morning. They forgot the switch on the lights in the biggest cenote. So we were swimming and snorkeling in the dark with a torchlight. For me a great experience, but I can imagine not everybody would like that. But the cenote itself is beautiful and not very busy. All the big tour groups are not visiting, due to the closeness of the cenote to Playa del Carmen. Do you have a day with bad weather and noting to do, go a chap a cab and visit this cenote!

Nice side trip. This is the only cenote we visited during our visit to the Yucatan peninsula so I can't really comment on the price value compared to other cenotes. It was about $30 per person, with snorkel, life vest, hard hat and water shoes. This doesn't include the tip at the end for the guide. Anyway we decided to go because the weather forecast called for rain, which would have not been a good time on the beach. The guide was very patient and knowledgeable. The water was a little chilly but the body does get used to it, and you'll warm up a little after moving around. This was definitely a highlight of our trip.

Awesome history and beauty. 30 US dollars for snorkle and mask, the tour, priceless. When I got there around 9:30, only me and a great guide, Edwin. He knew his history and a cool guy. Stunning views and great experience. A must see and do visiting Playa Del Carmen.
great to see. good to see the under ground lake and even be able to swim in it.never seen any thing like this before

Cenote worth seeing. Our visit here was so cool. We were provided hard hats (for the walk into the Cenotes, they came off when it was time to swim) life vests and flashlights. Our guide was informative and helpful. The scenery was breathtaking with bats, stalactites from above and below in the crystal clear water. There were two Cenotes, one partially open to outside with a beautiful tree growing up through the opening above and the second totally enclosed. Be aware that the water is cool but not unbearable, you get used to the temp very quickly, it's similar to a regular cool swimming pool. Just jump on in and be done. The views are like nothing I've ever seen and shouldn't be missed. There were many levels of fitness and ages, everyone seemed to do just fine. Move slowly as there are slip points and rocks to watch, if you pay attention to where you are going you should be fine. Once we were done with the pools, we were fed a delicious lunch. There was a variety of spice levels to the salsa, tacos, fresh fruit and it was all really good. I'd do this excursion again in a hot second!!

Beautiful. Both cenotes here are beautiful! One partially open and the other closed. We swam in crystal clear water. Admiring both above and below the water with our torch lights. It wasn't too busy which made our experience all the more enjoyable. Our guide, Carlos was soo nice and informative he pointed out cool things and even found his friend Pancho a shy Scorpian Spider! They provided all the equipment- torches, life vests, foot ware. Which were all in good nic I couldn't recommend this enough. Nice and close to catch a taxi from Playa del Carmen.

A must see. We were very excited to see a cenote while in Mexico, however didn't want spend the whole day/a lot of money doing so. This experience was just great! Well worth the money and everyone there was very knowledgeable and helpful. Our guide only spoke Spanish but our photographer was able to translate everything! After the tour we went for a walk and saw spider monkeus as well. The whole tour only took us about 1.5 hours although you could definitely spend linger if you want. Really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone!

Real Gem in Playa del Carmen. We only found out about this cenote thanks to trip advisor reviews, and I'm so glad we did!! We have previously visited another cenote, which at the time was great, but having visited Chaak Tun it put the other one to shame!As recommended we went after 2pm, and true enough we had the whole sink hole, guide and photographer just to ourselves! Amazing experience knowing what cenotes used to be, how they formed and how long for, and just the sheer beauty of them, the formations are within your arms reach, the fish are swimming between your legs, the bats are flying above your head, truly spiritual!!We were very surprised that so many locals never even heard of it! Certainly not to be missed if you're staying in the area!Useful info: entrance fee was 350 pesos incl. wet suit, snorkelling equipment, life jacket helmet and a guideHighly recommend the photographer, which was additional 300 pesos but the photos are incredible!

Lovley. such a amazing beautiful piece of land. Its so amazing how long it takes for this beautiful site to be formed. Good spot for the whole family not only is this spot beautiful but lots of things for the whole family to learn. recommend this spot
Swim the cave. This was amazing. Crystal clear, very cold water. Not for the faint of heart entering and exiting, but well worth it.

Nice & Expensive. to be as synthetic as possible:-I really enjoyed visiting this cenote, I have not seen so much but this one is very cool.-I paid exactly 360 pesos per person (mid Nov) for a 1h visit with a guide + you also have to take a taxi (from downtown : 150 pesos, one way)

Quiet, off the map. Small Cenote, perfect to break me in as I was afraid of being eaten by creatures that live in cenotes. (there are not really any but I have an active imagination). We had a great tour with Felix- they no longer allow folks to go without a tour guide. Other reviews say you can but not anymore. It is not longer 100 pesos, it was 340 pesos- new ownership according to them and they do not negotiate. There may have been a better use of the money but it was very pretty, that included mask, wetsuit, vest and waterproof flashlight. Do not take a tour there if you are staying in Playa. They are a rip off. One attempted to charge us 700 pesos per person! We took a taxi for 150 pesos. Grand total for two: 730 pesos. We made new friends and they drove us back to the playa so we did not take a taxi back. Sweet small place with a little ion about Mayan culture to boot.

Cenote. Perfect water, feeling of mystery and aw as you swim around in this enclosed underground well. Seeing the erosion on the walls, thinking of the spiritual significance of cenotes in Mayan life, an experience worth the effort. Breathtaking experience.

Beautiful!. Went during the last week of October. Cab ride was $200 pesos each way and about 15 minutes long. The admission included a wet suit (which we didn't use, the water was cool but refreshing), water shoes, a snorkel, flash light and tour guide. There are two caverns, the first is larger with beautiful stalagmites and stalactites. We saw catfish, guppies, a little turtle and so many bats! The tour took about an hour. Our cab wasn't there to pick us up so they let us go back in and explore on our own. It was fantastic!
Nature at it's finest. Hard to believe this is minutes from the large bustling city of Playa Del Carmen. Great place to go, snorkeling, underground caves, temescal and more...

Cool place. You get here with a taxi from Playa (ado bus station on 5 Ave) for a 10 minutes. It cost us 200 pesos each way. Entrance is between 20 and 30 USD. The difference is wet suite, snorkels, and flash light

Hidden Gem. -18/10/14This is perfect!A taxi each way cost $140 pecos from Playa. When we arrived there were only 3 other people there and this was on a Saturday Afternoon!!It costs either $35USD for the full package including snorkels, lockers, torches and guide or $25USD for just admission.The extra $10 is defiantly worth it.There are 2 caves, the first one is a bit more like a pool, but the second one is fantastic as you work your way around the nooks and crannys!There is an option for your own photographer with a disc provided for an extra $25 USD but that was a bit too much for me. The tour in total takes 2 hours. However if you need longer you could go back in.Also in ref to "Bring your bolt cutters" comment. There is a locked gate that looks like the entrance about 20 metres closer to Playa. But this place is defiantly open for business!

Beautiful formations! Must do in Playa!. Only a 20 dollar ride from Playa del Carmen, beautiful cenotes with amazing formations.Get there early or late in the afternoon to beat the crowds, 40 dollars to get in with equipment, a little more then other reviewers reported, but I was the only one there. David was my guide and did a great job explaining what the formations were!! Highly recommend!!

Bring your bolt cutters. We went to the cenote by taxi on October 11th, 2014 at 9:00am, after reading reviews on tripadvisor. No one was there and it was appeared to be shut down. Hope we save some people the cab fare!

Wow!. This was an incredible cenote to visit! I think it was about $20 per person and they provide a snorkel, wet suit, and a guide. The tour lasted about 1 hour. There were many formations and they provide a photographer so you do not have to take photos. It was maybe another $20 to purchase the photos. Staff was super friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this cenote!
coba. wonderful the guide was very knowledgable the ruins are beautiful and when the excavation of the rest of the site begins I would very much like to go back to see it
Great guide, beautiful rock formations.. Friendly, knowledgeable guide, beautiful rock formations, plues, its very close to Playa del Carmen.

So wonderful and peaceful.. Grab a taxi and head for the cenotes! The taxi driver will wait and bring you back as well. Four of us went on this trip and I think spent about 30 USD each; well worth it. The guides are exceptionally knowledgeable and swimming in the dark of the freshwater caves is a unique experience. Since these caves are created by rainfall do not expect to see many fish but do listen for the bats! We came towards the end of the day and only had a few more people in our tour group so it was quite intimate. 5/5 - great afternoon trip.
Great diving.. This was a great place to dive. Geology and some fish life. The diving was easy and for those that have not experienced haloclines (when sea and fresh water mix) it is a Must!

Pretty Cool!. Definitely worth going! Caution: very steep stairs and rocks overhead. Water is really cold! Bats in caves and will fly about, especially if you shine your flashlight on them. It is an incredible adventure!

3rd trip to Playa, this was the best!. $20 USD if you have your own equipment, $30 if you don't. You get a guide and a 2 hour tour of the amazing cenotes on the property. We came on a Sunday afternoon and were the only 2 people we saw. Our guide George was funny, informational and overall a great guy to show us the amazing caves.For this price if you want to see some amazing cenotes, it cannot be beat! ** Tip on getting there ** We did get pretty lost...twice. But once we found it we were said, wow so easy! Take Benito Juarez away from the ocean past the highway till you don't think you can possibly be going the right way, through neighborhoods and green nothing. You'll see signs. So close to the town of Playa!
If you get the opportunity to dive -- do it!. Loved the accessability -- walking in with tanks, and the overall experience. . Unworldly We went with Dressel divers, Would recommend

So many Mexican Cenotres... This is the one to see. Such an amazing experience. We did 3 or 4 cenotes swims... all just snorkel, no scuba, but this was by far the best. If you can, ask for Carlos... he was the most sensational tour guide. Very thorough and caring "watch your head!" and super knowledgable. Great experience...
Very rustic and cool. Not as commercialized as others . Lots of swimming , don't go if your not at least a little outdoorsy .

Awesome Experience! Go!. I had read about this particular cenote prior to our vacation to Playa del Carmen the week of 08/30-9/6/14, and it didn't disappoint! The water is a little chilly at first, but doable without a wet suit.. Really cool. The stalagtites and stalagmites were massive, the guide was great, and it really was one of the most interesting and unique experiences I've had - especially on vacation. I wouldn't pass it up.NOTE: In hindsight, I left my camera in the car, for fear of it getting wet - which really is a total bummer because we could've taken some awesome photos in the caves. I would either bring along a waterproof camera from wal-mart, or bring your camera along on the first leg and just leave it in the "staging" cave before you jump in the water. It's too cool not to capture. Also, if you have water shoes - bring and wear them!~250 pesos per person / half price for kids - well worth it

ice cold - cenote swimming. was fresh water- ice cold but refreshing with the extreme heat- very satisfying and such a beautiful natural environment -- there were 3 cenotes all very close connected with walking paths - price was 250 pesos for 2 of us taxi ride rd. trip the same 250= it was a fun time

absolutely amazing!!. I recently went here on an excursion with a carnival cruise. I personally thought it was the most amazing thing id ever seen. Our guide Andy was so much fun and gave us so much history about the place and the culture. The lunch we got was delicious and it was in one of the caves. All in all it was just an amazing day!!!

An Unforgettable Experience. I visited this cenote as part of a tour with The Snorkel Shop. We went into two different cenotes; one was smaller and the other rather large (although the smaller one was still rather big). Our group consisted of five people and the staff was great in making sure that groups were kept separate to allow for a more private and enjoyable experience. I must admit I was a little anxious about going into a cenote as it was my first time. Thinking of the dark, the bats, and the enclosed space sort of bothered me. Once inside I was glad I went. It was an experience I'll never forget (I still wasn't a fan of the bats but they certainly didn't bother us).
