As part of our tour we were given waterproof flashlights, life jackets, and a snorkel and mask. I know that with some tours you can use a wet suit. Being from New Englanders we found the water inside the cenote refreshing and not too cold. The water is crystal clear and there are some smaller sized fish swimming around. The stalactites and stalagmites were incredible. I would highly recommend visiting this cenote!

extreme activity day in the woods. It was one of the atraction during the extreme activity day in the woods .It was a very fun day inc visiting arcological sites , eating lunch in a maya villige that was cooked by them , omega in the forest and more .... Personally ,I don't think that it suitable to come with little kids, but there is lots of other option like water park, swim w dulphin and more other version of trip in the forest that more fit for enjoying the day w kids outside the resort .

Enjoyable dive trip. Great cave diving experience, would recommend to anyone who has never dove caves before. Dive was very well organized, good dive masters, and was fun to meet and dive with new people, who never dove caves before.

Refreshing. I had never been to a cenote.....what an unexpected treat.We had been out in the heat of the day looking at chizen Itza, and were hot.To dive into this "sink hole", was about as enticing and refreshing, as it gets.GO!!

Great site to see on way back from Coba Ruins..... We stopped here on our way back from the Coba Ruins and really enjoyed ourselves. We rented snorkle gear and swam in the underground natural caves (there are bats flying around so beware). It is a little touristy but we did not mind since it was an easy visit from Coba or Tululm. They have fish and slider turtles in the water and it was a very fun experience for my kids and us!

even the concierge didn't know about this one.... Chaak Tun is close to Playa Del Carmen and is relatively unknown so it is less crowded. You take a taxi to the other side of the highway and take a ride into the jungle. the cenote is about 15 minutes from the center of Playa Del Carmen. the people are great - very professional and helpful. there are lockers for your stuff and then they take you with a guide down into the cenotes. the entry fee is $30 US including guide and waterproof light and lifejacket. the first cave is small and is really for getting used to the relatively cold water. then they take you into the much larger cave system and you get to swim into the stalactite covered caves and see the cave roof and underground formations. really a great tour and an unusual experience. Highly recommended. Our guide was Santiago and he was excellent.

Really great experience. I suggest to everyone to see this cenote. To reach it from the city center of Playa del Carmen you have to pass trough some unpavement road (now the build a new asphalt street.)The place is really amazing and the i suggest to ask for Santiago as a guide! He is a funny guy who gonna explain you all the secrets of this caves. The tour is more or less 1.30 hours long and in loco is available to rent all the necessary equipment. In comparison to Gran Cenote this place is a way much better.

Cave snorkelling. We went here after a morning of swimming with the turtles at Akumel Beach - it was OK!! There's a cliff to jump off into the fresh water - a cave to swim into and fish to chomp gently at your feet !!! Not much else there and it was quite busy - not realy my thing but it was different

a lot of fun. a group of 10 of us went through with one guide. we were basically alone as a group throughout the entire tour of the caves. the water was chilly, but with a provided wetsuit on it was very refreshing. the guide (Jorge) was very funny and entertaining. it was about $30 us dollars per person.

Family fun underground. Following TripAdvisor recommendations, I visited this family-fun denote to escape the Mexican heat. I joined a tour with a Spanish-only guide, which was fine because I came to improve my Spanish. A lovely family with two little girls provided delightful entertainment when our guide's explanations went over my head.The management provided a wet suit, locker, mask, and underwater flashlight to equip ourselves for the plunge. Still, the shock of the cold water was unexpected, but a wonderful (though abrupt) shift from the heat of the day. We saw a few fish swimming in the water and many mursielagos--bats--nesting among the stalactites over our heads. The three hours we learned and swam underground passed all too quickly.

Mystical cenote. We hired a car and drove 15 minutes out of Playa del Carmen down a dusty road to this relatively unknown cenote. We had heard that it was more natural than those which are part of big theme parks and we were not disappointed. There are 2 cenotes that take about 2 hours to explore fully with a guide, we took the basic package which was about $20 and did not include flashlights or snorkeling equipment which was quite sufficient. The cenotes are both stunning in their own way and we were lucky enough to visit them alone as we arrived mid afternoon - apparently all the crowds had already dissipated. Highly recommended!!!
Great fun diving!. I like the diving into the cenote with its beautiful natural surrounding and its affordable entrance fee.

Gorgeous. Small. Well set up. Not touristy.. Very close to Playa Del Carmen - so maybe you think "no I should go somewhere far..." Actually no you can stick with this one just 10 min from the city.And it's not an overproduced touristy disneyland either.It's a family run little spot with a big awesome underground cave that is super impressive and a couple others. A Mayan in costume is hanging out to add a little flavor. And only $20 per adult with kids free if you don't swim -- just a really fun 1 hour tour of walking around the cavesIf you swim... also awesome and adds some cost I guess.
Very cool. We loved this cenote. It was so fun. The guide Carlos was fantastic. This is a must do if you are in the Riveria Maya.

swimming beyond belief. My family and I took a cruise to Cozumel Mexico where we took the underwater river tour on the mainland and it was out of this world. Although the water temperature was very cold, somewhere around 60 to 65 degrees, it still was extraordinary. We went to the smaller cave to swimming in the river and get cooled off, where we were able feel how cold the water was. From there we proceeded to the large cave to swim. They provided each of us with helmets to protect our heads, a flotation vest and swim mask. We then made our way down to the river inside the cave, all the while ducking and squatting to keep from hitting the rocks growing all around us. Seeing all the nooks and crannies where bats were and watched as they flew all around. Once we made it down to the entry point we were given a waterproof flashlight to use and jumped in. The water was crystal clear and you could see all the way to the bottom, on average from 10 to 15 feet deep. There were many places you could stand but the most fun was swimming around in the deeper areas. After swimming and exploring for about a hour, we stepped out of the river and proceeded to another section of the cave where we were provided with an authentic Mayan lunch. I have seen and done many things in my life but I never would have thought I would be swimming in a river inside a cave. This is one attraction I recommend you try if you happen to go to this part of Mexico.

directions, directions, directions. first of all, its great! Jorge is a great guide, very funny and interesting and knowledgable. very beautiful place. it's $30 american to tour, plus the tip for your guide, which you need if it's your first time. if your coming Southwest on 307, go past the exits for Playa and take a right Av Benito Juarez, then go 5km and the destination is on the right. it took us a while to finds the place because of poor directions and this is a very little known place. so here you go! very easy to get to when you know how to get there.

Awesome and FUN!. We visited Chaak Tun during a western cruise and we had a blast! The tour guides were knowledgeable and lots of fun! The caves and underground rivers were spectacular and the water was crystal clear. The tour provided an authentic lunch afterward, and allowed us time to ask any questions about the area. They provide life vests and goggles, so it's great for small kids. HIGHLY recommend!!

Local guide through Playa Cenote. Fantastic. Virgin cenote without the crowds so maybe I shouldn't tell. We asked the concierge, Carlos at the Playa Palms and he set us up with a private guide, George. We snorkeled through the cenotes, saw the bats, incredible birds, and local jungle. George is extremely knowledgeable. The tour was adventurous and very reasonable without the lines and crowds.All snorkeling equipment and transportation included.

Authentic Experience. Although we went to this cenote without a guide, it was fascinating — the sights, the sounds and the smells! The water was cool and refreshing and we could see and hear bats. The food was also wonderful and home-cooked. Highly recommend it.

Beautiful…In a different world. This was a very unique adventure and to be able to swim through the Cenote was very cool. The water is clear and refreshing. The rock formations are pretty amazing. We were a little scared of other reviews that said they saw lots of spiders and snakes, we are not fans of either and we saw none. So we will live in our ignorance happily and gladly recommend this place. Jorge was a great guide. One thing I will say, is that none of the lockers actually lock. They seem as if they do but they do not. So I would not bring any valuables with you. Just a change of clothes or a towel for when you are done. They provide water shoes, life jackets, and goggles.

It was a-ok but toooo expensive. We did buy our own equipment and went there again and this time did buy the entry. It was two dry cenotes areas just for walking in (like caves) and 2 wet ones for swimming. Only one of the swimmable ones was interesting as it looked tiny from outside and had depths that you could see inside. Nothing super beautiful or even colorful like the big lake ones a little away from town. Ten or fifteen minutes of swimming in each wet ones plus walking around the cave ones. The only good thing is that at that price, it is not crowded especially since these are small swimming areas in small caves.
Beautiful. We did this after the Chitzen Itsa, so the ''refreshing'' water was great. Very beautiful as the sun streamed through the hole above the cave/sink hole

The coolest thing I did in Playa del Carmen.. The cave entrance is beautifully located in the jungle just outside Playa del Carmen. The gentleman who greeted us at the counter was super nice and told us how the cave tour worked. Our guide, a cool young guy named David, knew everything about those caves and could swim like a fish. The tour only took about two hours but we learned a lot and saw turtles, bats and tiny little catfish. I highly recommend this cenote tour if you're looking for a beautiful natural setting and a rad guide at an affordable price.
Awesome. We all loved this place, 2adults, 14yo, 6yo. Beautiful water. Awesome caves. Bats were not a bother. Wonderful lunch in cave. Would definitely go back.

Great Experience. My girl friend and I decided to do this spur of the moment style. It was $36.00 a person for ecerything. Snorkle, wet suit, locker, wet shoes, etc. They don't tell you this but you have to have a tour guide. You also have to tip him. He said the minimum is usually $10.00 usd. We gave him 15.00. Not for the faint at heart. The water is dark and it's deep and you must travel by water. You can touch certain things. It's really dark and almost scary! You can see tons of bats, spiders, fish, etc. We were lucky enough to see a turtle :-D. There is one part where you have to let go of the life jacket and swim through an underwater cave. We opted not to do that because we are chickens :-p. Make sure you wear the wetsuit. The water is super cold. All in all, great price for 2 hours. I highly recommend. Just take the road that the ferry to Cozumel is on all the way west and you will run into it on your right. It's past the main highway and past the check point you come across.

Great place to visit in Playa. I recommend to anyone wanting adventure for a reasonable price in Playa to visit Chaak Tun. For $36 USD you get a tour guide (in my case it was just my husband and me), a flash light, goggles, a wet suit, a locker for storage, and a hard hat. They take you through two different cenotes and explain the cave, the various formations, point out the wild life (mostly spiders, bats, birds, and catfish) and let you explore the various parts of the cave uninterrupted. We were staying in Playa, so we just paid a taxi to drive us there and wait for us to finish (it takes about 1 - 1 1/2 hours to explore). But we could have just had him drop us and then called before viewing the second cenote (a smaller quicker cave to explore) and that would have worked out just as well. I highly recommend spending time at Chaak Tun. I didn't visit other cenotes to compare, but from what I've read, heard and could tell, this experience trumps all of the other nearby cenotes. One more thing, be sure to take directions because many cabs and hotels aren't familar with this cenote yet.

close to playa del carmen. Only a short drive from playa del Carmen. We paid $20US each, I had my own mask/snorkel, my daughter preferred to free dive with her swim goggles. They provided lifejackets and underwater flashlights and guide (mandatory). We arrived between 1-2 pm, had a guide to ourselves. Lots of interesting formations, both under and above water.

The guys (60's) loved it here!. A perfect spot to relax and cool off after the heat of Tulum. I wasn't brave enough to give it a try but my husband and friends thoroughly enjoyed themselves in spite of the crowds of other "bathers". I was the official photographer and that was enough for me :). A unique and beautiful place. Almost eerie.

wonderful natural experience. Our guide Roberto took us to 2 cenotes and showed us around underground caves. We paid 360 pesos per person and gave 200 pesos to the guide ( they work on tips). We enjoyed the experience very much. The caves are natural, no touristy gimmicks like Xplor/xcaret etc., really liked it :)
pretty cenotes. Clear, cool waters, nice guide and a few minutes sitting in complete darkness. Nice, quick trip from the centre of Playa.

great adventure. Our first time in playa.I love to experience adventures off the beaten path. We took our 2 boys,20&22 they really enjoyed the two hours exploring the cenote and caves. Our guide was informative and let us take our time to enjoy the trip.it was difficult to plan as they are not highly advertised. We read a review that recommended to go in the afternoon. We arrived at2:00pm and had a guide to Ourselves. I would get a waterproof camera....

Nearby treasure.. Just across the main highway on Juarez (same road as the ferry). Get on that, cross the highway and in about 5 mins you run into on the right hand side. Cost $25 pp if you have your own snorkel and water shoes. Comes with a helmet, life jacket and a guide. I think it's $35 for entrance and full rental with guide. We were a group of seven but when we entered the first cave we quickly became a group of five! This excursion is not for the claustrophobic! I loved it! Bats and all! Wasn't a lot to see under water but the caves were amazing, our guide was fun and you can't beat the price. I read in 2009 it was $3.50 to get in. The price seems to increase the more popular this gets. We opted to go without life jackets but eventually put them on because trying to take pictures without them was too hard.

Great Experience!!. I picked this excursions from Carnival cruise, and it was the best experience. The tour guide "ANDY" he is the best. Great service, beautiful experience... priceless moments, If you want to have a great experience... you have to be there.

Unadvertised adventure close to Playa Del Carmen. Refreshing mineral water in cool caves. Snokeled and used a underwater flash light with a guide leading the way. See before it becomes over crowded with tourists.
Awesome. I have never seen anything quite so stunning !!! I was speechless , this should not be missed ! I loved everything , real Mexico

Not to be missed!!!!. Chaak Tun was absolutely amazing. Its an easy drive and easy to find. The road is now paved to the location, straight out of town with no turns to make, on Juarez Ave. We are a party of five at times prone to laziness and hesitant of adventure, our ages ranging from 10 to 67. We all were thrilled with our outing. After we were outfitted with a torch, wetsuit, shoes, and helmet, we were led down into a cavern. There we were met by our guide, Jorge, who was essential to our good time as he pointed out the stalagmites, stalactites, and how they are formed. We squiggled through caverns, swam through crystal clear waters and were awed by the majesty created by nature. Everyone was thrilled with their experience and very glad that we came. The staff was friendly and wanted to ensure our enjoyment. I would thoroughly recommend this experience which was just 350 pesos but worth so much more to all of us.

Best for Snorkeling!!!. Chaak Tun is by far the best cenote for snorkeling! It is absolutely stunning. You enter in to a sink hole then into the caves. Once in the water, you snorkel through stalagmites and stalactites, in crystal clear water. It is artificially lit and really well run. It is a little hard to get to as it is in the jungle, but if you can arrange a tour then do not miss it.

All can say is wow!. So much more natural than something like Explor and ten times cooler. I went on my own via a taxi from playa, which cost me about 150 pesos. The entrance fee was 350, and for that I got torch hire, wet shoe hire and guide. I was told you couldn't do this without the guide and to be honest aftera few minutes in the cave I could see that even if I could, I wouldn't have wanted to go without one. It's not really for the faint of heart, so if you get clostraphobic you might want to think twice. That said it should be pointed out that this really isn't dangerous, as long as you listen and do what the guide says. The really great thing about the guide was he was sooooo patient. Everything was do you want to do take photos here, do you want to do this, etc. I never once felt rushed, which was quite refreshing to be honest. All I can say is just go. Forget the other places that charge the earth and often have an artificial feeling about them. Certainly two of the best hours I have spent in this region. One important point to mention is that this place whilst close to playa is actually out in the middle of nowhere, so if you go by taxi I would recommend asking them to come and pick you up later, which they will usually do. And don't be a fool and go try walking back. When they say, it's a jungle out there, in this case they actually mean it. If people want to camp they need a permit from the government, this helps them work out where to collect the bodies once the jaguars have finished with them.... Joking aside locals in the region do get killed by them, so don't ruin your holiday by becoming a toothpick... Again, it's all safe as long as you are sensible.

What an adventure!. A unique Mexican adventure. I rappelled down a long rope into a deep cave, at the floor of this cave was a deep pool of wonderfully cool, refreshing water. I was in an ancient/sacred Cenote. I swam, splashed and dived in mineral dense water. Had a GREAT time!

Cenote Chaak Tun Av. Juarez, Playa del Carmen, Mexico. Interesting day trip from our hotel. First we toured Chitchen Itza, our guide was very knowledgeable explaining about the Mayan ruins and the people's way of life. Our lbuffet unch was included at the hotel on site. Then on to the caves where you take stairs built in the rock to reach the underwater pond. After our dip into the water went on to this wonderful medieval town of Villadolid. We returned to the Royal at the end of a long but very interesting day.This visit took place last February while at the Royal Playa del Carmen.

Wonderfull Experience/Must see!. Visited the Cenotes Oct 2013. Beautifull underwater caves, fantastic formations, very large..quite the experience! Guide kept it well lit for us and took gorgeous pictures for us. Water is cold,but you get used to it right away. It's just one of those places you need to experience..mother nature has again outdone herself!

Loved Chaak Tun. We discovered the Chaak Tun cenote through the Playabus tour. It is great that this group of cenotes are located so close to Playa. You just head straight across the highway and stay on Juarez Avenue. Was a great few hours snorkeling/swimming and discovering the underwater caverns and experiencing total silence and darkness in one when we all shut down our lights and were quiet for 5 mins. True relaxation! A must do if you like discovering all the cenotes in the mayan riviera. They have everything there that you need..snorkel equipment, water shoes (we'd bring our own next time), helmets if you want them, life jackets if you want them, and there is a person taking pictures if you like. Picture purchase price is $10. It was 200 pesos to get in.

CENOTE LIFE. If youve never visited a cenote then your missing out. Even if you just go down the stairs it will put a smile on your face. Unless your a miner it's probably deeper than you have every been. If you swim in it's cool, clean and clear water you'll experience joy.

Best excursion I've ever been on. This excursion was great. It was well organized and planned. As soon as your get off the ship they have a sign where you pick up a sticker which gets you on a nice air conditioned ferry ride to Playa Del Carmen. The boat ride can be a little bumpy, so try to find a seat in the center of the boat. Once at Playa Del Carmen you are met with your excursion guide who than places you into a nice air conditioned bus that takes you directly to Cenote Chaak Tun. On the way they give some history of the caves and also some history of Mexico. There's some interesting information shared by the guides. Upon arrival you are given water shoes, life jackets, lockers and helmets. After you change you make your way through the forest to the cave where you are met by a Mayan priest. A brief history is given about the Mayan people and than you begin to enter the caves.The caves are a great experience. the water is fresh and crystal clear. There are some deep sections, but you have a life vest so there's no reason to panic. You also see some fruit bats, which are harmless. You will get some amazing pictures If you bring a water camera, however they have a photographer which has photos for purchase. The tour lasted about 90 mins.After the cave excursion you are taken to another cave for a great Mexican buffet. The food is really good and drinks are provided. You are than taken back to Playa Del Carmen where you can go to the beach, shop or go to the bars. The beach is beautiful so make you to check that out also. Your tour guides designate a meeting place where you will catch the bus back to the ferry to Cozumel. This was a great excursion, definitely worth the money, they take care of everything and the food is great. I highly recommend it.

Perfect Way to Spend the Afternoon. During our third consecutive Xmas in Playa, we ventured out in our rental car to check out our first cenote. I would say that this experience couldn't have been any better. Besides myself and my husband (mid 30s), we brought our 2 children (3 and 8) and my parents (mid 50s). Although it was over the busy holiday, it wasn't crowded and all of us were able to enjoy the cenotes. The first cenote was perfect and the entry was so easy that our daughter with Cerebral Palsy was able to walk down on her own. I felt the whole experience was do-able because there was no pressure. There was no tour that hurried you along; you could enter the water and explore at your own pace. The experience we had here has made us all excited to check out some of the more remote cenotes.

Not easy to get to, but worth going. „Not easy to get to, but worth going“ - If you’re staying in PDC, I recommend going. I can’t judge if this is the most beautiful cenote there is in Yucatán, but it was the only one that was within reach for my partner and me. We were able to swim and snorkel in two beautiful caves which was an unforgettable experience. I especially liked the fact that it was not overcrowed like so many other cenotes seem to be. On site we were equipped with wet suits, snorkel goggles and flashlights and accompanied by a guide and a photographer to each cave. They tended to disappear from time to time without any further note, and in the end it was the photographer who gave us some information about the place. But we saw interesting rock formations, bats, motmot birds and even fish. The place doesn’t seem to be advertised much, so I could not gather much information before going. The only way getting to the cenote is by taxi. It took us appr. 20 mins from downtown PDC going all the way down on Avenida Benito Juarez. We forgot to arrange a pick-up with the taxi driver, but our guide was kind enough to drop us off at the main street after the tour to grab a taxi. All in all, the place is not enough taken care of and staff appeared to be disorganised, but we enjoyed it very much.
Amazing!. Swimming in a Cenote with a guide for 35$ a person is a bit pricey but it is very nice and very natural!

scuba in air. If you've never tried this it is well worth it. The haloclines and thermocline (hope I spelled this correctly) are visible and like moving between oil and water. Loved the cathedral ceilings.

Not a secret anymore (and they know it) but still pretty awesome. A couple of 2014 updates; many taxi drivers in playa now know this one and will try to charge around 300 pesos for taking you there and back. We, holding on to out pride and the fact that it's quite close by, decided to rent a scooter. We saved 30 pesos, our dignity and had much more fun. The admission now costs 240 pesos per person (we had our own snorkeling equipment). At first we were told that this is the cheapest admission, and includes a life vest and a helmet (.....what?) and a flashlight. Then, all of a sudden, the same "head guy" told us that all inclusive price is 360 pesos, and the flashlights were not included in the admission anymore, but he could rent us the flashlight for 100 pesos per flashlight. I went berserk about it and said some less friendly things. After that, we got the nicest private tour guide, Carlos. He didn't make us use the tedious life vests or helmets, showed us where to go, including a dive throug an underwater tunnel (a little panic-provoking but fantastic) and in the end, left us completely alone with two flash lights to explore the amazing caves and tunnels that we almost got lost in. There are alltogether three separate larger caves, two of them can be explored together by diving through the underwater tunnel, and one (the one on the left side of the reception) having endless small passages that can be explored with a flash light, partly by foot (shallow water) and partly by swimming. I suppose there is more artificial lighting in the smaller passages nowadays, but large parts are still pitch black, with some backround screeches from the bats flying above. I doubt that any cenote open to public will top this one. Be careful with the prices, but enjoy some serious cave-exploring!

The kids loved it. Took the trip to this cenote as a cruise shore excursion and am very pleased with the value. The kids thought it was great and so did the adults. Don't go if you're very claustrophobic, some of the places can get a bit narrow to navigate. I have a little bit of claustrophobia, but sucked it up and went anyway and enjoyed it very much. The guides were pleasant, informative and helpful.

great experience. We paid $140 for an 8-hour tour with Eco-Alltournatives, started 8:30am pick-up from our hotel, went Tulum ruins with a guided tour till 10:30am, 30 minutes shopping outside the ruins. An half drive to the mayan local community where we had lunch, we rapel down a sinkhole, drove a 4x4 jeep; zipline 3x, we had a backward-zipline and 3rd where we ended up inside a cave with fresh water, snorkel. Then we had to walk half hour to the jungle back where we started. It was pretty good for the price and service was excellent. Also the lunch that was prepared by the local mayans. I will do it again but next time I won't get trick of not bringing my water camera.

Great experience. From Cozumel we took the tour to Isla del Carmen, that means a bait ride for 40 minutes. If weather is good no problem but it can be a bit windy & choppy sea so be careful if you tend to get seasick. Make sure to have your swimsuit, towel & sweater. The car ride to the caves is for about 15 minutes, you will arrive at the first simple and plain installations where you can change, store your clothing, they will give you water shoes & you can use the toilets. Then you go down into the rain forest towards the caves where you will have some information regarding the Yucatan peninsula & the area. They will give you mask, snorkel & life jackets if you feel you will need it. The limestone caves are awesome!! The guide will swim with the group & will show all the stalagmites & stalactites formations, water is cool but enjoyable. After this beautiful experience the tour includes lunch -surprise- & they will offer a Mexican lunch, simple but very tasty inside another cave which makes it very original. Once it is finished, they will take you to the shopping area where you can go on your own for about 1:30 hours. Very nice area but very expensive! After that you will be taken back to the pier where you will take the boat back to Cozumel.

Take a dip in pristine waters. I went here as part of a tour, going first to Coba and then here. A guide took us back here and after walking for a while to the jungle came across the cenote. There was a small changing area made of wood from the forrest just outside of it and some people there selling snacks and trinkets. It wasn't what I'd expected at first, but as I let go of my expectations and just went with it I found myself enjoying it more.As an attraction, it's really just fresh water in an unusual container with some fish in it. Being down in the deep cave isn't necessarily thrilling in the sense that it's moderately dangerous nor connected to the history of the people there in some significant manner, but I still found it quite enjoyable. The guide gave a history of how someone had once managed with the assistance of scuba equipment to follow the underground caverns some hundred plus miles to go out to the sea. Whether or not that's true or just an interesting story I don't know - but being in there it was neat to imagine doing that.If you want to test your upper body strength, try doing what the guides do and climb up the rope rather than being pulled up. I managed to get all the way to the top, but was then quite hot and sweaty.

Beautiful and mysterious!. We visited the cenote as part of a snorkel tour and were amazed at the beauty and serenity of the place. The location was not crowded and appeared to be well managed. The swim through the caves was a special treat--looking forward to a future visit.
Thefts are there. 100usd was stolen from locker box. The cenote was good though. If you go to this place, make sure you know spanish. You don't need a guide. AGAIN, WATCH YOUR BELONGINGS!
Fresh Clear Water Anyone?. The smell of the water here is awesome! Gotta go if you like to swim. Truly a magical experience. Spiritual refresher for anyone who is looking to breathe.

Kid Friendly. Great time make sure you ask your cab driver to stay and wait for you great experience, closes about 5 so allow yourself about 2-2.5hrsbring your own snorkels if you have them and you don't really need any of the other gear

A bit overpriced. I didn't read about the cheaper option to explore the caves for 240 pesos, so we paid the 360, however the caves were a once in a lifetime experience!We had such a good time. It took a little over two hours. Arrange to have a cab take you out and bring you back (for about 400 pesos from downtown). The snorkeling was so fun! We had three children and four adults and we all had a great time! (even pre-teens who are hard to please).
awesome!!!!!. Part of our Chichen Tour... amazing.. got to take a swim... loved it!!! Restaurant near by and bathrooms available.

Nice cenote. I don't think it's that important to go see this cenote...It's nice, but I wouldn't go back! Some swam in the water, it was clear bleue water. Nice to see, but don't change your plans to go there! There must be other cenotes much more interesting.

All kitted out. I really enjoyed this tour.it was easily accessible from playa del Carmen by taxi.we just turned up and they brought us in straight away and kitted us out.it was only 360pesos which was a lot cheaper than other cenotes.it was great.the tour guide was really helpful and answered all my questions.great value and fun snorkelling

cenotes trip. My son and I had the side tour of our lives.This is a full day of fun.First we went into one cenote where we sorkeled in a cave with a lot of fossils visible in the rocks.Our guides explained how they got there and the different ones.Next we kiacked down a small river(at our leisure)Next cenote we zip lined into the water (twice,very neat).We also rappeled down into a cave(about 60 feet)and did some swimming.We had a lunch.This is a MUST tour.WE had a pick up at our resort at 9;30 and got back around 6;00.Truely an amazing tour.

Unforgetable. We were among a small group of visitors from a cruise ship. I had no idea what to expect. The experience was almost holy. Quiet beauty in the crystal clear deep water. Planning to go back to Playa del Carmen next year and you can bet there will be time made to see this incredible site.

Just magical!. We visited Chaak Tun for one day and had an incredible diving experience! lots of wild life to see, don't miss it if you're in the area. Very easy to get here, around 10 minutes away from downtown Playa.

Beautifully unique experience.. I was a little apprehensive as this place was a bit out of the way and I was the only one there. But the man at the desk explained everything to me, and then I changed and headed out with my guide, Carlos. We had the entire place to ourselves which was both wonderful and a bit scary. Carlos talked and joked with me the whole time making me feel comfortable in the dark. He slowly and patiently took me through all the caves, pointing out many things as we went along, like bats and a turtle. The water is fresh, but not cold. He also took a few photos of me with my camera, which was super nice as I am travelling alone and it's difficult to snap a good selfie while swimming ;)It took about an hour and a half, I think, to see all three caves but you can take as long as you want. The admission price is 360 pesos ($30) and includes water shoes (you will NOT be able to wear flip flops), life jacket, helmet, and a waterproof flashlight which you will definitely need. These gorgeous cenotes are totally undeveloped, with the exception of a couple of paths and a small platform/stairs.Don't let a little fear keep you from having a very unique experience!!

Way too costly. We finally arrived to this off-the-beaten-path cenote only to be asked to pay 1,000 pesos or $80 USD. We are two adults with two kids under the age of ten. The price kept us from even entering, as we thought it was too high. They were not willing to negotiate. There are plenty of cenotes in Mexico without the high charge.

snorkeling here is a MUST. The water is fresh and crisp. You get used to the temperature after a few moments, and it's so lovely around you you get caught up in snorkeling and watching the fish below you.

Highlight of our trip. Nothing short of amazing. I think it's mainly used for cruise ship tours, so not every taxi driver is familiar with it. But that said, there was nothing about it that felt touristy. The only bummer was the lack of regulation as far as people touching and apparently breaking the stalagtites. As always, bargain your taxi price. I believe you should pay no more than $100mxn each way. Tell them it is at the end (it's not really the end but they will get it) of Juarez and also make sure that they come back to get you in a couple of hours as you will be on a dirt road with zero taxis coming by. They told us the entry fee was $250mxn and well, lets just say that we paid much less than that. It seems the price is a bit flexible.We had read that we should wait until after 1 or 2 in the afternoon when the cruise tours are gone but we got there at noon to a group of loud obnoxious Americans that their guide had to yell at to be quiet! They were decked out in wetsuits, river shoes, and hard hats but we were just fine in bare feet and swim suits. I normally get very cold in water but I was in such awe that I never even got a chill. I would even say that snorkel/mask is optional. I used mine and my friend did not and I don't think her experience was any less because of it.They supplied us a guide free of charge (please tip though) which was great. We swam / walked through beautiful caverns with crystal clear water. I have a bit of a phobia in some water but here I never felt creeped out or claustrophobic. Sure some people might though. Well in cave #2 which we went to solo, there was no light and no people. I tried to swim to the caven opening and was quite freaked out by the darkness which gave my friend a good laugh as she watched from shore after starting "Oh hell no."So anyway....two thumbs up for Chaak Tun!

Off the beaten path. If you like being off the tourist trail, this beautiful cenote is the place to be. I was fortunate to be on a small tour in the jungle when we explored Cenote Chaak Tun. Stalactites are amazing as was swimming in the space among the cave wildlife. And other people.

Very cool cenote with private tours. This hidden gem was a real treat, off the beaten path of the major attractions that gives you a real sense of adventure. Bring your underwater flashlight, snorkel gear and swimsuit and get ready for an adventure into the unknown. The guides are very friendly and helpful.

A little Oasis. An Oasis hidden in the jungle, amazing site deep clear water, and a great experience to swim in or just dip in after a long hot day being a tourist - just beautiful and a superb experience
enjoy!!!. It's a nice place,,...prepare your wet suite if not they have it there for rent! enjoy your time there. water is a little bit cold but overall experience was positive.

Exciting snorkel. Make sure you have your wet suit on as the sun doesn't touch this clear water a bit slippy getting in but a good snorkel round a must experience for water lovers very nice experience

Amazing experience. One of the greatest experiences on any trip. Snorkel in the cool waters of this combination cenote / cavern. It seems, though, the prices are highly flexible as we were asked for USD 30.00 entrance fee, and when we winced a bit at the price, the manager lowered the fee to around USD 20.00 with no charge for the kids. All in all a very good experience, however.
Worth the money!. Amazing, a scuba diving experience like no other. Worth the money! A bit of a walk from where you set up to where you enter the water.

A must!. This is by far the best part of our travels so far through Mexico and Central America. We saw information about the cenote on a blog online and decided to have a go at walking there from our hostel in Playa del Carmen. Despite being #4 on TA very few of the locals know of this place (we were stopped and offered help by at least 4 locals who thought we were out of our minds!) but it does exist and it is truly beautiful! My husband and I were fortunate enough to have the place to ourselves when we arrived. From the cool waters, to the amazing bats and serenity of the place, this has to be seen to be believed. The guys at the entrance and those that helped see us into the two cenotes were great too. A must if you're in the Playa area!!
Fun snorkel & swim in cave trip. Great day away from the beach, but still a day in the water. Excellent guides are available and comfortable transportation. A very enjoyable day!

Amazing. Its a must! incredible diving experience!!! all planed out and a full dive brief. there is a cafe to get a hot lunch from there. Just be aware of the bathrooms.... pretty bad very dirty and Im sure the mozzies in there were on steroids!!!

By far the best part of our vacation!. We actually took this as an excursion from our cruise ship, and far exceeded our dreams. Our tour guide was from Xplor, named Pablo, and was a delight as a guide and travel companion! Before entry to the cenote, we were given a brief review of Mayan history and the importance of the rivers to the ancient Mayans (about 15 minutes). We were then blessed by a Mayan Priest before entering the cenote through a wooden walkway. This walkway with handrail was easy to navigate for all ages, and I am 55. After wading through the cenote for a few hundred yards, it opened into a large room, which had an opening from above, that was simply majestic. Here, we were able to take off our helmets, (so we didn't hit our heads while getting there on the cave ceiling) and swim in relative freedom, although we still had life vests on. We went the day after a tropical storm hit, so the water level was high, yet rarely over our heads. After further exploration, we returned to this room and we allowed to swim without life vests, if we were comfortable in doing so. I truly never wanted to leave this place, ever....

Amazing! Magical! Must See!!. Loved this place a must see!! very relaxing! place offers hotel, restaurant, lockers. Only recommendation best to go on your own instead of tour guide, less expensive and more time to really enjoy this wonderful place.

Beautiful Cenote tour guide was great. the Cenote was beautiful, lots of wild life to see, water was very cool be prepared for swimming in cool water even in the summer the area was a little hard to get to they are working on the roads but if was worth the drive
Like nothing I've ever seen. The food was not worth the price. They fed us toasted bread with beans and cucumber salad. You have the option of purchasing the trip only, do that instead.
Beautiful. Cenote is very beautiful, the water is low, has little fishes that bite deathskin off you, it don't hurt.

Refreshing water and an amazing natural wonder. I went to Chaak Tun as part of an excursion with the Snorkel Shop Northern Surf and Turf Tour and was so amazed by the natural beauty of it. The water was so refreshing and the vampire bats were a bit freaky at first but then you get so immersed in the cenote, you forget they are there. Memo, our guide thru the Snorkel Shop (which I highly recommend as a tour company) made sure we were safe with helmets, life jackets and torches and pointed out amazing details to us. Catfish swim all along the bottom and the visibility was so clear. The bottom of the cenote looks so soft but it is many feet down and untouchable by me. Great timing for our visit because as we entered the cenote it was full of people but as we came out, everyone was gone and we got to jump and play in the water all alone. I would of reviewed this cenote thru the Snorkel Shop but I am new to Trip Advisor and thought I could review each tour separately as well as the company, but it turns out only one review per person, regardless of how many tours or times you visited. My apologizes to Graham and I hope you see this link!

Amazing underground experience picture cannot put into words!. We just got back from Chaak Tun and I have to say it was unbelievable! It was a bit of an excursion though, we thought we could walk it from town but after an hour, we flagged down a taxi and made it! Which worked out in our favour. We arrived around 2:30 and had the place all to ourselves! Adam got us situated and Carlos took us to the first big cave. It was amazing being in there by ourselves with the piece and quiet. The waters were cool and we explored all around. We were then taken to the second cave where you can swim to a secret cave! This was an awesome experience having this other world to ourselves. I highly recommend going after the rush, about 2-3pm. That way you still have 1:30 mins to explore. The price is well worth it, and if you didn't bring an underwater flashlight, they have everything you need. And it's worth the price. Thanks to Carlos for taking us through and Adam for saving us by driving us back to town! You guys rock! If you go by taxi, make sure you get them to come back at least 2 hours later. You seriously HAVE to go! And thanks again to Adam for the tips on more things to do in playa on the cheap.

Awe inspiring Cenotes. While staying in Playa Del Carmen we took a cab to this cenote. Had researched it before hand on TA and thought I had seen the cost was about $100 pesos pp. Well, i was wrong..it is 200 pesos per person. Also we knew to bring our own snorkeling stuff but one of the group did not. It cost her about 50 pesos for the mask and snorkle. However, the guy at the cenote was telling us that the underwater flashlight would be 30 pesos; the locker was 20 pesos and i can't remember what the guide would cost. He told us we could have all the above for 260 pesos each (including the guide) but once we told him we did not need certain things he broke it down to "ala carte" prices. The first cenote is awesome! it is literally in a cave, which is very dark, but for a couple of lights. When we went there was no one else there (about 11:30am) and it was a little spooky..there were some bats flying around us. It is circular fresh water. Great experience. The second cenote has a small opening which you could see the sky outside. This one was larger then the first but there was alot of parts you really could not swim in. There was heavy "muck" in those places. As long as you stay where the ropes are you will be fine. Really interesting and highly recommended. My only issue is that when we went last year to the Gran Cenote (outside Tulum) it was larger and able to swim all over it for approx 100 pesos. The guy told us the "prices" went up last november. There is also a dry cave you can explore, we did not as we really just wanted to do swimming.

Connect with nature. It is an unbelievable experience with real nature. water is so clear cold beautiful, and the rocks formations are just something else! Very easy to get here, around 10 minutes away from downtown Playa. If you can bring your own waterproof flash light will be better,they will charge you the same fee for the flash light and for the entrance, AND YOU WILL NEED ONE!! But this is a most see place, better than going to any of those fictitious parks.
Grand Cenote. This was approximately 10 minutes from Tulum Ruins. It was great to swim in the cave. Everyone enjoyed it.

Unbelievable!!!. Before our family vacationed in Mexico, we researched interesting things to do in the Playa del Carmen area. We came across reviews for Chaak Tun. We read that most hotel staff and taxi drivers would not even know where it was... TRUE. We read that it is off the bumpiest road in Mexico... TRUE. We read that it was not to be missed... VERY, VERY TRUE!!! Amazing doesn't even cover it! We were taken to three cenotes (basically sinkholes). Two of them are filled with water and are absolutely breath-taking! We had Adam as our guide. He was very fun and knowledgeable. He had us rub decomposed limestone on our faces as a facial... But it didn't stop there! In the next cenote he presented us with our pedicures... little guppies nibbling at our toes! (Beware ladies... do not let your husbands claim this as your spa day, as mine tried!) I was so worried about what types of life forms we would encounter... We saw bats (we didn't bother them / they didn't bother us), some catfish, tiny guppies, a cricket... That was pretty much it! We searched for "Lupita" - a cricket-eating spider, but did not find her. I was okay with that! :) To get to the last part of the tour, we had to swim underwater from one cave to the next! It wasn't difficult to do, only a few seconds underwater. My 6 and 8 year olds did it easily with Adam's guidance. Getting to swim into a "secret cave" was one of the highlights of their trip! The only sketchy thing was that their bathroom facility was currently enjoying a facelift... I'm sure it will be beautiful upon our next visit!The total cost of our self-made excursion was $120 for our family of four. This included entrance to the cenotes (discounted for the children) and a taxi ride. We negotiated that the taxi driver stayed while we visited, so it cost a little more than normal. It was only about a 20 - 25 minute ride there.Be sure to take bug spray for the part of the tour. The mosquitoes in Mexico are no joke! I wish I could give this place more than 5 stars!

Warning! Costs have doubled!. Just like every reviewer has stated. This is a beautiful cenote. But, the base cost for people not in a tour (which are usually overpriced) has doubled from $100 pesos a person to $200 a person. It’s still $100 pesos if you can prove you live or work in Playa.The guy at the desk said it was orders from the new management/owners. And, he didn't budge and inch on negotiation. With a clear tone of “take it or go F yourself”. For Quintana Roo his behavior was very aggressive, and I’m saying this as a two year resident of Mexico on my 3rd trip to the state. It is especially weird because the guides who work there are quite friendly and helpful.It’s sad because this is now the most expensive "non-tour" Cenote in the Yucatan with no amenities! No snack bar. No beverages except those provided with a guide package. Not sure what the new owners are thinking, but repeat business doesn’t seem to be a concern.If you just have time for one cenote and don't care about the cost. It's a good choice, but there are a dozen other great ones usually costing $50 to $100 pesos, with much better service and less hassle.
stunning. Incredible cenote, if you can find it! Juan, our guide, was great with his perfect english and fun anecdotes. Dont miss it if you're in the area. We had the place to ourselves at 3pm today.

Very interesting!. New experience for us - extensive underwater formations, fish & stalagmites viewed through crystal clear waters.
Definitely need a guide to do the entire loop.
Excellent cenote to dive. Amazing light effects, crystal clear water, easy access, beautiful formations of stalgmites - a must see

Best part of our trip. I visited this cenote, located just outside of Playa del Carmen, with two teenagers. It's an amazing experience!! Juan, our tour guide, was informative, fun, laid back, and welcoming. We tipped him $20 at the end (he works solely for tips) and it was WELL worth it! This cenote experience includes three cenotes, some underground "river" type experiences, and a guided tour. We brought our masks and snorkles, but you could do with or without them. We were the only family there (we got there about 10am) and it was a personal, one-on-one experience as opposed to the "theme park" experiences of the larger cenotes. This is the real deal. All four of us agreed that it was the highlight of our time in Playa, Tulum, Chichen Itza, and the environs. Can't say enough!!

A cenote and caving experience. We had a great experience here too. First we had to find out how to get there - our hotel concierge in Playa del carmen had not heard of this cenote, so we decided to ask taxi drivers. The first one didn't know, the second thought he knew - but had to stop and check on the way. We got there fine - 120 pesos for the taxi. The cenote people will call a taxi for the return, but it costs 150 pesos because its a callout.We took the guided tour just for the 2 of us, and were pleased we did - another group went through with about 20 people and was very regimented. We went through small passages and into very small caves so you have to be prepared to do it.Our guide gave us lots of information and was careful as well so we didn't feel worried at any stage. We were in the caves and cenotes for over 2 hours.They provide all the equipment so you don't need to bring anything except watershoes and swimming gear.

Highlight of our vacation!. Big shout out to Juan from his friends from Boston! He was a great guide and provided us with a very personalized tour that you just can't get from the big tourist traps. Water was a bit high due to all the rain we had but still got to see 95% of everything. Really a great experience and I would recommend this to everyone

Unique. Not too far out of town, took a taxi for $10.00 each way ( set it up before hand to pay him upon his return. If you pay when you get to the cenote, he may not return, and you won't have a way back.) Our front desk clerk Louis at Aventura Mexicana was most helpful. It took him 15 minutes & 4 cabs to get one to finally agree to it. The road to the cenote is under construction. The cenote cost $20.00 each and included entry, helmet & life vest. You can rent a flashlight for $6.00 ( called gringo tax ) or $8. to buy, (or bring your own!) Did not get one but Juan our guide had one. Do not really need snorkel equipment. We had equipment, but never used it. No flippers allowed. We were the only people there. We used Juan as our guide & tipped him $10.00 U. S.- well worth it. Can't stress how important a guide is. You will miss a lot without one. If you go, ask for Juan. He speaks perfect English and has a real love and enthusiasm for nature, which is infectious. No pictures allowed as it can harm the habitat, birds, bats etc. Strongly suggest water shoes or flipflops or something on your feet. Just the walk from 1 cenote to the other will cut & bruise bare feet.

Beautiful cave.. My husband and i went to this Cenote at the end of our swim with Turtles.It is quite dark and as i am not a good swimmer i nearly chickened out of going in, but i had conquered my worse fear being in the sea so i gave it a go and was so glad i did.The cave is beautiful above and below, with bats that dont bother you flying around. You will need a good underwater camera with flash if you want to capture the beauty under the water.It is very rocky but the guide stears you around the rocks.A must do.

Awesome expierence with great guides. My husband and I were in Playa Del Carmen for our honeymoon. We came to Chaak Tun for one day and had a wonderful time. Our guide was Carlos & he was the best. I told him I was clausterphoebic and he assured me he would make sure I felt safe. He took us through a few cenotes and we did some snorkeling. My husband and I had a wonderful time. I would highly recommend.
Unmissable for divers. Part of a 4 day package with Bullshark Diving in Playa del Carmen. The cenotes are incredible and would return to Mexico just to dive them again.

good excursion. from playa del carmen is a perfect excursion of 1/2 day. you can organize with a guide (recommended) if you want to taxi (120 pesos from playa). bring drinking water with you. snorkeling in the cenote water is one of the most exiting things that you can do in yucatan. water is actually very cold so not so good for joung children. a part of swimming in the cave there is notthign to do. 3-4 hours in enough
very nice. very nice and great to visit, nature and be quiet and fresh air repirar thank God and thanks to the people of

Beautiful cenote very close to town. My husband and I were the only two people at Chaak Tun when we arrived. Based on previous reviews, we did get a guide and it was the best decision we could have made. We tipped him 100 pesos and he really helped us find things that we otherwise wouldn't have found. The water is cold, but you're in a cave so that is to be expected. It taxi ride cost us 100 pesos each way from Playa and the entrance fee to Chaak Tun was 200 pesos (we had our own snorkel equipment). It was a little pricey but definitely worth it! We also asked our taxi driver to pick us back up in two hours and that was plenty of time to see everything Chaak Tun had to offer.
Best excursion we've done!. Did the half-day excursion, was perfect. Three ziplines was plenty, and an hour of snorkeling was just right. The guide (Cerbando?) did a wonderful job taking care of us.

Favorite cenote!. Definitely off the beaten path. Chaak tun was closed on Sunday so we came back the next day but were short on time because of an afternoon flight. Carlos was very helpful and told us where to go. The first cave is small, but beautifully lit, you swim under stalactites (watch your head!) and into another cave with natural light. It was beautiful! The larger cave we only briefly saw, and would have really wanted to explore with a guide if we had the time. Even tho we only swam in the first cave, we thought it was worth the 200 pesos, just for the pictures and the experience. You're given a snorkel, helmet, and vest. But we went in only with our own snorkels and were fine. My husband and I were the only ones there in the morning in it was a grand experience. Great way to end the trip. Would visit again to explore the larger cave with Carlos!

Amazing experience. Best cenotes in Playa del Carmen. As other reviewers mentioned, go in the afternoon. It was just us and our tour guide, Carlos. Would reccommended the tour guide, informative and will take you to parts that you might not neccessarily enter on your own. There is no extra cost for the tour guide, he works on tips.

Less Touristy, More Natural Beauty. A bit off the beaten path, you can take a taxi for about 150 pesos to this cenote, which is about 20 minutes from the ferry dock. There are three separate caves, all with pools of varying depths, the largest of which is more than 15 feet deep. All have bats and cave catfish. Us a guide if you can -- they will show you more than you would likely find on your own -- plus they'll point out where you need to watch your cabeza because of low overhangs!Best part about this cenote is that it is minimally developed, with only a few lights and man-made structures. It's about as close to untouched nature as you could find.
cenote swim. the guide was great with us - made the kids feel very comfortable! It was nice to get a bit of history with the tour.

Cenote swim and snorkel. What an awesome time we had at chaak tun,very informative,interesting and personal,Adam was an awesome guide and is all around a great person,not to many people so the guide can answer all your questionsThanks Adam from the Simon family

Super tour. We went on this tour in March with our 14 year old Granddaughter. It was just super. We were in the caves for about 3 hours. Our guide, Mannie, was just great and was very informative. He spoke good English. It is not scary, except if you look for some of the bats on the ceilings. They provide the lifejackets, snorkel gear, flashlights, and 2 free soft drinks. There is a bathroom/changing area at the site. The also have lockers to store your clothes. You cannot get to the site by the map that is on the internet. There is currently road construction, so you have to go to the parallel street about a mile to the north. We drove in our own rental from Puerto Morelos and the cost was $30 per person to get in..Recommended for all ages that can snorkel.

Kids loved it!. We took a taxi from our hotel - 150 pesos. We did the 360 peso package. Our two 8 year olds were only charged 200 for the package. We loved it. Really incredible site. Can't imagine having done it without a guide - just to take us through it. We had the taxi come back for us in two hours and that was a perfect amount of time. There were only a few other people there besides us when we arrived around 12:30. The taxi returned exactly on time. It really is an incredible experience and something the kids will always remember. We saw bats hanging from the ceiling and had to swim through a small opening in the rock (sort of underwater but with your snorkel on) to get into the next cave. There are tiny catfish swimming around. Would say that water shoes are very helpful but not absolutely necessary. water was chilly at first but we got used to it. imagine it is very cold if you are visiting in winter. We would definitely recommend it.

Great fun!. Read about this place here on Tripadvisor. It was quite difficult to find but we found the direction in somebody's review. The place is a lot of fun. We paid 10$ each. We didn't take the tour, however one of the guides showed us the place. I tried to swim the whole circle. In order to do it you have to dive in one place and swim underwater following the rope. Finally I didn't risk it.Still great fun!
Snorcheling with Rod. perfect Tour with yourprivatetours. Rod showed my wife how to snorchel.It was a great expierience, thanks so muchAndreas & Eneken

how fun is this!. rapelled into the cenote, swam, ziplined, and walked the tight rope across the cenote! all this and i am terrified of heights thanks to the tour guide who helped me through this exciting adventure!

Hard to get to but worth it.. We had trouble getting to and from this attraction. If I would do it again, get your condo, hotel, or resort to arrange transportation. We negotiated with a cab in town for a round trip ticket and then when we got there he asked for full payment and then refused to come back to get us. The staff did get us a cab return back but it took a while. They were a lot of help. Still worth the trip to see this attraction. Pay extra for the guide. Ours did not speak a word of engilsh and was hard to communicate with but we would not have seen it all without him. This attraction seems relatively new and they seem to be trying to improve it.

Good Experience. This was a first time experience for us swimming in caves. I cannot compare it to alo of other similar cenotes in the area, but we did enjoy ourselves. It cost us US$60+tips for 2 of us with a guide- Carlos. He was a nice guy and showed us around and let us spend as much time we’d like. I’d definitely suggest this place and activity to people visiting Cancun

Great Family Fun. As this cenote was quite local to our resort we decided to give it a try. The prices were pretty high but it was a certainly a fabulous cenote. In our family we have children who are ages 7-13 and all of them loved the cenote. If you are looking to save money I would recommend bringing your own snorkel gear if possible as they did charge a large amount for snorkel rentals. Also I recommend getting a guide. Our guide made our experience fabulous since we learned a lot about the cenote and its formation and all the little things in the cenote which we would likely miss without a guide. This is certainly a great and local place for all who are visiting Playa and I give it 5 stars for the overall experience.

Beautiful cenote, great experience. We visited a few cenotes on our trip and our experience at Chaak Tun was by far the best. We took a taxi from Playa, he dropped us off and returned promptly in 2 hours. We got a guide based on other reviewers suggestions. Definitely get the guide! Adan was an excellent guide. He shared a lot of information about the natural and cultural history of the area, and some of this I expect from a guide. The best part though, was his conveying a little of the spiritual experience of a cenote: the quiet tranquility and total darkness of being in a cave, the respect for the creatures living there, and the beauty of it all. Thanks Adan!

Needs to be boycotted until they lower their insane fee. Once too popular on such sites, prices for these places go sky high. I simply could not believe what the other reviewer said about the admission price having gone up that much. I had to go there to believe it. It was true. They said they have one price of 100 pesos for local folks from Playa and 200 pesos for tourists and with equipment, which you need, the "package" deal is 360 pesos per person. We rejected, since we had a car and could go elsewhere.The cave and the water they showed us was nothing to write home about, no plants or fish, no colorful rocks. I have seen amazingly colorful cave formations and this did not seem to be that interesting.Getting to this place is a pain even though it is not too far from town. We went all the way up Juarez only to realize the road is closed and we have to go back, turn north east, get on constitution and basically make a 2 mile loop around to get back on that dirt road.
Trip Highlight. For novelty, we really enjoyed this activity. It was something neither my husband or I did before and it was really fun.

Amazing and unforgettable experience. This is highly recommended. I did went to several Cenotes in Yucatan but this one is the very best. The swimming experience is unique. Make sure you book a guide or you will never understand half of the beauty of it. Simply amazing!

Close to Playa del Carmen and so beautiful. We took a taxi from Playa del Carmen (150 pesos). We had drawn a map based on google earth, so although he had not heard of it before he had no problems getting there even with Ave. Juarez construction.As noted with other reviews, this cenote is under new management. There are two entry fee levels: 200 pesos for entrance only, 360 pesos for entrance plus helmet, life jacket, flashlights, locker, and mask/snorkel. Guides are now independent contractors and work for tips.I suggest getting the full package - worth it for the flashlight alone! - and the mask/snorkel will really improve your enjoyment of the cenote. Also, you should totally spring for the guide. When we were there (Friday morning at 10 AM) there was only one other couple at the cenote. They went without the guide and ended up missing the 2nd of the 3 caves. The 2nd cave also has a very narrow passageway (maybe 3 feet tall?) which I would not have ventured through without a guide.Our guide was Carlos, who has been at this cenote for 12 years. His English was good, he was fun and friendly, and very patient with this family of four.We really debated coming here - the entrance fee seemed a bit steep - but are SO glad we did! This is unlike any other cave that we have seen. My daughter was not excited about coming (nervous of a small cave, hates cold water), but she ended up enjoying it and was happy throughout the tour.We wore our wetsuits and sport sandals. While the water seemed warmer to me than snorkeling in the ocean, you are in the water a long time here. If you have wetsuits bring them; they have a nice changing / bathroom area. Sport sandals were not required, but you are going to be walking over uneven and rocky cave floors.

An awesome local attraction. A little tough to get to as Avenue Juarez has been closed for construction at the top before you arrive however approach by Consitiuyentes and take the last left across back to Juarez(Brand-new paved road) And you will be on track to get to the entrance as others have guided. Our guide told us this road will be closed for about four months. Well worth looking for though. Very intimate as it seems very few tourists make the effort to get here. Our guide, Adan was fantastic. Spoke wonderful English and had an obvious passion for the natural surroundings including the history and geology. Because of the remoteness, we were only one of three groups at the caves during the late afternoon. A very unique experience and a true trip highlight.

A Great Deal on a Fabulous Experience. Don't recall the price but it was definitely a good value compared to other cenotes. It is really close to Playa Del Carmen...just west on Juarez. Had the guided tour (Approx. 1.5-2 hr)....well worth the money amd very informative.
Great time, very beautiful. Did this as part of a package from the resort. Liked the care they took to preserve the cenotes. Enjoyed the spiritual ritual too.

Fabulous underwater pool. If this is what I remember, it was a underground freshwater pool in which you could have a swim. Visually it was awesome, a bit cold but definately worth the experience. It is a bit out of the way and down a rather bumpy dirt track so if you are not a good traveller, it may not be your cup of tea.

One of the best cenotes. Surprisingly, not many people know about this cenote, and its almost not advertised in Playa. We asked to several taxi drivers but none knew where it was, si we decided to walk. It' actually really easy to get there: you just have to go straight on avenida Juarez till the end and then pass a construction site, you will see the entrance on your right. From the end of av. Juarez it's about 4 km to get there. The cenotes(the are 3) are very beautiful and it's cheap: it costs just about 15 dollars.

Under world adventure. We visited this cenote with a guide from The Snorkel Shop in Playa. The day include snorkeling the reefs in a nearby town, transfers, and lunch. It was a small group of 7 people for less than $100 dollars. It was worth it. We received a free cd of photos that captured the adventure. I would not have felt comfortable without the guide. Snorkel gear and a water proof flashlight is a must if you go without the guide. The underwater caverns and depth of water is amazing.

Very cool experience. Visited the Cenote Chaak Tun because the weather was poor in Playa Del Carmen today. Two differenent cab drivers did not know where it was and offered drastically different rates. The first wanted to charge me $50 US dollars and the second agreed to 150 pesos. Ask the drivers to take you down Avenida Juarez and you will make it there. You will have to go through a security gate and down a pot hol ridden dirt rode, but it is only 10-15 minutes from town.I paid 40 pesos which included 20 for the entrance, 10 for a waterproof flashlight and 10 for the guide. Being that it was late in the day (3:30) I only saw a few other people there who were just leaving, so I had the denotes and guide all to myself. I would highly recommend the guide as he took me places I would have not be comfortable (or safe if the flashlight died) going on my own. I highly recommend this side trip, it is well worth it and a great way to kill a few hours on a rainy day.

very nice. unluckly its been my only cenotece but i liked it much, the best part of this cenote are the cave inside it, very amazing, breathless and also the light making a moving raimbow on the rocks, very very nice, i advice it

Cool Bike Trip to Closest Cenote to Playa Del Carmen. So i was bored and rented a bike in Playa Del Carmen, took Avenida Juarez (good bike trail in center of road)- stopped by a cheap taco joint along the way, took dirt road and after 40 minutes ride was there (Entrance is on the right if you come from Playa)...it was 230 pesos (entrance fee with locker). The Cenote was empty around 12 that day and I liked that i had the cavern all to myself. I floated on my back watching the play of light on the stalactite filled ceiling and watched the herbivorous and insectivorous bats flitter about. it was very peaceful and almost spiritual to float in the crystal clear, cool water. Could imagine how the Maya would consider this the entrance to their underworld (Xibalba) which according to them had 9 levels with one god and lord of the underworld along with several gods of sacrifice that they placated by throwing humans and trinkets for things they needed in ancient times. Seems like they still do throw things as i found a modern day statue thrown in and was resting at the bottom of the clear pool i was swimming in. The guy at the gate told me that up until about 2 years ago local people did use the cenote to make offerings for good luck or wishes wanted to be granted. Tip-take a waterproof flashlight...this cenote is pretty extensive and has two large caves (one to right of entrance down dirt road is the nicest and biggest one) without a guide you definitely will need a flashlight to navigate the dark passageways safely. There is some lighting.

impossible but very impressive. We are experienced divers. As such, we cannot defend cenote diving, as it is by all means real cave diving with all its dangers. Nevertheless it was a great experience. Not in the first hours after the dive, as the danger and risks, hit upon us. But thereafter, the positive experience won over the negative.

Get the guide.. Based on all of the reviews, I would get the guide. We didn't and it was pretty boring. It was alright...somewhat interesting, but nowhere near 5 stars like everybody else is rating this place. I have to assume it's the guided experience that made the difference. We drove ourselves and had no problem getting there and finding the place.

Nearest Cenote to Playa. Easy to get to - a taxi is 100 pesos each way from Playa. We went half way by collectivo but didn't save much. Entrance to the caves is 200 pesos but you pay extra for the locker and torch - both necessary. The water is not as cold as I imagined after reading reviews but do wear a couple of layers to keep some body heat in and wear water shoes. Snorkel wasn't really needed but nice to see some formations below. Don't miss the part where you go through a short tunnel with a few inches between your face and the ceiling into darkness (torch needed!) then further into an sun filled open Cenote! There was no one there when we went at 1pm. Very still and silent - just bats calling. Amazing.
pleasant surprise. incredible !!!!!! went with my kids and went swimming through the caves. I have scuba dived through cenotes before. this was a total highlight of the trip.
Nice and affordable. I spent a couple of hours there. It is impressive. You see a real cenote very close to Playa del Carmen. If you snorkel in certain areas, the underwater view is amazing.

Well set up and low key experience!. When we went here in the height of tourist season (July), there were only two other small groups (2-4 people) and so we virtually had the place to ourselves! The cenotes are very cool, make sure to check out both of them. The one that's off the beaten path more is definitely worth going look as it's even more mysterious than the bigger one. The proprietors were very helpful and accommodating, even offering to call us a taxi for the trip back to Playa. The fee was only around $10 and renting snorkles and flashlights was also relatively cheap. Highly recommended!

A quality experience. If you are someone who values unique and memorable experiences that don’t involve throngs of tourists, then Chaak Tun is for you. It is quite an experience to swim through the remarkably clear, quiet, stalactite/mite laden recesses of the two Chaak Tun caverns.Everyone there and was so accommodating. Our guide, Carlos, was knowledgeable, enthusiastic, and amiable. One of the high points was when he asked us (my wife and two sons) whether we were interested in experiencing a few moments of total silence and darkness. When we consented, he switched off the lighting (appropriately scant to begin with), and we stood together in silence, ensconced in the novelty of perfectly silent, perfectly dark, primordial immersion.Here are my suggestions to maximize the experience:1. As others have suggested, arrive in the afternoon (1:30pm or later) to minimize the number of fellow explorers. We actually arrived at 3:15 and still had the full, two hour experience even though they technically closed at 4:30.2. If you can, wear 1) a wetsuit, and 2) water shoes. Don’t hesitate to go if you don’t have access to either of these items, but either will increase your comfort since the water is on the cool side and the rocks are a bit uncomfortable in parts. Again, these were minor challenges, but worth counteracting if possible.3. If you are bringing your own snorkel equipment, leave the fins at home; you can’t use them because of the potential damage to the formations.4. You can and should rent at least one waterproof flashlight for your group. We rented one, but probably should have rented two.5. Pay for a guide; it’s totally worth the 100 pesos.6. Bring some dry clothes to change into and store these clothes and valuables in a locker. We only needed to rent a single locker for 4 people.Finally, I’ve read many of the posts complaining about the price changes and I would like to add my perspective. I talked to the onsite operations manager, and it’s clearly a simple case of miscommunication. The cenote management changed recently and, not atypically, the prices changed as well. Because it’s a small staff, with limited English and likely limited resources, these changes were not publicized nor were the adverse posts addressed. But I strongly believe they are not trying to deceive or “rip-off” anyone. Enjoy!

Fantastic. We spent almost 3 hours at this Cenote. I will say I was a little disappointed to find the price to be double what I saw online. It is actually 200 pesos if you have your own gear which we did. We did have one person that had to pay the full 360 pesos to rent their gear. There were six in our group. We had Adam guide us through the Cenote. There are actually two different cenotes that you can visit. We absolutely loved his guided tour. If we would have done this on our own without a guide it wouldn't have been the same experience at all. We went deep into the caves and actually had only a couple of inches between us and the ceiling in some areas as we swam from room to room. I would recommend this to anyone in the area but only if you have the guide. That made all the difference in the world. Also, about the road.... very bumpy and quite a ways away from civilization. Just keep driving away from the Ocean (west) down Avenue Bonita Juarez. Eventually the road turns to dirt. Then you pass through a security check point. Just keep going. Finally, the road has a very small bend in an otherwise straight road. When it bends, you are there. I am guessing it is 5-7 km from the highway. Enjoy!

Awesome. We were a little nervous as we drove down the dirt road and reached a security checkpoint. There was a jail in the area, and I had not read on any reviews about this checkpoint. Our driver got us to Chaak Tun safe and sound, but we did have do make a 'contribution' to the security guard in order to get back to the main road. Cost to get in to Chaak Tun was 200 pesos per person for helmet, life vest.... this was after some negotiating with the owner who originally wanted 360 pesos per person. (Tour, locker, coke....) The cenote is well worth it.

Thief. They said it was 100 pesos in the internet...after a ride on a road with a lot of holes, at the entrance they say to you that it's cost 360 pesos !!! Even if we said that it was show at 100 pesos in the web site of trip advisor they affirmed that they raised the price last month. But it's not a rase, it's almost a x 4 !!! We didn't go so I can't tell you if it's value the price but of sure you better not go there if you prefer not to be the fun of them.
