Unusual experience. Visit early in the day to have the place to yourself. It's easy by taxi , 150 pesos from centre of town. The water is cold but the life jackets keep your body heat in. Swim in underground caverns, there are 2 with water to swim in, and 1 dry to explore. Stalactites hang from the roof.

of the path feel in the afternoon. Go in the afternoon to avoid the tour groups. 360 peso each gits you to both cenotes, the first is the main where the groups go but if it is only a few you can go to the other which is much more impressive to me because of its tight spaces at one point you even swim under ( only a few feet) to the next chamber.

First time I have ever seen oneof these. It was interesting and we let the little fish clean our feet-- I had heard about thisd but never had it done --- I cam home with very soft feet --I am from Iowa --USA

Nice cenote. It's $30 per person. The cab cost us 100 pesos each way (down Juarez - dirt road with potholes). The water gets cold so bring a shirt if you can. 2 cenotes - you can swim in both. Bring a waterproof camera, water shoes, rashie, board shorts and a snack. You can spend as much time as you'd like but I think 2 hours is plenty to look around and chill.

Great first cenote experience. My husband, two kids (8 & 11) & my first experience snorkeling a cenote. It was very interesting & highly recommended. We toured with a private guide (Eddie from The Snorkel Shop, who was awesome & took his time with us). The water was chilly, but the experience was amazing & unforgettable & totally worth it. My daughter (8 year old) was a little freaked out & held onto my arm most of the way but at the end of the day said she enjoyed this over the reef that she snorkeled at earlier in the day (first time snorkel). If you're unsure, do it, you won't regret it.

cenotes and atv's. Great tour, louis was great, cenotes where beautiful, Saw where the small children went to school, The atv's were a ball, They made a video and for a small price you could buy it, so worth it.

Do it on your own Cenote near downtown Playa del Carmen. There's many toward the Tulum end but we didn't have time to do one when we were there. Luckily for us we found the Chaktun Cenote through a referral from the snorkeling guys. Renting a taxi for a three hour trip came up to $30 and he drove us to the cenote (about a 15 minute drive) and we got to swim in the cenote with vests and snorkeling gear for about $10. The water was freezing so the Little Monkey was not a fan, but we enjoyed taking turns to swim in the caves and soak in the craziness bats and all. This place isn't stroller friendly but quirky guys at the quaint make shift entrance were more than happy to keep it safe for us. This isn't a busy spot at all and while we were in there for about 2 hours, we only saw 10 people at most.

Great cenote with little - no tourism. We found this cenote on Tripadvisor. However when we asked the reception desk or guest service, none of the personel had ever heard of the existance of this cenote. Every person gave us a map will all the "famous" cenotes where all tourists go to.When I asked a local taxi driver he knew exactly where it was. We drove from Playacar (Sandos) to this cenote for 200 pesos and agreed with the taxi driver that he would pick us up in 2 hours (it is advicable to arrange the taxi back, as you will end up in the middle of nowhere).How to drive:From Playacar (or Playa del Carmen) you first go to Avenida Juarez. This road you will follow all the way north untill the asphalt road stops (it stops beside the collega MayaLand). From here you will enter a sandy road. This road you will need to continu for approximately 2km. Than the cenote is found on your right hand.The cenote itself is beautiful and very quite (in total you will find 2 cenotes and 1 dry cenote / cave). For example we were there as the only 4 persons. When we left 5 others came.Price:Locals pay 50 pesos to enterForeigners pay 100 pesos TIP: DON'T go here by tour, they may charge you crazy amounts of money and the staff (1 old man) are extremely helpful (the only disadvantage is that he doesn't speak english)
A must see!. It was awesome to see the cenote & swim in it. The water is refreshing & while snorkelling the visibilty is amazing.

absolutely beautiful. although very crowded and one of the most popular stops after a visit to the ruins this stands out as one of the most visually spectacular centoes we visited. The small restaurant nearby is staffed by friendly people with plentiful filling food.

Beautiful,. I was suprised to find this spot on trip advisor it is more out of the way and not to touristy, they have 3 different cenotes, one of which you can dive underwater for a few feet and come up in a completly different cavern. Dont try it without the guides help.
Once in a lifetime experience!. I never thought my husband and I would go swimming in a cave, but we did - and we loved it! It was a rare and unexpected experience.

Great alternative to sea diving. Cenotes are a great side show for divers, very different and unique. A must do in my view! The Place has restaurant and supplies good authentic Mexican fare and the guides I had were spot on. Worth the trip alone

A MUST DIVE!!. Very unique dive. My wife and I are open ocean divers and this was very different, in a good way. We loved it. Extremely beautiful. We went though Alux Divers and absolutely recommend them.
Great dive. This was a very unique dive experience. Our guide was from bahaia dive center and was well qualified.
Very Nice Cenote!!!. Loved the fresh cool water, very nice & pretty big with a waterfall. Its pretty remarkable as its situated in the middle of the city!
Cenote swim. An awesome chance to swim in the cool waters of a true cenote--- loved it!!! Hope that you beat all the tourist like we did--- we had the cenote to ourselves for thirty minutes.

Brilliant Half Day Excursion. Really good value, great experience. Started off with arriving in the jungle with a walk through and the lovely guide Flavio giving a heart-felt passionate feel of the jungle including a stop for us all to listen quietly to soak up the surroundings and sounds. This followed with an amazing snorkel in the first cave like Cenote with the most amazing crystal sparkling sapphire coloured water with crystal visability of the caves under the water. The second snorkel was of a more open Cenote. After a lovely snack offered of bananas, cake, sweets, drinks and a shower we were back in the comfortable shuttel to the beach to snorke with the turtles in their natural environment. A truly fantastic experience and wonderful service from beginning to end.

Beautiful, Quiet, Cavern Cenote. If you are looking for a more rustic, less touristic, cavern type cenote, Chaak Tun is an excellent choice. For $10 you will get a cave tour and a chance to swim or snorkel in the cenote. The guides spoke some English and were very helpful. We brought our own snorkel equipment, but rentals are available for snorkel as well as underwater flashlight rentals (much recommended). The water is clear, clean and cool and it is really fun to swim over the interesting cave formations. The drive to the cenote can be tricky so it is best to have your GPS coordinates marked before going out there. Also, it can get crowded with the jeep tours, so afternoons are really a better choice. Between the tours, we pretty much had the place to ourselves. A couple of important things to know before you go: 1. They ask that you do not use sunscreen or insect repellent as it disturbs the delicate ecosystem in the cenote. 2. Some of the passages are a little tighter (not for the claustrophobic) but you still have the option of remaining in the more open areas to swim.

Definitely Worth Checking Out. Visited this cenote last March as part of a snorkelling tour and it was one of the coolest things I've done! The water was so refreshing and the snorkelling was amazing! So awesome to see the formations and the wildlife under water. It was very cool swimming but, after a hot day, we loved it! I definitely recommend water shoes for the walk down and for exploring in the cave. It wasn't busy at all and we were the only group down there the whole time we were snorkelling. I highly encouraged others to try this tour!
The beautiful and different place to visit. The beautiful cenote. We recommend to visit and swim in the lagoon. Prepare your photos and video recorder. The water is very cool, but, it´s amazing.

This was awesome!. I had read wonderful reviews about this place and wanted to check it out for myself. I asked our hotel concierge about it and she didn't even know it existed. It is located a few minutes outside the city limits. We arrived at a perfect time. A cruise group of about 25 was leaving and we ended up having the place to ourselves for over two hours. Carlos swam around with us and showed us the beauty Chaak Tun has to offer. I would recommend renting the snorkel gear so you can see the beauty underwater. I loved this place, it was amazing! It truly is a hidden gem.
Not much fun. Didn't enjoy this at all. Guide didn't speak any English and it was quite boring. Many much more fun, and beautiful ceynotes around.

Perfect for those looking for a peaceful, magical cenote. We were not sure what to expect when we rented a scooter and headed out to Cenote Chaak-Tun (despite the lack of directions to Chaak-Tun online, it is very easy to find. Take Benito Juarez away from the ocean, continue about 10-15 minutes after you go under highway 307 and it will be on your right hand side); but we were truly blown away. We chose Chaak-Tun over the much other more touristy options in the area because we like our independence and didn't want to be forced to go with a large group. We also didn't like all the rules that many of the other cenotes had (for eg. no photos "in order to protect the cenotes" aka so they can sell the overpriced photos that their photographer takes). Chaak-Tun was the PERFECT pick for us. When we arrived, there was only one other family. By the time we were ready to enter the water, the family was on their way and we then had the entire cenote to ourselves for over an hour! (We went at about 3pm). It was so, so relaxing and magical. The man who runs Chaak-Tun was wonderful. He was more than willing to guide us through, but when he found out we preferred to do our own thing, he allowed us complete independence. He also gave us a great deal on the snorkel equipment and underwater flashlights and went above and beyond to take care of little details.Thanks for the wonderful experience!

Our favorite cruise shore excursion. My wife, two grandchildren and I recently went to Chaak Tun cavern and cenote as a shore excursion from a Carnival Dream cruise that included Cozumel. Of all of our activities, this turned out to be our favorite. We did it as part of a Jeep and Cavern excursion. Since the ship docks at Cozumel and this excursion starts with a 45 minute ferry ride to Playa del Carmen which isn't exciting and can be a little rough if the seas are rough. Sea sickness is a possiblity. Once in Playa del Carmen, we met our guides "Andy" and Isaac. Andy was very funny while being informative and safety concious. The jeeps are four passenger with manual transmissions, so to drive you need a valid drivers license and able to drive a stick shift. The roofs are down, so expect a lot of sun and wind. Bring eco friendly sun screen and insect repellent. The jeep drive to the cavern is mostly zig zagging along city streets with the final stretch down a very bumpy and muddy dirt road. Bring bathing suit, water shoes and dry clothes to wear after the cavern. There is a changing area, lockers to rent and snorkel sets to rent if you don't bring your own. At the cavern they give you time to change before and after. You are given a hard hat to wear while walking in the cavern. Wear it. I bumped my head at least 5 times. Once you reach the underground river, you put on life vest and snorkels if you want to snorkel and jump in the beautiful green water. The water is 72 degrees and is up to 50 feet deep in spots. The guide tours you around various areas, lets you do a facial with the mineral rich bottom sedimen and then gives you about 20 minutes to snorkel and explore on your own. It is wonderful and exhilerating. After changing clothes the jeeps head for a beach where you can buy lunch at a restuarant. Bring cash or cresit card. Good food at a moderately high price. You have about an hour at the beach. Then jeep back to Playa del Carmen and the ferry ride back to the ship.
Pablo is a great guide. Great people, very safe and secure. Crossed this off my bucket list

Better then you can imagine. This is the best experience we've had on an vacation excursion.The directions are shady, but it's very simple to get there. Once on 307, take Jauves west. You'll be on there a while, once you get to the security guard, it's exactly 2.4 kilometers it's on the north side and has a big sign.As far as the caves themselves, they're beautiful. The stalagmites and stalagtites are stunning. Seeing the fruit bats hanging and the catfish swimming imersre you in this reality that we aren't the only ones enjoying this cave.We got a private tour from Carlos because it was a rainy slow day for them and it was totally worth it. It's about $20US per person wich is much better then the $69+ every other place was asking for the same thing.We cannot recommend this enough! Bring a water proof camera.

cenote snorkel. We took a taxi to this cenote and cave It is on the outskirts of Play Del Carmen.We went in the afternoon after reading other reviews, and we had the place almost all to ourselves. We wandered through the caves with bats on the ceilings, very cool, then entered the cenote with the cool clear water for a snorkel.We were a bit intimidated about how far we should go down some of the channels, so we stayed in our comfort zone.It was fun and not as crowded as the big cenotes on the tourist routes.
Ameising tour. Ameising whit ATV jungle tour Wheelie Trails in hotels Riu

Magical- late in the day, alone in the ceynote. A completely spontaneous trip to the ceynote- skipping out on class for the day with my instructor- and arriving close to 5pm meant that we had the place to ourselves and that made it truly magical. It would still be amazingly cool even if I had had to share the experience with dozens of other people, but with just the two of us quietly making our way through, we saw birds, bats and baby catfish. My instructor has been to Chaak Tun many, many, MANY times, and was able to point out stalactites that were still forming and those which were ´dead´.As a bonus, there are reasonable bathrooms (that had toilet paper, soap in the dispensers, and paper towels) on site where you can change into your bathing suit- or back into dry clothes.Even if you only have a couple of hours, you really need to cross this off of your bucket list...

Hidden gem right in Playa del Carmen. We had swam in a few different cenotes on the last trip, and this year we had brought friends for their first time who also wanted to go. With only one week in town our schedule was pretty full with visits to Akumal, Tulum, and Cozumel, and we just didn't have time to fit in a cenote while on the go. But, I had remembered there was a cenote right in Playa, just on the other side of Juarez and it had great reviews, so we thought this was a great chance to have our cenote experience without leaving town. We grabbed a taxi from our hotel on 1st Ave and hired him to bring us there and come back to pick us up in 2 1/2 hours for a cost of $30US. On the drive there, which only took about 10 to 15 minutes, the skies opened and it started to rain...hard. We didn't mind, though, because we would be underground anyways! We didn't bother with a tour, so we only purchased the entrance, snorkels, life vests (for two of us), and a flash light. We were also given the mandatory hard hats since the entrance to one of the cenotes is quite low and it's easy to hit your head. There is a long winding path with stairs through the jungle that leads to the entrance to the first wet cenote. As I said, it was raining hard outside so it was very slippery. Once inside, though, it was great. We could see the rain coming down through one of the openings in the roof and it was so pretty. The first cenote has a winding path that leads to a dock platform with stairs into the water. Note that this is already quite deep here once you step off the last step. The water is cool and refreshing and so clear. You can see right to the bottom. There are a few small fish swimming about, but nothing to worry about. There are also some great rock formations in this cave, with lots of stalagmites and stalactites hanging about. From here you can also continue into the dry cenote for a tour, but it is dark and we decided to head to the other wet cenote instead as we were really there to cool off. To get to the other cenote you have to go back outside, pass the front gate, and walk a short path to where some more stairs lead down into the cenote. The first part of the cenote is dry and has a temezcal and alter, before leading to another platform dock. Again, the water is cool and refreshing. We had the place to ourselves on that afternoon, which was nice. Really great visit, wish I had heard about it sooner! No need to take one of those bus tours to a crowded cenote an hour or more away when you can just head across town. Go. Enjoy.

Nice caves but a few things could make the experience even better. We enjoyed swimming through the caves with out guide. The price was reasonable too The stalactites and stalagmites are nothing in comparison to something like Luray Caverns in West Virginia, but being that most readers are not likely to see that, this is still enjoyable. There were a few things that could have made the experience better:-our guide did not speak any English short of "watch your head" or "swim here". I really wished we had a guide who could really explain to us what we were looking at. I get that they are limestones formations that are millions of years old, but later we met someone who was really knowledgable and told us how they were formed and how they were all connected etc.-you are given one handheld flashlight for two people to share. I think everyone should get an overhead flashlight of good quality. -they don't give you flippers and that would have made swimming through easier since you already had the life vest and snorkel gear.
lovely and quiet. nice day swam in centoes beautiful and real we were there early morning snorkel and mask provided
Fun in the jungle. Nice place. Not very touristy yet. My daughter had fun doing the zip line.
brill. this is a lovely cenote - hole in the ground where the river flows too as there is no rivers in mexico - they all run underground. it was 150 metre deep - so fresh and lovely
Cave Diving. Was amazing with Tank-Ha. Guide was great and took us on a very safe and fantastic dive. Felt like I was in outer space with interesting rock formations all around.

Not sure if this was the Cenote trip we took. Our trip included the cenotes, cave swim, ocean swim, lunch. This was the best outing. We first swam in a cave, then went to the brackish water snorkled and swam to the ocean, then we weretaken to a large palapa where a native family cooked us the bestlime chicken I have ever had, bar none. Afterwards, we jumped inthe cenotes. Make sure your trip includes all of that. The otherouting should be Xelha, pronounced shell ha.
Family group enjoy it.. the scenery, but the trip was short, need to use kayaks on your own to see more
Awesome Excursion. This was the best excursion we went on while were in the Caribbean. I would highly recommend this cenote.
What an experience. My family absolutely love our excursion. Water was SO clean and clear
Cool Refreshing and Clean. Well managed, clean and inviting. A nice break from a hot day.

Great fun. There are many more prominently advertised cenotes in the Yucatan, but this one is certainly a goood value. We actually had been there 15 years ago, so we went looking for it this time. It seems to mostly cater to cruise ship passenders (from Cozumel!) and we had to tell the taxi driver how to find it (go out Juarez from the center of Playa). It is low key and very Mexican, although they do have running water and a changing area now. Plan on spending 2 or 3 hours if you like to swim.

Beautiful Cenote right in Playa del Carmen. We spent a lovely afternoon at this site where I traveled with my three teenagers. My teenage son liked this adventure the best of all the things we did on our vacation. Bring your swim suit and I recommend some shoes that you can swim with (not flip flops), otherwise you can swim barefoot, which is ok, but the cave floor is rough at parts. There are several caves to explore. We saw lots of beautiful formations, interesting roots coming into the cave, a ritualistic Mayan sauna, and lots of fruit bats hanging from the ceiling. A majority of your exploring will be in the water, which was cool, but refreshing. Many parts are too deep to touch the bottom, so life jackets are provided. There is a place to set down your camera while you are swimming, so it's ok to bring a small camera into the caves, but have something to put it in to keep it dry.To get there, we took a cab ride from downtown Playa del Carmen which cost us 100 pesos, plus a tip. Drive on Juarez Avenue all the way to the end until you come to a checkpoint with a guard where the land is private property from that point. Our cab driver told him we were going to the cenote and let us through. From there it was about a mile or so on a very bumpy dirt road through mostly jungle to get to the site which is marked well with a big sign (see photo). Getting home when we were finished was a little tricky. They couldn't (or wouldn't?) call a cab for us, so we began to walk back down the dirt road to town where we though we'd pick up a cab there. Luckily there were a few cabs headed back to town from further up the road, and one picked us up so we didn't have to walk very far at all. Just be prepared to walk in case you're not as lucky!We paid the entrance fee of $10 US dollars each, plus more to rent snorkel gear and/or a waterproof flashlight. You definitely need at least one flashlight in your party because many parts of the cave are not lit, and it's fun shining the light under the beautiful water. My son got the snorkel gear, but the rest of us did not. It was very fun either way, just a preference if you want to see under the water.The restrooms had running water and working toilets where you can change into your swimsuits. Make sure everyone in your party uses the restroom before you go down into the caves. Everyone will be given life-jackets and helmets. Helmets are for the first cave and life jackets are for the next two.I recommend going in the afternoon when there are not as many tour groups there. There was only one group of about 20 people there from a cruise ship when we arrived about 2pm, but I understand that it is much more crowded in the mornings with groups. We had the last cave all to ourselves and we swam and explored and had a wonderful time. We spent about two hours there total. The people were friendly, but we could only find one who spoke English well enough to tell us where to go and what to see. He was extremely helpful and took us through each of the caves. This is a perfect excursion for a hot afternoon when you want to cool off. I would not recommend this activity for very small children who cannot swim, or who are afraid of the dark. Older kids who can swim will have a great time. The caves were beautiful and definitely worth visiting, especially if you are staying in Playa del Carmen since it was right there in town.
